Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The village elders never asked things idly; every inquiry was a test, every silence a trap. He stared at the red dust swirling outside the meeting hut, wishing he could vanish into it. But the chief’s eyes remained fixed on him, patient and unblinking.

He replayed his answer in his head, hunting for flaws. Had he said too much? Too little? The other boys shifted, feet scuffing the packed earth, but none dared look his way. This was his moment to prove himself—or reveal a secret best left buried.

The chief finally spoke, his voice low and grave. “And if the path is blocked, ẹniọlá, what will you do?”

Ẹniọlá’s mind raced. He thought of the stories his grandmother told, of spirits and shadows, of courage and cunning. Summoning what little boldness he had, he met the chief’s gaze. “I will find another way, even if I must walk into the forest alone.”

A hush fell. The elders exchanged glances. Something unseen shifted; the test, for now, was over.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The principal’s office was colder than he remembered, the air stinging his skin and making him regret not bringing his sweater. He stared at the faded blue carpet, his mind scrambling for answers to questions that hadn’t yet been asked.

Ms. Olumide tapped her pen on the desk, her glasses perched precariously on her nose. “So, you say you found the phone in the corridor?” she asked, her tone neutral but her eyes sharp.

He nodded, feeling the heat rise in his cheeks. Was that all she wanted to know? Or would she press further, ask who he was with, why he was late to class? He could feel the truth bubbling up, threatening to spill out.

But then, the bell rang, shrill and urgent. Ms. Olumide sighed, glancing at the clock. “We’ll continue this tomorrow, Ẹniọlá.”

Relief flooded his chest as he slipped out of the office. There would be more questions, he knew, but for now, he had time to decide which answers he would give.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. He shifted, feeling the worn fabric of his trousers against his skin, and tried to remember exactly what he’d said. The room was quiet, except for the ticking of the clock and the distant clatter of plates from the kitchen. His mother sat across from him, her eyes sharp, her lips pressed in a thin line.

She set her mug down with a soft thud. “And what happened after you left the market?”

Ẹniọlá stammered, “I… I went to Tunde’s house, Mama. We played football.”

She raised an eyebrow. “Hmm. Is that so?”

He nodded, too quickly.

A long silence stretched between them. Ẹniọlá’s heart thudded in his chest. He wondered if she knew about the money he’d found—or the trouble he’d narrowly avoided.

Finally, she let out a sigh. “Next time, come straight home. The world is changing, Ẹniọlá. I need to know you’re safe.”

He nodded again, this time slower, promising himself that next time, he’d tell the whole truth. Or at least a little more of it.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question.

responses.text:
Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The silence in the room grew thick, punctuated only by the distant whirring of the ceiling fan. Auntie Ronke’s eyes never blinked, her fingers drumming a soft rhythm on the tablecloth. He could feel sweat pooling beneath his shirt, but he forced a smile. “So, Ẹniọlá, you say you helped with the project,” she finally spoke, voice gentle but sharp beneath the surface. “Can you explain what you did exactly?”

His mind raced. The truth was complicated, tangled up with promises and secrets he’d made to his friend Tobi. He looked down, searching for the words in the swirling patterns of the rug. “I, uh… I collected the materials,” he stammered. “And I made the, um, poster.”

Auntie Ronke raised an eyebrow. “Collected the materials? Which ones?”

The follow-up had come, sharper than a mosquito’s bite. Ẹniọlá knew he’d have to decide: reveal the truth, or invent a story clever enough to fit the silence.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The interview had already gone on longer than expected, and each answer seemed to lead the panel deeper into his past. He tried to focus on the patterned tile below, hoping the next question wouldn’t expose the secret he’d carried since childhood.

The chair creaked as Mrs. Adeoye leaned forward, her pen poised. “So, Ẹniọlá, what did you do after the incident at the river?”

He hesitated, memories of laughter and then screams flashing behind his eyes. “I—I ran for help,” he managed, his voice barely above a whisper.

Mrs. Adeoye nodded slowly, unconvinced. Silence fell again, and for one terrifying moment, Ẹniọlá thought about running from the room itself. But he stayed, heart pounding, knowing that sometimes, the hardest questions were the ones left unasked.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The teacher’s gaze lingered on him, her pen hovering above the register. His classmates sat frozen, as though his answer would determine their fate too.

He shifted in his seat. “I… I finished the assignment, Miss.”

Her lips curled into a thin smile. “And did you work alone, Ẹniọlá?”

He swallowed hard, recalling how Fẹmi had whispered answers to him that morning. Honesty warred with loyalty in his chest. He glanced at the clock, willing the bell to ring, but time seemed to have paused just for him.

At last, he met her eyes. “I tried my best,” he said, voice trembling.

The teacher nodded, making a mark on her paper. The tension eased, but the lesson lingered: sometimes, the hardest questions were the ones you asked yourself.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The last time he’d lied to his grandmother, he’d ended up confessing before the beans finished boiling. Now, sitting on the rickety bench, he tried to steady his breath.

“Ẹniọlá, are you sure you didn’t touch the kola nuts?” her voice came again, sharp and suspicious.

His eyes darted to the woven basket, still missing two nuts. Should he admit it? The taste still lingered on his tongue, sweet and bitter all at once.

He shook his head, but the guilt was a heavy stone in his belly. His grandmother sighed, her knowing eyes softening. “Next time, just ask if you are hungry. You are never too old for honesty.”

He nodded, voice caught in his throat, silently resolving to do better. Sometimes, the hardest person to outwit was oneself.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The room was tense, the air thick with the smell of fried plantain and secrets. Uncle Dayo leaned back, his face unreadable, knuckles white around his cup of tea.

“So,” Uncle Dayo said, “where did you say you were last night?”

Ẹniọlá hesitated, recalling the pulsing lights and wild music of the party he wasn’t supposed to attend. He had practiced his story: ‘at Tunde’s house, studying for the exam.’ But now, under Uncle Dayo’s gaze, the words tangled in his mouth.

“I… I was with Tunde,” he managed. His uncle’s eyebrow arched, skeptical.

“And Tunde’s mother? Did she see you?”

Ẹniọlá’s heart pounded. He didn’t know. He shook his head, hoping it would be enough. Uncle Dayo sighed, turning back to his newspaper, letting the lie settle, at least for now.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question.

responses.text: Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. He glanced over the rim of his glasses at the looming figure of his uncle, who sat across the table, drumming his thick fingers against the worn wood. “So, Ẹniọlá, you said you went to the market… and then?” Uncle’s eyes narrowed. The lie he’d told about where he’d been was already unravelling. The secret art studio hidden behind the yam stall was not a place his family would approve of; he was meant to be studying for exams, not painting murals on cracked plaster walls. His heart thudded. He could feel the itch spreading up his leg—a sure sign of nerves. “And then I, uh, bought some tomatoes,” Ẹniọlá mumbled. Uncle’s eyebrow arched. “Just tomatoes?” The air felt thick. If only his uncle knew about the bright blue paint smudged on his left hand, or the sketches tucked in his backpack. As the silence stretched, Ẹniọlá realized he had a choice: keep hiding, or share his secret world of color. He took a deep breath, readying himself for the truth.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The room was silent except for the ticking of the old wall clock and the distant sound of rain. His mother sat opposite him, her eyes sharp and unblinking. "You know, Ẹniọlá, honesty is like a river. It always finds its way out," she said softly, her voice threading through his nerves. He shifted in his seat, feeling the sweat gather at the back of his neck. The lie about where he’d spent the afternoon was flimsy at best, and he knew it wouldn’t hold under much scrutiny. He could invent another story, or he could confess. He glanced out the window, watching a bird shake water from its feathers. Maybe, if he told the truth about the forbidden football match, the consequences wouldn’t be as dire as he feared. Gathering his courage, he cleared his throat and opened his mouth. The truth felt heavy but somehow lighter than the burden he’d been carrying.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The elders in the circle were not known for their mercy, especially when it came to tales of mischief. He felt the gaze of his grandmother, sharp as a hawk’s, and the corner of her mouth twitched, as though she’d already guessed the truth. "So, Ẹniọlá, what happened after you saw the goat?" she asked, voice mild but loaded. He stammered, searching for a plausible story. The goat, with its mischievous eyes, had indeed led him astray—right into the old shrine where children were forbidden. The memory of the cool shadows and the strange carvings sent a shiver up his spine. Should he tell them about the voice he’d heard in the darkness, or would they laugh, chalking it up to childish imagination? He pressed his lips together, torn between fear and wonder, and realized this was a story only he could truly know.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. He could almost predict the glint in his teacher’s eyes, the slow inhale she always took before launching another inquiry. The classroom felt unusually stuffy, and he shifted in his seat, hoping his nervous energy wouldn’t betray him. “Ẹniọlá, you said you finished your assignment at home. Can you tell us what sources you used?” Her voice was gentle, but he heard the challenge in it. He swallowed, remembering the frantic copying from his cousin’s notes and the hurried scribbles to disguise his tracks. Should he admit the truth and risk embarrassment, or try to bluff his way through? The weight of the room’s collective gaze pressed on him. He looked down at his worn sandals, feeling the scratch intensify. Maybe it was time to own up, to let go of the anxiety. With a shaky breath, he met her eyes and decided to speak honestly.

Ẹniọlá scratched his thigh, worried that there might be a follow-up question. The air in the room felt thick, as if it held its breath along with him. His father’s gaze was unwavering, expectant. "You said you found the necklace behind the shed. Is that all you remember?" Ẹniọlá’s mind raced. He couldn’t mention the shadowy figure he’d glimpsed slipping away, nor the whispered warnings he’d heard in the night. Those details would only bring more questions, ones he wasn’t ready to answer. He shifted, wishing the itch on his thigh would distract him enough to forget the truth. "Yes," he said, voice barely steady. "That’s all." But as silence stretched, he wondered how long secrets could stay buried, and if perhaps, tonight, the truth would find him before morning did.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun in nauseous swathes of color and noise. Distantly, the echo of laughter mingled with the scrape of shoes on concrete. He tried to blink, but his eyelids felt glued down, heavy as lead. The taste of blood—iron and salt—spread along his gums. He had known the alley was a risk, but desperation drove him here. As the darkness pressed in, he heard a voice, sharp and unfamiliar, bark an order: “Leave him. We’ve got what we came for.” Footsteps receded. A cold drizzle needled his cheek. He forced his eyes open, saw the glint of his mother’s locket on the ground beside him. Somehow, through the haze, he found the strength to crawl toward it. His fingers closed around the silver. He would not let them take everything.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Rain drummed against the pavement, a relentless rhythm marking the seconds he lost to unconsciousness. When his eyes fluttered open, he saw only blurred silhouettes—shadows in the alley, moving away. He groaned, clutching his aching head, and tried to remember why he was here. The briefcase—where was the briefcase? Panic seized him. He staggered to his feet, searching desperately, but all he found was the echo of his own ragged breathing. The deal had gone wrong, he realized. They had left him alive, maybe as a warning. But as he limped out of the alley, the taste of defeat bitter in his mouth, he resolved that next time, he would be ready. He would get it all back.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Dull pain replaced thought, and for a moment, the alley dissolved into a swirl of neon fragments. The world returned in muffled bursts: a voice snarling, a boot nudging his side, the distant wail of sirens. He forced himself to focus, bracing against the slick pavement with trembling hands. As the assailants melted into the darkness, he caught a glimpse of a tattoo—a serpent coiled around a broken clock—etched on the wrist of the man who’d struck him. He would remember that. He had to. Blood dripped from his brow as he dragged himself upright. The night had only begun, and so had his hunt for answers.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Silence followed, broken only by the flutter of his breath and the distant hum of traffic. In the fog of semi-consciousness, a memory flickered: his father’s voice, stern and calm. "Never go alone." He had come alone, of course, trusting no one else with the package. Now, sprawled on cold asphalt, he felt the weight of his mistake. Steps approached, deliberate and slow. A hand gripped his shoulder, turning him over. Instead of a stranger, he saw the sharp blue eyes of his sister. "You didn’t think I’d let you do this by yourself, did you?" she whispered. Relief mingled with pain. He wasn’t alone, after all.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, the world stopped—then the pain came rushing in, hot and bright. His vision blurred, but through the haze he caught the glint of a silver ring on the attacker’s finger. He tried to speak, but his jaw wouldn’t cooperate. Someone was shouting—maybe at him, maybe over him. The sidewalk pressed cold against his cheek. In a final surge of will, he rolled onto his back, squinting at the streetlights overhead. He swore he saw wings—dark, ragged, impossibly large—framing the silhouette of his assailant. Then the world faded to black, leaving only the echo of feathers and the taste of fear.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world swam with flashes of red and black, voices echoing in distorted waves. Somewhere above, rain began to fall, icy needles prickling his skin, urging him back to consciousness. He tasted blood, coppery and thick, pooling in his mouth. Slowly, he opened an eye, blinking through the blur to see boots retreating down the alley, shadows shrinking into darkness. His memories tumbled and scattered—why was he here? Who had struck him? As he fumbled for answers, his fingers brushed something cold: a small, intricately carved locket, unfamiliar yet oddly comforting. He clutched it tightly, a fragile tether to reality, and forced himself upright. The night was far from over, and somewhere in the city, someone knew why he lay bleeding in the rain. He would find them, and he would learn the truth—no matter what it cost.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. In the haze between consciousness and oblivion, he heard the jangle of keys and a hurried whisper. The alleyway's neon glow flickered above, painting the puddles with sickly color. He tried to move, but his limbs were leaden, his thoughts scattered by pain. Something heavy pressed against his chest: a boot, pinning him in place. Then a voice, cold and unfamiliar, spoke, "Stay down if you want to live." Moments later, the pressure vanished. When he finally forced himself up, the world spun, and he realized his wallet was gone. But tucked into his fist was a scrap of paper, scrawled with an address he didn’t recognize. His head pounding, he staggered to his feet, the sense of threat mingling with a strange, irresistible curiosity.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The alley’s brick walls loomed, closing in as his vision danced with sparks. He fought to stay conscious, but the pain was overwhelming. Through the ringing in his ears, he heard hurried footsteps fading away, and the distant wail of a siren. Then, another sound—a soft, hesitant rustle. A pair of small hands searched his pockets, trembling. He tried to speak, but only a groan escaped. The hands withdrew, leaving something behind: a folded note, damp from the rain. As he faded into darkness, only one word from the note registered in his mind: "Run." When he awoke, hours later, the note was crumpled in his fist, and the warning echoed through the empty alley.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. His vision snapped to black, and for a moment he floated in a void where time stretched like syrup. Then, a sudden chill brought him back. Rain spattered his cheeks, mingling with blood. He blinked, groggy, as fluorescent lights buzzed above. The alley was empty except for a stray cat, watching from atop a dumpster. Disoriented, he tried to recall the attack—flashes of a masked figure, glint of metal, a whisper: "This is your last warning." His trembling hands dug into his pocket, finding a coin he’d never seen before—engraved with a serpent devouring its tail. As sirens approached, urgency surged in his chest. He staggered upright, knowing he couldn’t wait for help. Whatever message they’d tried to send, he wasn’t finished yet.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun sideways, blurred voices above him arguing in frantic tones. He tried to rise, but his limbs wouldn’t obey. Something metallic pressed into his palm, unfamiliar and cold. Through the fog, he glimpsed a figure kneeling beside him, urgency etched into their face. “You have to go,” they whispered, shoving something into his coat pocket. Tires screeched, and the figure vanished into the darkness. When he finally managed to sit up, he found a train ticket in his pocket—one-way, midnight departure, destination scrawled in ink he didn’t recognize. The pain in his head flared as he read the name, and a memory clawed its way to the surface: a promise he’d made long ago, and now, somehow, he had no choice but to keep.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, the world spun into a kaleidoscope of color and sound, the jeers of the crowd fading into a dull roar. He tasted copper, felt the grit of the alleyway press into his cheek. Above him, boots scraped and voices argued in a language he almost understood. With a herculean effort, he forced his eyes open. The blurry silhouette of his attacker loomed, rummaging through his pockets with shaking hands. He tried to move, but his limbs ignored him. As darkness threatened to close in, something sharp pressed into his palm—a key, dropped by mistake. Even as consciousness ebbed, a single thought flickered through his mind: this wasn’t over. Not by a long shot.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world flickered, then dimmed, leaving him floating in a hazy twilight. In that suspended space, he heard whispers—urgent, pleading. He tried to reach out, but his arms were heavy, pinned by invisible weights. Suddenly, light split the darkness. He glimpsed a child’s face, wide-eyed and frightened, clutching a worn teddy bear. The child pressed a finger to her lips. "Shh," she breathed. "They’ll hear you." Panic surged within him as footsteps echoed nearby. Was this memory, dream, or something else? He tried to speak, to warn her, but his voice was lost in the void. Then, as suddenly as it began, the world snapped back into focus—he lay bleeding in the alley, alone, hunted, with only the child’s warning echoing in his ears.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The lights of the underground ring swirled above him, harsh and unrelenting. He heard the ref’s voice, distant and muffled, counting. But for him, the fight wasn’t over—not in the way the crowd expected. As his opponent celebrated, he rolled over, clutching the tiny scrap of paper slipped into his glove before the bout. On it: a name, an address, and a single word—"Run." Gritting his teeth, he struggled to his knees, ignoring the pain, knowing that what happened in the ring was nothing compared to what waited outside. He’d lost the fight, but the real game was just beginning, and he was determined not to go down again.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Silence enveloped him, broken only by the ragged breaths of his assailant. Time seemed to stretch, each heartbeat echoing in his ears. As his vision blurred, he glimpsed a shadow detaching itself from the alley wall—a figure cloaked in midnight, moving with deliberate grace. The stranger knelt beside him, gloved hands examining his injuries. He tried to speak, but blood filled his mouth. The figure pressed something cold and metallic into his palm. "You’ll know when to use it," came a whisper. Then the world faded, leaving only questions and the chill of the object in his grasp.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. As consciousness flickered, he remembered the package in his coat pocket—the one he’d sworn to deliver, no matter the cost. Above him, the city’s neon glow blurred into streaks. Someone knelt beside him, rough hands rifling through his jacket. Panic surged. Suddenly, a dog barked in the distance, startling the mugger, who bolted into the night. Somehow, the package remained, untouched. He clutched it to his chest, willing himself to stand. The mission wasn’t over; if anything, it had just become more urgent. With a groan, he staggered to his feet, determined to finish what he’d started—even if the world seemed intent on stopping him.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Darkness closed over him like a velvet curtain, muffling the distant shouts and the slap of hurried footsteps. When he came to, a coppery taste filled his mouth, and the flicker of a dying bulb overhead painted everything in jaundiced light. His vision split, then refocused on the boots standing inches from his face. "You should've stayed out of it," a gravelly voice hissed. The boots moved, revealing a glint of metal—a battered locket, dropped in the scuffle. Groping blindly, he clutched it, feeling the warmth of old memories pulse through the cold metal. Somewhere above, sirens wailed, and the world spun sideways. Clutching the locket, he whispered a name. The footsteps retreated. He remembered why he came here: to find her, to make things right. Blood trickled past his eyebrow, but he crawled toward the light pooling under a distant door. Whatever waited for him on the other side, he was ready. Because she was worth it.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world swirled in and out of focus as he heard laughter, harsh and triumphant, echoing somewhere above him. He tried to move, but his limbs felt underwater, heavy and useless. Through the ringing in his ears, a distant memory surfaced—the smell of fresh bread, the sound of his sister's giggle. He clenched his jaw, fighting the tide of oblivion. Suddenly, a soft hand touched his cheek. "Stay with me," a voice pleaded. It was familiar, but not from this world. He opened his eyes to find a young girl, translucent and shimmering, bending over him. Her eyes glimmered with sadness. "You have to wake up," she whispered. The alley faded, replaced by fields of gold, sunlight streaming through endless skies. For a moment, he floated there, weightless. Then, with a gasp, he jolted awake—alone, battered, and changed. The ghost of her touch lingered, guiding him onward.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The taste of pennies filled his mouth as the world spun away, replaced by a cold, starless void. Somewhere above, the neon sign flickered, the only witness to his fall. He drifted, untethered, through fragments of old arguments, laughter, and the echo of his mother's lullabies. Then, a distant voice sliced through the darkness: "Get up, we don't have much time." He forced his eyes open. Blurred faces loomed, but one stood apart—a girl with a scar above her brow, hand outstretched. "You don't want to die here," she said. Gathering the broken pieces of his will, he reached up. She hauled him to his feet. The alleyway was empty now, save for the memory of violence and a single, bloodied coin spinning in the gutter. He staggered after her, mind churning with questions. But for now, escape was enough.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, the world narrowed to a tunnel of pain and static, then faded to black. When he awoke, the alley was empty, save for a stray cat licking raindrops from a discarded newspaper. His head throbbed, and he struggled to piece together what had happened. Slowly, fragments returned—the hurried footsteps, the shadowy figure, the glint of steel. He checked his pockets; the envelope was gone. Panic clawed at him, but he forced himself upright, leaning against the cold brick. Above, city lights blinked indifferently. He had to get the envelope back. Staggering forward, he followed the faint trail of muddy footprints, his resolve hardening with each step. The city was vast and merciless, but so was his determination. Somewhere out there, his assailant was waiting. And this time, he would not be caught unaware.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. He drifted in and out of consciousness, voices muffled and warped by the pounding in his skull. When he finally managed to open his eyes, he was alone, sprawled on the cracked pavement. A cold rain began to fall, washing the blood from his cheek. He sat up, memories returning in jagged flashes: the briefcase, the alleyway, the promise he’d made. With trembling hands, he checked his jacket—empty. They’d taken it. Panic threatened to overwhelm him, but he forced himself to focus. He’d come too far to give up now. He stood, swaying, and stumbled down the alley, following the faint glow of taillights disappearing into the night. Somewhere ahead, the thieves carried more than a briefcase—they carried his last chance. Teeth gritted, head pounding, he pushed onward, determined to reclaim what he’d lost, no matter the cost.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun and flickered, darkness licking at the edges of his vision. Choking on the taste of blood, he tried to remember why he was here, why the alley reeked of old rain and fear. Above him, footsteps retreated. Or maybe advanced. He couldn’t tell. The cold pavement bit into his cheek, grounding him. Somewhere a dog barked, sharp and insistent. He heard laughter—familiar, cruel. He forced his eyes open, seeing only blurred shapes and neon ghosts. As the night pressed in, a hand gripped his shoulder. Not to help, but to search. His wallet was gone. The footsteps faded, leaving only the sting and the memory. He blinked once, twice. He knew this city would eat him alive. But as the rain began to fall, washing blood from his brow, he made a promise to himself: tonight, he’d get up. Tonight, he’d find out who had taken everything from him. And he’d take it back.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The warehouse lights flickered above, throwing broken shadows across the concrete. For a moment, he hovered on the brink of consciousness, the copper tang of blood on his lips. He blinked, vision swimming, and saw boots circling him—three pairs, maybe four. Someone muttered, "Check his pockets." They rifled through his jacket, finding nothing but a crumpled photograph. One of them snorted, holding it up to the light. "This her?" he jeered. But the man on the floor couldn't answer; all he saw was her face, smiling, the only thing he had left to fight for. As another boot connected with his ribs, he curled tighter around that memory. He would not let them take it. Not tonight. Not ever.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world narrowed to a pinprick of pain and confusion. Above him, the night sky spun, punctuated by the harsh glare of streetlights. He tried to remember how he’d gotten here—what had he said? What had he done? The faces of his attackers blurred together, shadows with clenched jaws and hard eyes. Something cold pressed into his palm: his house key. A small mercy. As footsteps retreated, he forced himself upright, swaying. The city thrummed around him, indifferent. He spat blood onto the sidewalk and staggered toward the distant glow of home, vowing that if he ever made it through this night, he’d never walk these streets alone again.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. Above him, ceiling tiles swirled in slow motion, their patterns forming and dissolving. The muffled roar of the crowd faded into the background, replaced by the high-pitched whine of adrenaline. He tried to rise, but his limbs disobeyed, weighted by exhaustion and shame. The referee’s voice echoed: “Stay down, kid.” But he wasn’t just fighting for a title tonight—he was fighting for rent, for dignity, for the bruised hope that maybe, just maybe, he could turn his luck around. As the count reached eight, he pushed himself to his knees, jaw set against the pain. He caught his opponent’s eye—a silent promise that this fight wasn’t over yet.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, there was only ringing silence, broken by the distant hum of traffic. He tasted metal, felt the grit beneath his cheek. The alley’s bricks pressed cold against his back. He blinked, vision filled with stars. Above him, a figure hesitated—then knelt, whispering, “I’m sorry. I had to.” The voice trembled. Fingers pressed something into his hand—a tiny folded note. Then footsteps faded, leaving him alone with a secret he hadn’t asked for. He forced his eyes open, unfolded the paper, and read: "Meet me at dawn. Trust no one." Even as pain throbbed through his skull, curiosity burned brighter than fear. He would be there.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground.

responses.text: A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. For a moment, the world was nothing but blackness, punctuated by the distant echo of laughter and the sharp, metallic tang of blood in his mouth. Fingers scrabbled in the dirt as his senses flickered back, one by one. He blinked, vision blurry, the alley spinning around him. The last thing he remembered was the flash of a silver ring on his assailant’s hand—a detail he’d seen in the dossiers. He forced himself upright, pain flaring in his skull, and pushed through the fog in his mind. The package was gone, and so was the shadowy figure he’d been tailing all night. He cursed, struggling to his feet. Somewhere in the darkness, footsteps faded into silence. He wiped his brow, tasting fear and regret, and made a promise to himself: this wasn’t over. Not by a long shot.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world spun away, but in that darkness, colors burst behind his eyes—memories, or maybe dreams. He saw his childhood home, the garden his mother loved, the old oak tree. He clung to the vision, willing the pain to recede. When he finally blinked awake, the alley was empty except for the rain that pattered against his cheek. His wallet was gone, but his resolve remained. He dragged himself upright, every muscle shaking, and staggered toward the distant neon glow. He knew who had attacked him. He knew why. And as he limped into the storm, he swore to reclaim what had been stolen—not just his wallet, but the life he’d lost to these endless, violent nights.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The cold concrete pressed against his cheek, and the world seemed to ripple at the edges. Above, blurred faces hovered, their voices muffled as if underwater. "Is he out?" one hissed. He wanted to answer, to leap up, but his limbs were leaden. A boot nudged his ribs, then retreated. As the footsteps faded, silence crept in. Minutes stretched; rain began to fall, warm and sticky with summer’s humidity. When he finally stirred, the alley was empty except for a stray cat, watching with curious yellow eyes. He pushed himself up, head throbbing, and smiled grimly. They thought he was finished. But he had something they wanted, hidden deep in his jacket. He staggered away, the secret pressing against his ribs, determined to survive until sunrise.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. He drifted in a haze, not quite unconscious, not quite alive. Above him, neon signs flickered, casting garish colors across the cracked pavement. Shadows shifted—shapes with voices, arguing, searching his pockets. He heard the jingle of keys, the snap of a wallet. Panic clawed at him, but his body refused to move. As the footsteps retreated, a gentle rain began to fall. The water shocked him awake, and he gasped, sitting up too quickly. His head spun, but he forced himself to stand. Down the alley, two figures melted into the night. He staggered after them, driven by something deeper than fear—a need for answers, or revenge, he wasn’t sure. But he knew, as the rain masked the blood on his face, that this night was far from over.

A sickening thunk as a fist crashed into his temple; he slumped to the ground. The world turned sideways, then vanished altogether. When he came to, time had lost its meaning—maybe minutes had passed, maybe hours. There was a coppery taste in his mouth, the sting of gravel pressed into his cheek. He rolled onto his back, eyes catching the dim light filtering through the alley. His attacker was gone, but a single playing card rested on his chest: the queen of spades. He stared at it, confusion and dread twisting inside him. He knew what it meant—a warning, or perhaps a challenge. With shaking hands, he pocketed the card and hauled himself upright. His head throbbed, but a strange resolve hardened in his chest. The game had started, and he had no choice but to play.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass.

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I hesitate for only a moment before chasing after him, the cold morning air biting at my cheeks. My flashlight beam darts wildly, illuminating flashes of his black hoodie and the glint of something metallic in his hand. My heart thunders in my chest as I close the distance, branches whipping at my arms. He veers left, plunging into the thicket, but I know these woods better than anyone. Cutting through a narrow trail, I intercept him by the old stone well, where he turns, breath heaving, desperation plain on his face. "Please," he gasps, dropping the object—a locket, glinting in the dawn. Recognition jolts through me. It’s my sister’s. Before I can react, he bolts again, disappearing into the shadows, leaving only the locket and a thousand questions spinning in the misty air.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. The moonlight barely catches his outline as he darts toward the tree line, but I recognize the limp in his stride. I call out, but my voice is swallowed by the fog. My feet barely touch the ground as I give chase, adrenaline pushing me faster. Suddenly, he stumbles, tumbling down the embankment to the creek below. I stop at the edge, peering down as he struggles to his feet. With a trembling hand, he holds up the object he was clutching—a faded photograph. "You don’t understand," he whispers, voice ragged. "It’s all I have left of her." My anger dissolves into confusion. The secrets of the night settle between us, thick as the mist rising from the water.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I shout for him to stop, but he only moves faster, cutting across the field toward the abandoned barn. My breath forms clouds in the chilled air as I sprint after him. He crashes through the rotted barn doors, and I follow, heart hammering. Inside, the darkness swallows him, but I hear the scuffle of his feet in the hay. My hand finds the switch on my flashlight. Its beam falls on an upturned crate, then the figure crouched behind it, clutching a battered violin case. He looks up at me, face streaked with tears. "I just wanted one last song," he pleads. Something in his eyes makes me lower my voice. "Play it, then," I say, and in the hollow barn, the first trembling notes rise with the dawn.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. My instincts scream at me to give chase, but something about the scene feels off. Instead of following, I crouch behind the hedge and watch as he sprints clumsily, glancing over his shoulder. Suddenly, a second figure emerges from the shadows, moving silently and swiftly, intercepting the runner. There’s a brief struggle, a flash of silver, and the first figure drops to his knees. The second figure melts back into the darkness, leaving the limp body sprawled on the grass. I stay hidden, heart pounding, realizing I’ve witnessed something far more sinister than a simple theft. As dawn breaks, sirens wail in the distance, and I know I’ll never forget the chill of that morning or the secrets the dew-slicked grass tried to keep.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I sprint after him, my breath ragged in my throat, determination fueling my legs. He vaults over the low fence at the edge of the park, but he misjudges the landing, tumbling to the pavement. I catch up, grabbing his arm as he tries to scramble away. Up close, he’s younger than I expected—maybe seventeen, panic wild in his eyes. He holds out a crumpled envelope. "It’s not mine," he whispers desperately. "They made me take it." Sirens wail in the distance. I glance at the envelope, my name scrawled across it in shaky handwriting. The truth unravels in my mind like a thread: I was meant to find him. But by who? And why?

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass.

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I chase after him, heart pounding, flashlight beam wavering through the mist. Each footfall echoes in the silent dawn, drawing crows from their perches. He darts between gravestones, cloak flapping in the cold air. My breath plumes white, and I stumble, catching myself on a leaning marble cross. He glances back, hood falling away to reveal not the criminal I expected, but a boy—barely older than my own son. In his arms, a bundle of wildflowers. He drops them at a headstone and bolts into the trees. I stand, catching my breath, piecing together the story: a midnight visit, a desperate tribute. The grass slowly settles. I approach the grave, kneeling to read the name chiseled in stone, and understand—for some, the night is never long enough to outrun grief.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I shout, but he only plunges deeper into the foggy park. I follow, my own feet sliding dangerously on the uneven ground, adrenaline dulling the sting of cold air in my lungs. He veers suddenly, vaulting over a fallen log, but the momentum carries him down into the hollow. There, under the ancient willow, he stumbles, and I catch up. He turns, breath ragged, a flash of panic in his eyes. In his hand, a glint of silver—a locket. "Please," he whispers, voice trembling, "I just wanted to see her again." The moonlight reveals his tears. I lower my flashlight, heart softening. Sometimes, the things we chase are not what they seem.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. Instinct takes over—I give chase, dodging low-hanging branches and vaulting a rusted fence. The figure glances back, panic flashing in his eyes, and makes a sharp turn into the abandoned greenhouse. I burst inside, glass crunching beneath my boots, but he’s already vanished. Only the sound of his breath remains, echoing in the shattered silence. Then, from behind a row of toppled planters, a low voice: "If you know what's good for you, you'll forget you saw me." I freeze. Something cold and metallic presses against my neck. Outside, dawn breaks, painting the world gold. Inside, time stands still as I weigh my next move. Sometimes, it’s not the chaser who holds all the power.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I hesitate, uncertain, but curiosity outweighs caution. I follow, careful not to make a sound. He darts behind the old maintenance shed, breathing hard. As I peek around the corner, he fumbles with a battered duffel bag, spilling its contents—a tangle of old photographs, yellowed with age. He looks up, startled, eyes wide. "I didn't steal them," he blurts. "They’re all I have left." The words hang between us, fragile as the morning mist. I step forward, hands open. "Maybe we can help each other," I say. The first rays of sunlight catch the tears on his cheeks, and for a moment, the world is quiet and new.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. He’s fast—much faster than I expected, but desperation makes for good fuel. I sprint after him, lungs burning, every muscle screaming as we cut through the deserted field toward the woods. My mind races with possibilities: who is he, what has he done, why was he waiting by the old oak? Just as he disappears into the shadows, I catch a glimpse of his face, familiar in a way that chills me. It’s my brother—gone for three years, presumed dead. I freeze, heart pounding. The forest swallows him whole. I stand alone, uncertain whether to follow or flee, knowing that this night has changed everything.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass.

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I hesitate before breaking into a sprint, the adrenaline mixing with confusion—why would he run from me? My flashlight’s beam bounces wildly as I chase him through the labyrinth of gravestones. The silence of the cemetery is broken only by our ragged breaths and the slap of shoes against wet earth. He vaults a low stone wall, nearly stumbling, but I’m close behind. When he glances back, I catch a glint of something metallic in his hand—a knife? My heart pounds. But as I close the distance, he suddenly stops, turning to face me. In the glow of the flashlight, I realize with a jolt: it’s my own brother, eyes wide with fear. "I thought you were—" he gasps, but before he can finish, the ground behind him heaves, and a skeletal hand bursts through the sodden turf. We freeze, caught between terror and disbelief as the past comes clawing up through the earth, demanding to be reckoned with.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I follow, breathless, pushing through the thick morning mist that curls around the old playground. His shadow flickers between the swings, vanishes behind the slide. I’m not sure why I’m chasing him—curiosity? Fear? The air tastes like copper and rain. Suddenly, he stops, turning to face me. His hood falls back, revealing not a face, but a swirling void, black and endless. I stumble, rooted by a terror I can’t name. The figure raises a hand, and the world around us seems to slow, grass bending as if caught in an invisible tide. "You shouldn’t have come here," a voice intones, hollow and echoing from the void. The playground dissolves, the only thing left is his outstretched hand. Against every instinct, I take it. The cold seeps into my bones, and the world folds in on itself, pulling us both into the darkness.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I don’t remember why I’m chasing him anymore—it’s something primal, a compulsion that tugs at my core. He zigzags between the old oak trees, glancing back, his eyes wide and wild. The air is thick with the scent of earth and rain, and my lungs burn. Suddenly, he veers left, plunging into the shadows beneath a crumbling gazebo. I follow, skidding to a stop inside the rotting structure. He’s cornered, back pressed against peeling wood. Our eyes meet, and for a moment, the world shrinks to the sound of our breaths. "You’re not supposed to be here," he whispers, and the ground beneath us shivers. Roots snake up through the floorboards, wrapping around his ankles. He looks at me, pleading. I reach out, but the roots recoil, dragging him into the darkness below. Silence settles, leaving me alone with the dew and the memory of running.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I shout, but my voice is swallowed by the damp morning air. I push harder, feet squelching in the mud, following the trail of crushed blades. He darts past the old willow, disappearing behind a tangle of brambles. I hesitate, then plunge after him, thorns catching my sleeves. Suddenly, I stumble into a clearing—a ring of mushrooms glowing faintly in the half-light. The figure stands in the center, motionless now, his breath steaming. He looks at me, eyes glinting, and gestures for silence. The world seems to tilt. From the shadows, a chorus of whispers rises, weaving through the trees. The mushrooms pulse brighter, and the figure steps back, melting into the mist. I try to follow, but the air thickens, my limbs grow heavy, and the whispers become laughter. When I blink, I’m alone—except for the faint imprint of footsteps vanishing into the fog.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I chase after him, my breath forming clouds in the cold dawn. He cuts left, vaulting over a fallen log, but I’m gaining. My flashlight beam wavers, catching his silhouette as he ducks beneath the twisted branches. Suddenly, he stumbles, crashing to the ground. I slow as I approach, wary. He scrambles backward, eyes wide, hands raised in surrender. "Please," he whispers, "I didn’t mean to take it." Confused, I kneel and see the reason for his fear—a small, intricately carved wooden box clutched to his chest. The air hums around it, the morning birdsong replaced by a low, pulsing thrum. I reach for the box. He lets it go with trembling fingers. When I open it, a swirl of silver mist escapes, coiling skyward. The figure sighs, relief and sorrow mingling on his face. "Thank you," he says, before dissolving into the mist himself, leaving me alone with the empty box and a sense that something ancient has been set free.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass.

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I break into a sprint, heart hammering in my chest, mind racing with questions. My flashlight beam dances over the uneven ground, catching fleeting glimpses of the fugitive—torn jacket, wild hair, something clutched tightly in his hand. Ahead, the old iron fence that borders the cemetery glistens with condensation. He vaults it, but catches his foot, tumbling hard to the ground. I close the distance, breathless. He scrambles to his knees, turning to face me, eyes wide and wild. In the ghostly light, I see tears streaming down his face. He thrusts the object toward me—a faded photograph, edges curled, faces I recognize instantly. "Please," he whispers, voice trembling. "You have to believe me. I didn’t mean for any of it to happen." My anger falters, replaced by confusion and a creeping dread. In the photo, I see myself, standing beside him in a place I don’t remember. The air grows colder. "What did you do?" I ask, barely above a whisper. He shakes his head. "It’s not over. Not yet."

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I pursue him, my breath clouding in the night air, the only sound the frantic slap of his feet and my own desperate chase. He darts behind the abandoned greenhouse, glass shards crunching underfoot. I close in, ready to tackle him if I must. But as I round the corner, he’s vanished. Only the echo of his ragged breathing lingers. Suddenly, a hand grabs my shoulder from behind. I spin, heart in my throat, but it’s not the figure—it’s an old woman, her eyes hollow and voice thin. “He’s not what you think,” she whispers. “He’s running from something much worse than you.” Before I can respond, a shadow passes over us both, chilling the night. The woman fades into mist, and I’m left alone, the grass beneath my feet slick and cold, haunted by a chase that suddenly feels like I was never the hunter, but the hunted.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I give chase, not sure if I’m guided by anger or fear. He weaves between trees, his form flickering in and out of the pale moonlight. Suddenly, he stumbles, crashing into a mossy log. I skid to a halt as he turns to face me, breathless. "Why are you following me?" he gasps, voice barely more than a rasp. I hesitate—wasn’t I the one with questions? But I can’t remember what drove me here, what I’m supposed to say. The air grows heavy, thick with the scent of wet earth and something metallic. Slowly, the figure gets to his feet, and as he steps closer, his face shifts—my own eyes, my own mouth, twisted in terror. "You can’t outrun yourself," he whispers, and the ground falls away beneath us, spiraling into darkness. I wake, gasping, dew on my skin, heart pounding, alone.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I shout, but my voice seems to vanish among the fog-shrouded trees. He leaps over a fallen branch, nearly losing his balance, and I chase after, ignoring the sting of cold air in my lungs. Suddenly, he stops short, spinning around to face me. His hood falls back, revealing a face I know all too well—my own. For a heartbeat, we stare at each other, twin expressions of confusion and fear. He lifts his hand; in his palm is a small, cracked mirror. "I had to run," he says quietly, "before you caught up to yourself." Before I can react, he shatters the mirror against a stone. The world tilts, trees folding in on themselves, and I am left standing alone in the silent dawn, wondering if I have been chasing a stranger or a shadow of myself.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I hesitate before following, but curiosity outweighs caution. I pursue him across the moonlit field, my footsteps muffled. He darts into the ruins of the old mill, disappearing into darkness. I pause at the threshold, listening. A soft clinking sound guides me deeper. Suddenly, he trips, sprawling across the floor. A small metal box spills from his jacket, coins and trinkets scattering. He looks up, fear and desperation etched on his face. "Please, I just needed a place to hide it," he pleads. I glance at the box—inside, an old locket with my initials engraved. My stomach drops. "Where did you get this?" I demand. He shakes his head, eyes wide. "It was always yours. I just kept it safe until you came back." The mill creaks as morning light filters in, illuminating the truth I never wanted to face.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass.

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. My flashlight beam bounces wildly as I give chase, heart pounding in my ears. He glances back, panic etched on his face, and stumbles over a tree root, tumbling hard. I slow, breath ragged, and approach cautiously. He’s not what I expected—just a teenager, face streaked with tears and mud. He clutches a worn notebook to his chest. “Don’t take it,” he pleads. I kneel beside him, curiosity outweighing suspicion. The pages flutter open, revealing sketches of our town, monsters lurking in the margins. Suddenly, a low growl vibrates through the mist. Both of us freeze. Maybe the monsters aren’t just in his drawings. Maybe, tonight, we’re both running from something darker than each other.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I shout his name, but the only response is the frantic pounding of his feet. My own shoes crunch over the frost, breath steaming in the cold night. He veers toward the old cemetery and vaults the crumbling stone wall. I hesitate—memories of that place haunt me still. But I press on, vaulting after him. In the moonlight, I see him pause near a toppled angel statue, searching for something beneath the weeds. I call out, softer now, and he turns, face pale. “I had to come back,” he whispers, eyes shining with something between hope and fear. “She told me to.” The wind rustles, and I swear I hear a girl’s laughter, echoing between the graves.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I quicken my pace, determined not to lose him this time. He darts behind the abandoned greenhouse, breath visible in the chilly dawn air. My lungs burn as I round the corner, only to find him crouched, hands trembling, staring at a small metal box half-buried in mud. He looks up, eyes wide with something that isn’t quite fear. “You followed me,” he says, voice barely above a whisper. I nod. The box glints in the weak light. He opens it, revealing a faded photograph and a strange, rusted key. “It’s not safe here,” he murmurs. A distant howl splits the silence. We both realize: we’re not alone.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I chase after him, the fog swirling around our legs. He’s fast, but desperation slows him, and I gain ground. Suddenly, he veers left, crashing through a patch of brambles. I follow, ignoring the thorns scratching my skin. We burst into a clearing where fireflies pulse above an ancient stone well. He stops, breathing hard, and turns to face me. His eyes are filled with a pleading I don’t understand. “You can’t let them find me,” he whispers, thrusting a crumpled letter into my hand. Before I can ask who, the distant sound of heavy boots approaches. The woods seem to close in, shadows twisting, as we both realize we’re being hunted.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I hesitate for a split second, then sprint after him, adrenaline flooding my veins. He vaults over a low hedge, nearly losing his balance, and disappears behind the old toolshed. I lunge around the corner, prepared for a fight, but what I find stops me cold. He’s kneeling beside a small, shallow grave, hands covered in dirt, tears streaming down his face. In the faint glow of dawn, I see the glint of a locket in his hand. He looks up, voice trembling. “I had to bring her back,” he says, gesturing to the disturbed earth. “I had to try.” A chill runs through me as I realize we are not alone—the air grows colder, and a whisper rides the breeze.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass.

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I shout after him, but the mist swallows my voice. My heart pounds as I pursue, breath clouding in the cold predawn air. He darts behind an ancient oak, vanishing for a heartbeat, then emerges farther down the hill, coat flapping like a raven’s wing. I push harder, legs burning, thinking of the envelope he’d snatched from my car—a year’s worth of secrets sealed in trembling hands. My foot catches a hidden root and I tumble, mud streaking my jeans. By the time I look up, the figure is gone, only a single black sneaker left behind in the grass, glistening with dew and something darker. I pick it up, trembling. The initials inside are my own.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I break into a sprint, but he’s already darting toward the tree line, moving with a frantic, animal energy. My flashlight beam wobbles, catching glimpses of his silhouette—tall, thin, a hood pulled tight. He glances back and for a second, our eyes meet; his are a startling, unnatural yellow. He vanishes between the trees. I hesitate at the edge, then plunge into the forest, branches whipping my face. The woods seem to swallow sound; I can’t hear his footsteps anymore. But I keep going, drawn by curiosity and dread. Suddenly, the ground gives way beneath me, and I tumble into darkness, landing in a shallow pit. Above, the yellow eyes blink down. "Welcome," a voice whispers. "We’ve been waiting for you."

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I chase, the cold air burning my lungs, determination overriding fear. He veers toward the abandoned greenhouse, its glass panes fractured and glinting in the pale moonlight. I follow, just in time to see him disappear inside. Cautiously, I step through the broken door; silence presses in, thick and expectant. Shadows huddle in the corners. Suddenly, a hand grabs my wrist, cold and desperate. "Help me," he rasps, voice trembling. In the faint light, I see his face—my own, but older, eyes wild with terror. Before I can speak, he melts away, leaving only the echo of my heartbeat and the sharp scent of dew and fear.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I pause, unsure if I should give chase. The air is thick with fog and the distant glow of town lights barely penetrates the gloom. Suddenly, a sharp whistle pierces the silence, and another silhouette emerges from the woods ahead, blocking the runner’s path. The two figures freeze, tension rippling between them. I step forward, calling out, but my voice is swallowed by the mist. The first figure turns, face illuminated by a flash of lightning—my own brother, eyes wide with fear. The second figure raises a hand, palm glowing with a blue, unnatural light. The world tilts, and I realize I’ve stumbled into something ancient, a feud older than our family secrets. I close my eyes, bracing for the storm.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I give chase, adrenaline surging, every step a guess in the dim morning. He vaults a crumbling stone wall, landing hard. I follow, but as I clear the wall, the figure is gone, vanished into the mist. Confused, I scan the silent field until I notice the glint of metal where he stood. Kneeling, I pick up a small key, cold and ornate—engraved with a symbol I’ve seen only in my father’s journals. A distant church bell tolls, and I realize this isn’t just a chase; it’s the beginning of a journey I never expected to take. The key is heavy in my hand, the air charged with the promise of secrets long kept and dangers stalking the edge of dawn.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

responses.text: For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. The rain had drummed all night on the tin roof of their small apartment, but as dawn crept in, she tiptoed across the creaky floorboards and placed Simon’s favorite mug near the heater. She filled it with steaming cocoa, sprinkled with cinnamon—just as his mother used to do. He hadn’t smiled much since she’d left, but when he shuffled into the kitchen, hair askew and eyes heavy, he paused at the sight. No words passed between them. responses.text:
The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so nothing really surprises me anymore. I clutch my duffel bag tighter, trying not to stare at the girl from the agency sitting on the velvet sofa. Her hair glints gold even in the dim lobby light. The parrot squawks, and the girl laughs—a melodic, unguarded sound. I wonder if she’s noticed me yet. Maybe she’s used to people being nervous around her. Maybe she’s nervous, too. I clear my throat, and she turns, eyes bright and curious. 

“You must be Mia,” she says, her accent hinting at somewhere far warmer.

I nod, not trusting my voice. The parrot man winks at us both and disappears into the lift. The girl stands, extending a hand. “It’s going to be fun, I think.”

I wish I believed her. But as we walk towards our new flat—and whatever London has planned—I can’t help but feel that the city has just handed me the beginning of a story I’ll never quite believe myself.

I watch the parrot’s glassy eyes swivel as I squeeze my suitcase tighter. My new flatmate, Amelia, is waiting by the door, her smile dazzling and her hair perfectly tousled. She offers to help with my bags, but I mumble something about managing.

We step into the flat, and the scent of freshly brewed coffee hits me. Amelia gestures to the kitchen, where a teapot steams beside a plate of homemade scones. Suddenly, the parrot man appears at our window, grinning, and waves. I realize with a start that the parrot’s wings are slowly flapping.

Amelia laughs, a sound like windchimes. “Welcome to London,” she says, “where nothing is ever as it seems.”

I smile, suddenly hopeful that maybe this city—and this beautiful stranger—hold more surprises than I dared expect.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was only real with me.

responses.text: It was only real with me. The world outside spun on in grayscale, a flickering film with actors mouthing lines I could not hear. But in the attic, beneath the dust-thick rafters, the old music box played just for me. Each evening, I wound its tarnished key, and the melody spilled secrets in a language I alone understood. Some nights, the tune summoned a gentle breeze, carrying scents of summer fields or winter hearths; other times, the shadows gathered around me, forming shapes that danced and bowed. I whispered to them, sharing truths too fragile for daylight. The world called it imagination, but they were wrong. When the music played, the attic pulsed with heartbeat and breath, with laughter and tears, as real as anything outside—more real, perhaps, because within these walls, I was seen. When the key finally snapped, its song stilled forever, I felt the attic's pulse fade. The world outside waited, unchanged, but something inside me would always hum with the memory of a place where everything was real, and it was only real with me.

It was only real with me. The others walked through the park, their feet never snagging on the invisible threads she left behind. But I felt them, soft and warm, trailing from the statue where she first appeared. Most days, I doubted myself. Maybe I’d invented her—the girl with honeycomb eyes and laughter like falling leaves. But every dusk, she spun through sunbeams, her touch cool on my wrist, promising adventures just for us. She showed me how to listen to the wind, how to taste rain on my tongue, how to hide secrets in the roots of trees. When I tried to tell my friends, their faces stretched with concern. They couldn’t see the footprints she left in the dew, or hear the music humming in the air. Eventually, I stopped trying. Instead, I met her by the willow tree, sharing stories and dreams. When she left for the final time, her goodbye was a hush in my ear. No one else would remember her, but I did. Because it was only ever real with me.

It was only real with me. The world outside my window spun with routine: neighbors watering their gardens, cars humming along cracked pavement, birds tracing invisible paths through the sky. But inside my room, something shimmered and shifted in the corners, a secret world that opened when the clock struck midnight. Glowing moths whispered riddles from the lampshade, and the stuffed rabbit on my shelf blinked slow, solemn eyes. I sat cross-legged on the floor, waiting. Soon the wallpaper would ripple, and the small, golden staircase would unfold. I’d climb, barefoot and breathless, into a land where rules ebbed and every wish tasted real. There, I could fly or speak in colors, and laughter sounded like chimes. Each night, I promised I’d tell someone, but each morning the world pressed down and the words dissolved. The magic lingered just for me—as real as the sun on my cheek, as fleeting as a sigh. When I grew older, the staircase stopped appearing, but I remembered. It was only real with me, and that was enough.

It was only real with me. I saw the ripples in the air above the old well, the way sunlight twisted into colors no one else could name. My brother tugged at my sleeve, urging me to keep up, but I lingered, transfixed. If I leaned close, the world behind the shimmer vanished and another unfolded—one where the crows spoke riddles and the grass hummed lullabies. I tried, once, to show my mother. She looked, squinting, then shook her head and smiled the way grown-ups do when they think you’re pretending. For years, I returned to the well, slipping between worlds for moments at a time. With each visit, the other side felt more solid, more urgent, until I longed for the days I could stay. One morning, the shimmer thickened, and the voices called my name. I stepped through, heart thundering, knowing that even if no one ever believed me, it was enough that I did. Because it was only real with me, and that was all it needed to be.

It was only real with me. At night, with the lights off and the curtains drawn, I slipped between the world everyone knew and the one that belonged solely to me. In that world, the closet door opened into a moonlit forest, where silver foxes guided me along hidden trails and the wind whispered my name. No one else saw the footprints glowing faintly on my bedroom carpet, or the tiny, star-bright flowers blooming in the shadowy corners. I tried once, nervously, to tell my older sister what I’d seen. She laughed and ruffled my hair, saying I had too much imagination. But I knew the truth: every night, when the house grew quiet, the magic returned. It didn’t matter if no one else believed me. I carried the secret world in my pocket, tucked beneath my pillow, stitched into the lining of my dreams. It was only real with me, and that was enough for both of us—the world and me.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was only real with me.

responses.text: It was only real with me. The world outside blurred at the edges, a half-remembered dream, while inside my studio, the colors and sounds sharpened into something fierce and alive. I pressed my hands into the wet clay, feeling its coolness, shaping it into a memory. Every line, every indentation, was a secret I whispered to myself, truths too fragile for daylight. Out there, I was someone’s daughter, someone’s friend, but here I was an architect of worlds. The sculpture took form beneath my fingers, a face I knew better than my own. No one else could see the way its smile curved just so, like the hope I tucked away each morning. The kiln hummed with anticipation, like a heart beating out a rhythm only I could hear. When the piece emerged, its glaze catching the light, I saw it clearly: a fragment of myself, solid and shining. Maybe no one else would understand, but that didn’t matter. In this space, with the clay and the silence, what I made was real. It was only real with me.

It was only real with me. The world thought it was a phase, an elaborate game I played to escape the monotony of my small-town life. But in the late hours, when everyone else slept, I would climb the rickety ladder to the attic and open the door to the other side. There, the wallpaper shimmered, and the floorboards hummed beneath my feet. I could see the city of glass spires and hear the laughter of invisible children echoing down moonlit streets. I would run, barefoot and free, chasing shadows that danced just out of reach. Only I could touch them, speak to them, and they would answer back in riddles and rhymes. No one else believed my stories, and maybe that was for the best. Some magic, I learned, is meant to be kept close, pressed to your heart like a secret letter. In the morning, I would wake to sunlight and dust, but the memory clung to me, tangible as the cool air of night. It was only real with me, but that was enough.

It was only real with me. The world saw an ordinary garden, patchy with weeds and tangled vines. But I knew where the wild strawberries grew, hidden beneath brambles, and where the foxes curled up to sleep in the shade of the pear tree. At dusk, when the sky bruised purple, I would slip outside, barefoot on dewy grass, and listen for the soft music that drifted from the old stone well. No one else ever heard it—the tinkling notes that called to me, promising adventure and solace in equal measure. Once, I tried to show my sister, but all she saw was muddy water and a frog. She shrugged and went back inside, but I lingered, tracing the rim with my fingers, whispering secrets into the moss. I think the well understood. Its melody grew richer, the stories more vivid, until I could almost believe I belonged to this place as much as it belonged to me. It was only real with me, and sometimes, that was all the reality I needed.

It was only real with me. No one else saw the flicker of golden light in the corner of the old library, the way it danced across the spines of forgotten books. I would sneak in after hours, careful not to wake the night watchman, and follow the glow deeper into the stacks. There, between encyclopedias and fairy tales, waited a door. It wasn’t there by day, but I learned to trust my instincts. Each time I turned the brass handle, I stepped into a different world—a frozen tundra, a sunlit meadow, a city built on clouds. Sometimes I brought back a pressed flower or a pebble, small tokens to prove to myself it had happened. I tried to tell my friends, but they just laughed. ‘A dream,’ they said. But I know what dreams feel like. This was more. The hush of the library, the scent of old paper, the thrill of discovery—it was only real with me, and in the end, that was enough.

It was only real with me. The silver locket I wore was just costume jewelry to everyone else, but when I pressed it to my lips and whispered my wish, I could feel the hum of possibility, the shift of air in the room. I closed my eyes and pictured her—my grandmother, young and laughing, dancing under lanterns at a festival that took place long before I was born. She would appear, translucent and shimmering, and sit beside me on my bed. We spoke in a language of smiles and songs I barely remembered. When the locket grew warm in my hand, I knew she was listening. The first time I told my mother, she looked away, her eyes shining. ‘That’s a lovely story,’ she said. But I knew. Some things exist only for those who believe in them hardest. The world kept spinning, indifferent and loud. But in the quiet, I waited for night, for the moment when the locket’s secret world opened up, and I was not alone. It was only real with me.
