“We can’t keep doing this,” he muttered. But Liza was already moving, calling the families together, whispering plans, urging courage. She did not believe in miracles, but she believed in stubbornness.

When the trucks came that night, the families were gone—vanished into the maze of alleys and darkness. In the morning, Liza found Kasim by the gate, smiling despite himself.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. 

He looked away, eyes following the dust motes drifting in the slanting sunlight. “You’re stubborn, you know that?”

Liza almost smiled. “Stubborn enough.”

Outside, a dog barked, and the children huddled closer to their mothers. The tension in the room was thick as old bread. Liza knelt, reaching for the smallest child, offering comfort she wasn’t sure she possessed. 

“We’ve come this far together,” she said, raising her voice for everyone to hear. “That won’t change.”

Kasim’s shrug was a shield. “I heard what happened in the next town. They’ll come.”

“They always come,” Liza replied, standing. “But so do we.”

For a heartbeat, Kasim’s eyes softened. Maybe he remembered before the walls went up, before the fear. 

Liza squared her shoulders. She would not let history write itself in silence.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He picked at the peeling paint on the windowsill. “You can’t promise that.”

“I can try.” Liza’s jaw was set. The room was stifling, stuffed with whispers and the scent of boiled cabbage. The children clustered together, their mothers’ hands brushing their hair. No one dared speak above a murmur.

Kasim exhaled, slow. “They’ll send more men next time.”

“Then we’ll find another cellar.”

A hush fell, broken only by the ticking of the old clock. Liza moved to the door, peering out into the dusk. In the garden, footprints crisscrossed the mud, leading away into the forest. She turned back to Kasim. “You coming?”

He hesitated, then nodded. The families followed, slipping into the night, shadows among shadows, bound by Liza’s stubborn hope.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He looked older now, his eyes shadowed by doubt. The others in the room shifted uneasily, sensing the weight of the moment.

“We can’t stop what’s coming,” Kasim said, voice flat.

Liza shook her head, defiant. “We can try. We owe them that.”

A woman in the corner squeezed her daughter’s hand, silent tears on her cheeks. Liza’s resolve hardened. She stepped forward, drawing the circle tighter around her. “No one leaves alone. If they come for one, they’ll have to take us all.”

“Maybe,” Liza replied, “but not tonight.”

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He glanced out the cracked window as the buses rumbled into the square, blue uniforms spilling out like ink. In the hush before orders were shouted, he flicked his cigarette into the muddy gutter. ‘You can say that,’ he muttered, ‘but what about the list?’

Liza pressed the clipboard tight to her chest. The names, scrawled in her hurried hand, felt heavier than lead. She caught the eyes of the little ones, huddled in the doorway, their mothers gripping their shoulders. ‘No one goes unless I see it myself. That was the agreement, Kasim.’

He snorted. ‘Agreements change.’

The door behind them creaked open. Mrs. Avrami, cheeks flushed, thrust a battered suitcase forward. ‘They said we have five minutes.’

Liza’s voice trembled but didn’t break. ‘No. You’ll go together. Or not at all.’

Somewhere outside, a whistle blew. Kasim stepped aside, his face unreadable. ‘We’ll see, Liza. We’ll see.’

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He bent down to tie his boots, his silence heavy with resignation. Rain pressed against the tent, drumming a nervous rhythm.

‘You’re stubborn, you know that?’ he said, not meeting her gaze.

‘They deserve at least that much,’ Liza replied, her voice softer now. ‘We all do.’

Kasim stood, brushing mud from his knees. ‘It’s not up to us. Orders came down last night. They want the men separated at dawn.’

Liza felt the chill creep up her spine. She watched as children curled into their mothers’ laps, and men sat in uneasy clusters. She walked to the entrance, squared her shoulders. ‘If they want to take them, they’ll have to get through me first.’

Kasim sighed, a sound almost like regret. Outside, the sound of engines rumbled closer. Liza gripped the pole beside her and waited, the storm both within and without growing by the minute.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He turned away, tracing a finger along the dusty table, eyes far away. ‘Promises,’ he muttered, as if the word itself could ward off the inevitable.

Liza stood taller, ignoring the ache in her calves. The room seemed smaller with each passing hour, filled with the quiet rustle of children and the tired sighs of mothers. ‘We have to try, Kasim. If we give in now, what’s left?’

He didn’t answer. Instead, he opened the door and let in a gust of stinging wind. Shadows flickered against the cracked walls.

‘They’re coming,’ he said, voice flat.

‘Then we hold the line,’ Liza replied.

Outside, boots pounded on gravel. Liza gathered the families close, her words a shield. Kasim lingered at the threshold, caught between hope and surrender. In the gathering dusk, Liza’s vow hung heavy as the coming night.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He flicked a glance towards the window, where shadows stretched long across the courtyard. ‘They’ll do what they want, Liza. You know that.’

She bristled, her hands curled into fists. ‘Not if we stand together.’

Kasim snorted. ‘Stand together? Against trucks, guns, orders? You’re dreaming.’

But Liza’s eyes flashed. ‘Dreams are all we have left. And I’ll fight for them.’

A whistle shrieked in the distance, sharp as a knife. Children pressed close to their parents. The guards would come soon. Liza planted herself in the doorway, blocking the path. Kasim hesitated, torn between fear and something like admiration.

‘You’re going to get yourself hurt,’ he warned.

‘Maybe. But not before they see we aren’t cattle.’

The latch rattled. Liza squared her shoulders. Behind her, dozens of faces waited, silent and desperate. She would not let them be torn apart without a fight.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. With a twitch of his shoulder, he turned away, pretending to study the peeling paint on the wall. ‘You keep saying that, but it’s not up to you.’

Liza pressed her lips together, fighting the urge to scream. The camp was already restless; word had spread that the officials would arrive by nightfall. She glanced at the cluster of children playing quietly in the corner, the mothers whispering worries behind trembling hands.

‘If we refuse, they’ll have to listen,’ she insisted.

Kasim’s face softened, just a little. ‘Or they’ll make an example of us all. You know how it goes, Liza.’

She stepped closer, lowering her voice. ‘Then let them. I won’t help them tear us apart.’

A hush fell as the first headlights pierced the dusk. Liza straightened, heart pounding, her resolve hardening as the hour drew near. Families pressed together. Liza’s promise was all they had left.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

responses.text:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. Outside, a thin drizzle traced lines down the dusty windowpane. For months, the old brick house on Elm Street had teetered between safety and threat, its inhabitants unsure which way the scales would tip. 

Kasim, arms folded, regarded Liza with a mixture of admiration and resignation. “You say that as if you believe it,” he said, voice barely above a whisper. 

“I do.” She tightened her grip around the battered folder. Inside, letters from each family—pleas for mercy, for time, for unity. 

Kasim shook his head. “They’ve already sent the paperwork. Tomorrow, they’ll come.”

“Then tonight, we hide them.” Determination flashed in her eyes. “If they search here, we’ll move them again. No one will sleep, but no one will be lost.”

For a moment, Kasim looked away. Then he nodded, just once. Outside, the drizzle became a steady rain, and the house became, for one more night, a sanctuary against the world’s indifference.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. His indifference was almost infuriating, but Liza steadied her breath. “You don’t understand, Kasim. We promised them.”

He toyed with the edge of the chipped table. “Promises mean little when the city council comes with their forms.”

Liza’s eyes narrowed. “Then we make them mean something. We take them to the warehouse on Sinclair. No one checks there. We keep them together—at least until the vote.”

Kasim let out a slow sigh, the kind that comes from exhaustion deeper than sleep can fix. “You’re risking a lot, Liza.”

She looked out the window at the families in the courtyard, children playing in oblivious clusters. “I know. But I’d rather risk everything than stand by and watch them get torn apart.”

The silence settled between them, heavy. Then Kasim stood, turning his back as if to hide a smile. “You always did like the hard fights.”

Liza nodded. “Sometimes, the hardest fights are the ones worth winning.”

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: "These families will not be broken up." Kasim shrugged. Sunlight flickered through the battered shutters, illuminating the stacks of paperwork on the table between them. 

"It’s not up to us," he said, voice flat. "You know that."

Liza pressed her lips together. "It is, if we make it. I’ve spoken to the volunteers. We’ll move them, tonight if we have to."

Kasim’s gaze drifted to the window: children’s laughter echoed from the courtyard below. "They’ll come looking."

"Let them," Liza replied. Her resolve crackled in the room. "We’ll be ready. We owe them more than fear."

Kasim considered her for a long moment. Finally, he drew in a long breath. "You’re serious."

"As a heart attack."

He chuckled, the sound tinged with uncertainty. "Alright, then. If we’re doing this, we do it right."

Night would fall soon, and with it, the shadow of men in uniforms. But for now, hope clung to the fading light, and Liza held tight to her promise.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: “These families will not be broken up.” Kasim shrugged. He seemed smaller in the low light, as if the burden of the coming hours had finally found his shoulders. 

“You say that every week, Liza. But how long can we really keep this up?”

Liza’s jaw tightened. She stared at the shadows flickering across the cracked plaster walls, listening to the faint murmur of voices in the next room. 

“As long as we have to. They trust us.”

Kasim’s fingers toyed with the frayed edge of his sleeve. “And if they come tonight?”

“We’ll have to be quicker. The passage under the garden is still open.”

He sighed, but some of the tension left his face. “You’re relentless.”

She managed a thin smile. “Someone has to be.”

Outside, the streetlights winked on, and Liza imagined each window glowing with the hope she stubbornly refused to let go. Tonight, together, they would keep the promise—no matter what it cost.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: "These families will not be broken up." Kasim shrugged. The rain outside grew heavier, beating a nervous rhythm on the tin roof. 

He stared at his hands, then at the worn photograph of his own family, tucked inside his jacket. "We can’t stop them, Liza. They have lists. Trucks. People who don’t care about promises."

Liza moved closer, lowering her voice. "Let them bring their lists. I have my own. And every name on it will leave tonight."

Kasim’s eyes flickered with doubt, then with something like hope. "And tomorrow?"

"Tomorrow we find new names, new places to hide. As long as there’s breath in me, there will be families together."

He looked away, afraid and wanting to believe. The silence between them was heavy with everything unsaid. 

Liza slipped her hand onto his shoulder. "Help me tonight. That’s all I ask."

Kasim nodded, surrendering to her stubborn faith. Upstairs, footsteps creaked—a signal. It was time. The world outside raged, but inside, defiance found a home.

), if I’m not too exhausted. That’s what I’d told Sara, my voice trailing off as I closed my laptop and let my eyes adjust to the dimness of the room. The clock blinked 7:23 PM in blue neon, a reminder that time kept moving even when I felt stuck.

"You said you’d come to the roof," she reminded me gently. 

I smiled sheepishly, nodding. Together, we climbed the narrow staircase, the city’s hum fading into a hush as we reached the rooftop. The air was crisp, the sky streaked with violet. We sat side by side, sipping tea, letting the exhaustion slip away beneath the stars.

), if I’m not too exhausted. That’s what I told myself every night before bed, as I set the alarm for 5 a.m., promising I’d finally go for that run along the canal. But morning after morning, I’d hit snooze, convinced my bones were made of lead and the world could wait.

The city was silent, save for the soft slap of my feet and the distant call of a waking bird. By the time I returned, the sun had crested the rooftops, painting the world gold. I stood in my kitchen, sweaty and smiling, and scrawled a new note: “Do it again tomorrow—no excuses.”

Sometimes, you have to outrun your exhaustion, just to remember you’re alive.

I told myself I’d call her tonight. Just one call, to bridge the years and the silence. But fatigue pulled at me, a weight on my chest. I reached for the phone anyway. Her number was still memorized, though I hadn’t dialed it in years.

) if I’m not too exhausted. That’s the loophole I always gave myself, a way out of the promises that seemed too heavy by dusk. ), if I’m not too exhausted. That was the caveat I added to all my promises lately. But tonight, as the rain hammered against my window, I decided to ignore my exhaustion for once and keep the promise anyway. I grabbed my coat, my sketchbook, and slipped out into the storm.

She smiled. “Chasing inspiration?”

I nodded, surprised. “Something like that.”

We talked quietly until her stop, sharing stories of late-night adventures and tired dreams. When she left, she handed me a flower and said, “Sometimes the best stories happen when you’re too tired to expect them.”

), if I’m not too exhausted. The phrase trailed behind every plan I made, a secret escape hatch. Tonight, it whispered again as I stared at the invitation on my phone—rooftop stargazing, 10 PM. The first shooting star streaked across the black, and someone gasped. For a moment, exhaustion faded. I made a wish—not for more energy, but for more nights like this. 

By the time I crawled back to bed, the world seemed brighter, and the phrase ‘if I’m not too exhausted’ felt less like a limitation, and more like a gentle promise to myself.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s not what you’d expect—a biography or memoir—no, it’s a field guide. Each page catalogues his quirks: the way he sharpens pencils to nubs, the creases in his smile, how he hums when he’s nervous. I jot down notes, hoping to capture the essence of him before the world changes him too much. I don’t think he knows—he never asks why my hands are always ink-stained, why I study him with the intensity of an ornithologist. Sometimes, I worry the book will never be finished, because he’s always growing, always evolving. But maybe that’s the point. Maybe the book is less about him and more about the person I become watching him. One day, when we’re old and the house is quiet, I’ll hand him the book. Maybe he’ll laugh, or cry, or both. But until then, I keep writing, page after page, loving him from a careful distance.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. I say 'his' because it started as a favor, but now the words feel like a shared secret. He sends me voice memos at midnight, fragments of stories and half-remembered dreams, and I try to stitch them into something coherent. Sometimes, I swear the book writes itself; characters appear out of nowhere, events unfold that neither of us planned. One evening, I found a chapter I never wrote, describing a memory only he could know. The handwriting was mine, but the words weren’t. I asked him, but he just smiled, enigmatic, and said, 'Stories have a life of their own.' Now, when I work on his book, I wonder if I’m transcribing his life, or if the book is quietly rewriting us both. The line blurs each day, but I keep writing, hoping to find out where the story ends—and who I’ll be when it does.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s more than a project—it’s a promise. He trusts me with secrets, the kind that slip between sentences and haunt the margins. Sometimes, I think I know him better than he knows himself, piecing together his history like a puzzle. I write late into the night, chasing the shape of his story, rearranging chapters, searching for a hidden thread. The book grows stranger. Pages appear out of order, words rearrange themselves when I’m not looking. I find passages I don’t remember writing—dreams, confessions, things he never told me. I wonder if the book is writing itself, or if I’m losing myself inside it. Still, I keep going. I owe him this much, at least—a story only we understand, a testament to a connection that can’t be broken by distance. When it’s done, maybe I’ll finally know which parts belong to him, and which belong to me.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The pages are scattered across my desk, covered in blue ink and coffee stains. I’ve become obsessed with getting every detail right: the cadence of his laughter, the way he lingers at the window before dawn, his quiet bravery. I rewrite the same chapter over and over, never satisfied. Sometimes, I worry I’m writing a version of him that only exists in my imagination—a better, braver man than the one who sits across from me at breakfast. Other times, I catch glimpses of the real him in the words: raw, vulnerable, flawed. The book is taking on a life of its own, pulling secrets from me I didn’t know I carried. When he asks about it, I smile and say it’s going well. But the truth is, I’m afraid to finish. Because once the last word is written, I’ll have to face the reality of who we both are.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. He doesn’t know this, at least not fully—he thinks I’m editing, but really I’m searching for traces of myself in his words. Sometimes, I find glimmers: a turn of phrase borrowed from our long walks, or a metaphor that feels like an inside joke. The more I read, the more I wonder if I am the protagonist, or just a shadow flickering at the edge of his story. One night, I discover a chapter addressed to me, hidden between drafts. It’s brief: just a few sentences about trust, and the way distance can make even the closest people feel like strangers. After that, I start writing my own notes in the margins—tiny annotations, confessions, questions. The book becomes a dialogue, a secret conversation across paper and time. Maybe he’ll find my notes one day, and maybe he’ll write back. Until then, I’ll keep reading, searching, and hoping.

His handwriting is neat, precise, but the words betray a chaos I recognize well. I edit in pencil, terrified of making marks he won’t approve. Sometimes I imagine him standing behind me, watching as I strike through a sentence, his breath warm on my neck. When he returns, he never asks about the changes, only sits in the armchair, silent, as if listening to a story only he can hear. Tonight, I find an unfamiliar note tucked between the chapters: "Finish it for me." My hand trembles. I realize, with a pang, that I’ve already started weaving myself into his narrative, and the ending, if it comes, will be ours alone.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s become a ritual: I trace his words, searching for the places my own thoughts might slip in unnoticed. Sometimes I think the margins are more mine than his, filled with questions and quiet disagreements. I wonder if he reads my notes, or if he pretends not to notice the way the story is changing beneath his hands. Once, I left a message in the footnotes—an apology, or maybe a confession. The next day, his reply appeared, disguised as dialogue. We never spoke about it, but the pages grew heavier with secrets. Now, when I hear his footsteps in the hall, I close the notebook and pretend I’ve been waiting. Perhaps I have. Perhaps the book was always just an excuse for us to write to each other in silence.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s not really his, or mine, but something that grew in the spaces between our conversations. He sends me fragments, half-remembered dreams, and I stitch them together, hoping to find a pattern. Sometimes the words slip away from me, become strange and unrecognizable. I rewrite his memories, add my own, until the line between us blurs. When we meet, he asks about the story’s progress, but never about the story’s truth. Maybe he knows. Maybe he’s afraid to ask. In the quiet hours, I wonder if the book will ever be finished, or if it’s just a way to keep us circling each other, tethered by sentences that never quite say what we mean.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. I’ve memorized the patterns of his sentences, the cadence of his thoughts, until sometimes I forget which words are his and which are mine. The story weaves through our days like music overheard from another apartment, too faint to catch but impossible to ignore. When he calls, his voice is always distant, asking about characters I barely understand. I invent answers, knowing he’ll revise everything anyway. Still, I keep writing, filling up pages with his life and my longing. Sometimes, in the margins, I write notes meant only for him: reminders of things we’ve said, or things I wish we had. When he finally comes home, we sit together in silence, the unfinished manuscript between us, and I wonder if the real story is the one we’re too afraid to write.

responses.text:
If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The stories he tells me at night—half-remembered, sometimes feverish dreams—become my notes in the morning. He says he wants to write it himself, but his hands tremble too much these days, so it’s me who lifts the pen. Sometimes I wonder if I’m the ghostwriter, or if I’m the ghost.

Last week, I added a chapter he never mentioned. It was about a garden full of glass flowers, and a girl who wandered through them, afraid to touch anything for fear of shattering it all. He read it, quietly, then nodded. "That was always the hardest part to remember," he said.

I never told him I made it up. Now, every day I add a little more, stories he might have lived, or might have dreamed. When he finally finishes the book, I wonder if he’ll recognize himself at all—or if, by then, I’ll have written both of us out entirely.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The one with the green leather cover and the pages that smell faintly of cedar. He doesn’t know I’ve been rewriting the ending every night, changing the outcome in small, almost imperceptible ways. Sometimes the hero survives. Sometimes he does not.

I wonder if he notices. He never says anything, but his brow furrows when he reads. Maybe he’s searching for the version he remembers, the one he told me to write, not the one I want him to have. The quiet between us grows, filled with unwritten words and silent edits. One day, perhaps, he’ll ask me why the villain’s name keeps changing, or why the sun sets in a different place.

Until then, I’ll keep working on his book, crafting a story that belongs to neither of us but lives in the spaces we share—and in the ones we don’t.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. He trusts me with his words, even though he never reads them. Every day, he leaves me a new voice message: a snippet of dialogue, a memory, a question he wants the protagonist to ponder. I transcribe them faithfully, but sometimes I rearrange them, shaping the story into something he didn’t intend.

Last Thursday, I inserted an entire chapter about a train journey. He hates trains. I thought he’d notice, but when I gave him the pages, he only smiled and asked if I’d found his old conductor’s hat. I hadn’t, but I pretended I did.

Maybe the book is about us, more than he realizes. Maybe writing it is the only way I can stay connected to the person he used to be. When I finish, I’ll tell him the truth: the story was never just his. It was always ours, stitched together from the silence between rooms.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. I say "his," but I wonder if it’s become mine. At first, I only wrote what he dictated, pausing after every few lines for him to recall the details. Now, the characters speak to me even when he’s gone. I shape their fates while he sleeps, changing endings, adding secret histories he never imagined.

He'll read my latest chapter and sometimes frown, head tilted, as if searching for something he lost. "Did I tell you that part?" he asks. I always nod, and he lets it go. Maybe it’s easier for him to believe he wrote it all. Maybe it’s easier for me, too.

In the evenings, when we’re together, he tells me new stories. But when I’m alone, I let my own words slip quietly onto the page. In this way, we both become authors—of his book, of each other.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. At first, it was just editing: tightening sentences, correcting grammar. But over time, I started leaving my own fingerprints—shifting a character’s motivation here, inventing a memory there. I thought he’d notice, but he never does. Or perhaps he chooses not to.

Some nights, the lines between us blur. I can’t remember whether the chapter I finished was his idea or mine. His handwriting in the margins grows more cryptic, and the story spirals further from where it started. I wonder if he resents that, or if he’s grateful for the way I fill in the blanks.

When we finally sit together and read aloud, our voices overlap, sentences weaving until we lose track of who wrote what. Maybe that’s the point. Maybe the book is less about telling his story and more about the story we make together, in the spaces where we’re apart.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s a secret tome, the kind that hums with a strange energy when I crack open the battered spine. He never lets me see him write, only leaves me cryptic notes and half-finished chapters. Sometimes I think he’s testing me, seeing if I can piece together the story he’s too afraid to finish. One rainy night, a chapter arrives by carrier pigeon, ink still wet and words trembling on the page. As I transcribe his latest fever dream, shadows flicker on the wall and the words shift beneath my pen, rearranging themselves into confessions I was never meant to read. I pause, heart racing, as the door creaks open behind me. He stands there, drenched and silent, eyes fixed on the manuscript. In that moment, I realize the book is not just his story—it’s ours, written in invisible ink, waiting for the right light to reveal the truth.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The book is not just any book—it’s a living record of his dreams. Every morning, he tells me what he remembered while he slept, and I try to capture the fragments before they fade. Lately, though, the dreams have grown stranger: doors opening onto impossible landscapes, conversations with people who know my name, hints of places I’ve never been but somehow recognize. Today, his voice was tense. "Don’t write what I dreamt last night," he said. But I did. As I typed, the words rearranged themselves, forming sentences I never wrote, answering questions I never asked. The pages pulsed with heat. I realized, too late, that I was no longer the author, nor the scribe, but a character in his dreams—dreams that were becoming real, one word at a time.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. Sometimes, I wonder if he even knows how much of himself he’s given away on those pages, and how much I’ve quietly rearranged, shaping his story into something neither of us expected. He leaves scraps of ideas for me on the kitchen table: a phrase, a line of dialogue, a drawing of a crow. I collect them, spin them into chapters, and sometimes slip in details of my own. It’s a private collaboration, one neither of us acknowledges. I suspect he reads my additions, but he never mentions them. Instead, we pass each other in the hallway, nodding, as if the book is a secret language only we speak. One day, the book will be finished, and I wonder if it will tell his story, or mine, or if it will simply be the record of two people who never quite found the right words in the same room.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. That’s the rule we agreed on, after the accident. He never writes when I’m there, and I never ask why. The book is a collection of memories, or maybe confessions, but he won’t say which. Sometimes I recognize a name, or a street, and the words feel too familiar. Yesterday, I found a page that wasn’t there before—written in my own handwriting, recounting a memory I’d buried deep. I don’t remember writing it, but the ink smudges match my left hand. The next morning, he avoids my gaze at breakfast. We pretend nothing has changed, but the book sits on the table between us, open to a story neither of us remembers telling, waiting for one of us to fill in the ending.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The manuscript is a labyrinth, each chapter leading me deeper into places I’m not sure I should go. He writes in code—half-poems, scattered notes, names of people I’ve never met. My job is to decipher, to turn fragments into narrative, but the more I read, the more the lines blur. Was that memory his or mine? Did I dream that scene, or live it? Sometimes, late at night, I hear footsteps pacing above my room, and I wonder if he’s up there, rewriting our past. The book grows heavier each day, as if words have weight. By the time I realize I’m writing my own story in the margins, it’s too late. The book is finished, but neither of us recognizes the ending.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. Last night, there was a single line: "Do you remember the echo of footsteps in the marble hall?" I do—my own, sneaking down the corridor to meet him. I pour a glass of wine and stare at my screen, trying to find the thread, hoping for a sign. The book is about us, but he’ll never admit it. I add another chapter, my own memory stitched to his. Tomorrow, I’ll see him. We’ll pretend we’re strangers, but when I hand him the latest pages, he’ll smile. "You found the echo," he’ll say. And for a moment, the story will be ours again.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. He says it helps him to know that I’m out there, untangling his thoughts, turning them into something readable. Sometimes I wonder if I’m really editing his words, or if I’m erasing myself from the margins, piece by piece. The manuscript is a mess of half-formed ideas, poetry tangled with lists, memories that don’t belong to me but feel familiar. I try to impose order, but the chaos resists. One night, I catch myself writing a chapter in my own voice, a confession slipped between his recollections. When I see him again, he reads it silently, then looks up with a sad smile. "You’re part of the story now," he says. I wonder if I always was.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The pages are cluttered with secrets I’m not sure he means to reveal. Sometimes, I find myself reading between the lines, piecing together the story he can’t quite say aloud. There are nights when I call him, hoping he’ll answer, but the line rings out. I edit another paragraph, rearrange a memory, and wonder if he’ll notice. Once, he left a post-it on my desk: “Fix me.” I laughed, but now the words haunt me. By the time we meet again, I have a new chapter, polished and clean. He reads it, nods, and asks, “Did you change the ending?” I hesitate, then tell him the truth: “Only a little.”

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. I know every page, every crooked metaphor that tumbles from his mind. Sometimes, I think he writes for me alone, filling the margins with secret notes only I can decode. The story is supposed to be fiction, but I recognize the way his protagonist holds his coffee, the way she avoids eye contact on the subway. I edit gently, careful not to erase too much of him. When we reunite, he pretends not to care about my changes, but I see him searching for himself in the words. "Does she live?" he asks, and I know he means himself. I tell him, "She survives." Later, I add, "And so do we."

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. He trusts me with his drafts, all rough edges and unfinished thoughts. My nights are spent deciphering his handwriting, filling in the gaps where the ink trails off. Sometimes I wonder if he leaves those spaces for me on purpose, waiting to see what I’ll create. Once, I wrote an ending he never imagined, and he called me at midnight, laughing and crying all at once. Now, when we’re together, we don’t talk about the book. We sit in silence, letting the unwritten words settle around us. I think he knows I’m writing my own story, one where we’re always in the same room, and the book is never quite finished.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. This is both a promise and a penance. But lately, the characters have started speaking to me directly. I hear them at night, whispering secrets in voices that aren’t quite mine or his. I wonder if he knows I’ve begun to alter the story, shifting motivations, erasing entire histories. Perhaps he expects it; perhaps this is our unspoken game. When he returns, I hand him the latest chapter, my fingerprints pressed into the ink, and watch his eyes flicker with recognition or surprise. In this strange collaboration, I wonder where the boundary lies—between editor and author, between reality and invention, between his story and mine.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It started as a distraction, a way to feel useful while he vanished into his own world. But as the weeks passed, I found myself rewriting entire passages, slipping in memories he’d forgotten, dreams he never told me. Her mother boxed up her daughter’s trophies and birth certificate, driving east until the highway blurred. She left the town behind, but the headlines followed: ‘Troubled Youth, Tragic End.’ Years later, when the fields around the old house grew wild, a girl with the same quick smile moved in. The bus driver went free, his smile returning, while her parents boxed up her life, posters curling on the walls, notebooks half-filled with dreams. He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The detective, tired and wary, stared at the tape recorder, watching the small red light blink like a heartbeat. “You expect anyone to believe that, Darren?” she asked, voice flat.

Darren’s hands trembled as he clasped them together. “I didn’t do it. They kept me awake, kept shouting. I just wanted it to stop.”

In the corner, his lawyer scribbled notes, brow furrowed. Outside, a storm battered the windows, thunder echoing the uncertainty inside Darren’s chest.

The detective sighed. “We’ll look into it. But the evidence—”

“There is no evidence,” Darren interrupted, desperate. “Just my words. Ones I never meant.”

Three days later, new footage surfaced: a grainy security video of a different man leaving the scene. The detective replayed it, over and over, watching the way the stranger limped, the flash of a scar on his wrist. Darren’s wrists bore no scars.

The detective turned to Darren, who sat silently, eyes wide. “Looks like you might have been telling the truth.”

For the first time in days, Darren allowed himself to hope.

responses.text: The door clicks shut behind her, and suddenly, the apartment feels oddly quiet. I glance at the screen, thumb hovering over the play button, nerves buzzing. Maybe she’s humming, or maybe it’s just my imagination. I look around the living room, noticing how the lamplight pools softly in the corners, how her slippers sit by the couch, toes pointed together. We’ve watched a hundred episodes side by side, but tonight, my heart thumps in anticipation. The bathroom door creaks open. She steps out, hair damp and cheeks flushed, wearing my old college sweatshirt. She catches my eye and grins. “Ready?” she asks, settling in next to me. Maybe tonight, as laughter flickers on the screen, I’ll finally find the words.

I’m flipping through endless show thumbnails, debating between comfort and novelty, when the bathroom door swings open with unexpected force. She emerges wearing a dazzling superhero costume—cape, boots, the works—striking a pose in the hallway. I blink, remote forgotten. “Surprise! Costume night!” she declares, grinning. I burst out laughing, the tension of the week dissolving instantly. “You look incredible,” I manage, still giggling. She plops down beside me, her cape tangling in the cushions. “Well? Inside the bathroom, I sift through a duffel bag, finally settling on an old pirate hat and a striped shirt. When I return, she launches into a dramatic monologue worthy of a villain. We watch the episode in full costume, trading banter and popcorn, and by the end, I realize I haven’t smiled this much in years.

I fumble with the remote, nerves prickling in my fingertips. It’s only a TV show, but tonight’s different—the finale, after weeks of speculation and theories. I hear the faucet squeak and the soft patter of her slippers on tile. The thought crosses my mind to peek at the ending, just a second. But no. I wait, anticipation building. The bathroom door opens, and she steps out in pajamas patterned with tiny spaceships, her hair twisted up in a towel. She sits beside me, knees tucked under her chin, glancing at the screen. “Did you start it yet?” she asks. “Nope, waiting for you.” She smiles, and for a moment, the world contracts to this small living room, the glow of the TV, the warmth between us. As the opening credits roll, our hands find each other, fingers weaving together naturally. Neither of us speaks, but inside, I feel it: tonight, something quietly beautiful is beginning, and it has nothing to do with the show.

I scroll through the list of episodes, my mind only half on the screen. The apartment feels unusually still, the muffled sound of running water from the bathroom the only sign of life. The bathroom door opens, and she emerges in an oversized T-shirt, her hair still damp and smelling faintly of lavender. She grins, plopping down next to me, tucking her feet beneath her. “Did you pick one?” she asks. I nod, but my heart is pounding. She looks at me, eyes wide. Maybe it’s the glow from the TV or the comfort of this ritual, but tonight, I’m braver than usual.

Tonight isn’t just any episode—it’s the one where our favorite characters finally confess. I wonder if she knows how much I want to do the same. You nod for me to press play, and the opening credits roll, but all I can think about is the way your eyes don’t quite meet mine.

You vanish into the bathroom, door thudding shut, and I pull up our show. The familiar theme song is poised to begin, but tonight the air in the room feels heavier—like a storm just outside. I fidget with the remote, noticing a sticky note wedged beneath it. I unfold it: ‘Don’t trust what you see tonight.’ My heart skips. The TV flickers and, for a split second, the screen reflects not me, but a stranger’s silhouette. The bathroom sink screeches, then goes silent. I hear you humming, but the tune is warped, off-key. When you return, your smile is wide, but your eyes are too bright, almost glassy. You sit beside me. The note shakes in my hand, hidden beneath a blanket. You nudge me, “Ready?” My thumb hovers over play, but I can’t help but wonder—who left the note, and who just walked out of my bathroom?

You call out, voice muffled by the bathroom door, but I’m already lost in the glow of the screen. The app loads slowly, buffering in fits and starts. As the episode icon appears, the room flickers—just for a moment, the walls seem to pulse with an odd, amber light. I blink, and everything’s normal again. I press pause, waiting for you. In the silence, I hear a faint, melodic whisper, almost like static, drifting from the speakers. I move to turn down the volume, but the remote is sluggish, unresponsive. The bathroom door opens, steam curling around your silhouette. You look different, older, as if you’ve lived a hundred lives in those few minutes. You settle beside me, eyes shining. “Let’s watch,” you say, and the episode starts on its own, the familiar laughter warped into something I can’t quite recognize. I wonder if anything will be the same after tonight.

The episode auto-plays, laughter echoing eerily. I rise, heart pounding, and push the bathroom door. Empty. Only steam swirls around her clothes neatly folded. I blink, confused. Suddenly, the TV flickers, the actors staring out at me, their eyes too real, too knowing. The remote falls from my hand. Somewhere behind me, the water stops. I turn, pulse racing, and realize our night in is just beginning, but not at all the way we planned.
