prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

responses.text:
“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man pauses, adjusting the cuff of his tailored shirt, and gives Jonah a smile that’s all teeth and calculation. Without a word, he flips Jonah a single brass key attached to a faded hotel tag. It lands in Jonah’s hand with a weight that feels heavier than metal.

“Room 304. Don’t be late,” the man says, brushing past Jonah, leaving the scent of expensive cologne and something darker—gun oil, maybe, or secrets.

Jonah glances down the street. The Ferrari gleams, drawing the eyes of every pedestrian, but no one seems to notice the exchange. He pockets the key, heart racing. He knows better than to ask questions, but curiosity gnaws at him. Why him? Why tonight?

He hails a cab, clutching the key. The city blurs by, neon and rain streaking the windows. When he arrives at the hotel, the lobby is deserted. Jonah hesitates only a moment before heading for the stairs, the key warm in his palm. Whatever waits in Room 304, he knows his life will never be quite so subtle again.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man offers Jonah a brief, knowing smirk. “It’s all about blending in,” he replies, pressing a button on his key fob. The car chirps and, to Jonah’s amazement, the Ferrari’s deep red paint shimmers, shifting through a spectrum of colors before settling into a nondescript beige. 

Jonah laughs, half in disbelief. “That’s... unexpected.”

The man’s eyes glint. “You’d be surprised how much you can hide in plain sight.” He gestures to the passenger seat. “Coming?”

Jonah hesitates, but curiosity gets the better of him. He slides into the seat, feeling the plush leather and the subtle hum of hidden technology beneath his feet. As the car slides silently away from the curb, the city lights reflecting off its camouflaged surface, Jonah realizes he’s about to see a side of the city that doesn’t appear on any map. He leans back, ready for whatever secrets the night—and his mysterious chauffeur—have in store.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man’s mouth twitches, half amusement, half warning. He scans the quiet street, then opens the trunk, revealing a small velvet box. 

“Hop in,” he says, nodding at the passenger seat. 

Jonah hesitates. He’s never seen the man before—at least, not in person. Only in grainy security footage, always just on the edge of the frame. Now, here he is, inviting Jonah into the belly of the beast, so to speak. 

Inside the car, the air is thick with the smell of leather and anticipation. The man hands Jonah the box. “Don’t open it until we reach the bridge.”

Jonah’s hands tremble as he takes it. The city blurs outside as they speed through the night. At the bridge, he opens the box: inside, a single chess piece—the black king. Jonah looks up to see the man watching him in the rearview mirror, his eyes cold and expectant.

“Your move,” the man says.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man arches an eyebrow, surveying Jonah with an inscrutable gaze. He slips a thin envelope into Jonah’s hand, whispering, “Don’t let anyone see.”

Jonah’s fingers tremble as he tucks the envelope into his jacket. The man walks away, his polished shoes tapping out a steady rhythm on the pavement, the Ferrari’s engine purring to life. Jonah waits until he’s gone, then ducks into a nearby alley, tearing open the envelope. Inside: a single polaroid photo of a street sign, and beneath it, a scribbled message—“Midnight. Come alone.”

The rest of the day passes in a haze. As midnight approaches, Jonah finds himself at the corner from the photo, heart hammering. Shadows shift and a familiar engine growls behind him. The Ferrari is back. The man leans out the window, eyes glinting. “Nice to see you took the hint,” he says, a sly smile curling his lips. “Get in. Let’s see how subtle you can be.”

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man grins, teeth flashing in the dusk. “It’s all about keeping a low profile,” he replies, deadpan. 

Jonah snorts, but the man gestures him over. “Hop in. We’re late.”

The seats are buttery leather, the dash a constellation of dials. The man tosses Jonah a pair of sunglasses. “Put these on.”

Jonah complies, and the world shifts: colors invert, streetlights pulse with hidden symbols, and the city’s ordinary skyline bristles with invisible towers. The man accelerates, weaving through traffic as if the laws of physics no longer apply. 

“Who are you?” Jonah manages.

The man shrugs. “Call me Lucien. I deal with the unseen.”

They pull up in front of a crumbling theater, its marquee flickering with a message only visible through the glasses: WELCOME TO THE OTHER SIDE.

Jonah steps out, heart pounding, as Lucien winks. “Enjoy the show. Remember—sometimes, the loudest things are the hardest to notice.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes!

responses.text:
Yes! The word echoed through the empty concert hall, bouncing off velvet curtains and polished wood. Zoe stood center stage, arms flung wide, grinning at the rows of empty seats as if they were filled with cheering fans. She had just said yes to the invitation of her wildest dreams—the chance to perform her own song at the city’s biggest music festival.

As she rehearsed, the stage lights flickered on, casting golden halos around her silhouette. She sang her heart out to the ghostly audience, feeling every note ripple through her veins. Suddenly, the creak of a door caught her attention. A janitor poked his head in, broom in hand, and listened, spellbound. When she finished, he clapped softly, a solitary but sincere applause.

Zoe blushed and bowed, laughter bubbling up. Her “yes” had already brought an audience, even if it was just one. She knew, in that moment, that the empty seats would soon be filled, and that her music—her story—was ready to be heard.

Yes! The word burst from Tim’s lips before he’d had time to think. The old woman smiled, her eyes twinkling behind thick spectacles, and handed him the tiny, tarnished key. He turned it over in his palm, feeling the weight of adventure settle into his bones.

The key was meant for a door in the abandoned library at the edge of town—a place children warned each other about on stormy nights. But Tim, spurred by the thrill of the unknown, set out beneath a sky bruised with twilight. He found the door tucked behind a fallen shelf, its lock whispering secrets only the key could answer.

When he turned the key, the world rushed away, replaced by shimmering corridors lined with stories yet unwritten. Tim stepped forward, heart pounding, ready to explore a library that grew and changed with every thought and dream he dared to have. In the hush of possibility, he grinned and whispered again: "Yes!"

Yes! That one syllable tumbled from Mia’s mouth, surprising even herself. The spaceship’s hatch hissed open, revealing a staircase descending into the shimmering dust of an alien planet. She’d spent years training, but now, standing at the threshold of the unknown, fear warred with exhilaration in her chest.

Commander Liu gave her a thumbs-up from inside the cockpit. Mia took a deep, shuddery breath and stepped out. The ground felt springy, almost alive, and the air shimmered with scents she couldn’t name. Strange plants waved gently, as if welcoming her. She knelt, pressing her gloved hand to the surface, and felt a subtle thrumming—like a heartbeat.

Behind her, the rest of the crew waited, anxious and hopeful. Mia looked back, grinned, and called, “It’s safe!”

As they joined her, Mia realized that her impulsive yes had opened a doorway not just to a new world, but to a new version of herself—one bold enough to answer the universe’s call.

Yes! shouted Jasper as he leapt from the crumbling ledge, trusting the wind to carry him across the gorge. For a split second, he soared, arms flailing, heart hammering against his ribs. The far side rushed up to meet him, gravel skittering beneath his boots as he landed, barely managing to keep his balance.

Behind him, the ancient ruins groaned, a soft rain beginning to fall. Jasper glanced back and laughed, exhilarated. He’d made it. His daring move meant the map he’d risked so much to find was now within reach. Pulling the oilskin pouch from his satchel, he unrolled the faded parchment. The next clue shimmered in the rain, revealing a path through the mist-shrouded valley below.

Jasper grinned at the unknown. Sometimes, the only way forward was to leap and say yes to adventure, unsure of where you’d land, but certain it would be somewhere worth discovering.

Yes! The answer blazed through my mind as I watched the old clock strike midnight. The shadows in the attic seemed to shudder, and a fine dust glimmered in the shaft of moonlight. I stepped forward, heart pounding, and placed my hand on the ancient chest everyone said was cursed. The air tingled with possibility.

As the latch clicked open, a whirl of blue light spiraled upward, coalescing into the shape of a tiny fox with eyes like burning coals. It bowed its head to me and spoke—yes, spoke—promising a single wish to anyone brave enough to unlock the chest at the stroke of twelve. I swallowed my fear, and with trembling lips, made my wish.

The fox grinned, nodded, and vanished, leaving behind only a feather and a faint scent of cinnamon. I left the attic changed, the world outside buzzing with magic I hadn’t noticed before, all because I’d dared to say yes.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes!

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth.

responses.text: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The bundle was heavier than he remembered, its shape oddly misshapen by time. He unwrapped it with trembling fingers, the scent of old machine oil filling the air. Inside, the automaton’s face stared back at him, porcelain cracked but eyes still glinting with promise. He remembered the promise he’d made to his sister—bring it home, fix it, and make it dance again. As he wound the key, the gears inside groaned, shuddering to life. The first note of the music box echoed through the cellar, soft and haunting. He watched, tears stinging his eyes, as the tiny dancer pivoted atop the wooden stage—just as she had all those years ago, before everything changed. In that moment, the past and present merged, and for a heartbeat, he was home again.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. With care, he drew the bundle from the earth, his lantern flickering nervously in the crypt’s stale air. The device had belonged to his great-grandfather, an inventor with a penchant for secrecy. Unwrapping the cloth revealed an intricate pocket watch, its face etched with symbols he did not recognize. He pressed the winding key, and a low hum vibrated through his fingers. Suddenly, the watch’s hands spun backward, and the world around him seemed to blur and ripple. The stone walls faded. He found himself standing in a bustling Victorian street, the air thick with smoke and horse-drawn carriages. Clutching the watch, he realized he’d become part of its mystery, swept into history by the very thing he’d sought to unearth.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The sensation sent a shiver up his spine—he never expected to find it again. Carefully, he brushed away the dirt and peeled away the tattered fabric, revealing the ancient music box his grandmother had buried fifty years ago. He remembered her warning: only play the song when the moon was full. But the temptation was too much. He wound the key and opened the lid. The melody was warped, eerie, and as it played, shadows in the room began to twist and lengthen, swirling around him. The air grew colder, and he realized too late that some secrets are meant to stay buried. The music box’s song wouldn’t stop, and neither would the shadows it had awoken.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The touch of the ancient artifact sent a jolt through his arm, memories surging from a life he’d long forgotten. He unwrapped the cloth, revealing a clockwork compass, its arrow spinning wildly before locking onto a direction he could not see. He hesitated only a moment before following its pull, stepping into the darkness beyond the ruins. Each footfall echoed with the tick of unseen gears, guiding him deeper into the forest’s heart. Whatever lay ahead, he knew it was bound to the destiny he’d unearthed with trembling hands and a racing heart.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. His breath caught—he recognized the artifact instantly, though it had been years since he'd last seen it. Suddenly, the owl took off, circling the room before landing on his shoulder, whispering in a voice that was both mechanical and eerily familiar: "Welcome home, Elias. The secrets await."

He realized then that this watch was a key, not to the past, but to futures yet unwritten—and it had chosen him as its next traveler.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth.

responses.text: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The parcel trembled in his hands, as if it remembered being awake. He unwrapped it with trembling fingers, revealing a pocket watch unlike any he’d ever seen—the face was etched with shifting constellations, and the second hand ticked backward. He pressed the tiny button on its crown and the gears inside whirred to life, emitting a faint blue glow. The world around him seemed to shimmer. Suddenly, the room was gone, replaced by a moonlit forest he’d only seen in dreams. A fox with silver eyes sat before him, tail curled around its paws. "You found it," the fox murmured. "Now, time is yours to mend—or break."

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. His fingers traced the intricate pattern through the fabric: tiny cogs, smooth knobs, the sharp edge of a key. He hesitated, remembering the stories his grandmother told about the automaton buried generations ago, meant to keep a secret safe. As he unwrapped the bundle, the soft whirring grew louder, and the gears began to turn on their own. Suddenly, a metallic bird unfolded from the contraption, blinking its glass eyes. It whistled three notes and spoke, "The time has come. Are you ready to remember?" The ground trembled, and distant voices echoed, as if the past itself was awakening beneath his feet.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. Pulling it free, he brushed off the dirt and glanced over his shoulder, making sure no one saw. He hadn’t expected to find it here, beneath the old willow tree, where the map had led him. Unwrapping the cloth, he revealed a small, handcrafted music box. When he wound the key, a haunting melody filled the air, and the gears inside shifted, opening a hidden compartment. Inside lay a faded photograph and a note: "For the day you’re ready to forgive." He stared, heart pounding, as memories flooded back—of laughter, loss, and a promise he’d buried long ago.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The parcel was heavier than he expected, almost humming with anticipation. Pulling it into the moonlight, he unwrapped the layers and stared at the object: a mechanical heart, its gears twitching with a life of their own. He remembered the old inventor's words, whispered in the dark: "Return it to where it began, and the debt will be paid." With trembling hands, he cradled the heart and walked to the ancient oak at the center of the grove. As he placed it into a hollow, a pulse echoed through the earth, and the forest awoke, whispering his name.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. He pulled the bundle out, breathless, and peeled back the damp fabric. The contraption looked like a child’s toy—except for the tiny golden key protruding from its side. He hesitated, then wound the key. The gears spun, and a tinny melody began to play. Suddenly, the air shimmered, and the world around him flickered. He saw flashes of places he’d never been: a bustling city, a ship at sea, a castle under siege. The music sped up, and the visions grew clearer. Was he traveling through time, or just dreaming? He clung to the music, desperate for answers.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth.

responses.text: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. Pulling it from the earth, he brushed off centuries of dried mud, his heart thumping. The bundle was heavier than he expected. Carefully, he unwrapped it, revealing a delicate contraption: a clockwork bird, its wings tucked in, tiny ruby eyes dulled with age. He wound the small brass key and waited, breath held. With a shudder, the bird whirred to life, wings fluttering weakly, a faint song rising from its chest. The melody was familiar—his grandmother’s lullaby. Tears welled in his eyes as memories flooded back, and he realized this was her secret, left for him beneath the old oak. The bird sang on, and with each note, he felt less alone, as though time itself had wound back just for him.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The soil was damp, clinging to his fingers as he pulled free the odd bundle. It was heavier than he’d expected. He unwrapped it by the light of his lantern, revealing a strange mechanical box, its surface engraved with symbols he couldn’t read. As he turned it over, gears shifted within, emitting a low hum. Suddenly, a tiny door popped open, and a rolled parchment slid out. He hesitated, then unrolled it. The map was unlike any he’d seen, marked with cryptic constellations and paths leading deep into the forest. His heart pounded. Perhaps the stories were true: the forest held more secrets than anyone realized, and tonight, he might become the first to discover them.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. His hands trembled as he unearthed the object, careful not to damage the delicate mechanism beneath. The cloth was stiff with age, but he managed to peel it away, revealing a miniature automaton—a mechanical fox with glass eyes and silver whiskers. He pressed a hidden switch, and the fox sprang to life, scampering in a circle before sitting back on its haunches, tail flicking. A compartment in its belly slid open, revealing a faded photograph of a man he’d never seen, but who looked just like him. He stared at the fox, realization dawning: this was his inheritance, a riddle left by the father he’d never known. The answers, perhaps, lay hidden within the fox’s gears.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. With a cautious tug, he unearthed the bundle, fingers tingling with anticipation. He peeled back the layers to reveal a battered music box, its surface etched with swirling vines. When he wound the tarnished key, the box creaked and sputtered, then played a haunting melody that seemed to echo through the empty woods. As the melody played, the moonlight flickered and shadows around him shifted, forming shapes that danced in time with the tune. He realized, with a chill, that the box was more than a keepsake: it was a key to something ancient. The shadows beckoned, and he felt the pull of curiosity stronger than fear. He stood, music box in hand, and stepped into the unknown.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The object was heavier than he expected, and as he lifted it free, he could feel the faint vibration of something alive within its mechanism. He hurried to his workbench, unwrapping the layers with the reverence of an archaeologist. The device was an ornately carved mechanical heart, the gears visible beneath thin brass lattice. When he pressed the tiny button on its side, it began to tick, a soft rhythm echoing his own heartbeat. Suddenly, tiny clockwork wings unfolded from the heart and began to flap. He watched in awe as the heart lifted gently from his hands and hovered before him, casting a warm, golden glow. He knew then that he had uncovered not just a relic, but a message from the past—a promise that hope, once buried, could always rise again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text: Are there children? The question echoed through the empty hallways as Maribel stepped carefully over the scattered toys, their colors faded with dust and time. She listened, but only the low creak of timber replied. The village elders had warned her not to come after dusk, but curiosity was a stubborn companion. In the moonlit kitchen, she found a child’s drawing pinned to the wall—a spidery figure holding hands with someone tall and faceless. A shiver ran down her spine. Then, a giggle, soft as silk, drifted from the staircase. Maribel’s heart pounded. She followed the sound, her flashlight flickering. At the landing, she found a cracked door and, inside, a circle of children, their eyes wide and unblinking, their mouths sewn shut with crimson thread. Maribel stumbled backward, tripping on her own terror. As she fled, the laughter grew, echoing through the night, and she understood that in this place, there were always children—waiting, watching, never leaving.

Are there children? The question startled the caretaker as she unlocked the orphanage gate at dawn. The visitor wore a crimson cloak, her eyes hidden by a wide-brimmed hat. The caretaker hesitated, glancing at the silent playground beyond. "Not anymore," she whispered. The woman stepped inside, her boots crunching over glass marbles and wilted paper cranes. She knelt, brushing dust from the hopscotch squares, and hummed a lullaby that seemed to vibrate in the chilly air. The caretaker shivered. The woman rose and nodded. "They’re ready now." Shadows flickered; laughter sparked in the empty corridors. One by one, spectral figures appeared—children, translucent and smiling, their hands reaching for the woman. As the sun rose, the visitor led the children away, their laughter echoing softly, leaving the caretaker alone in the silent dawn, the orphanage finally at peace.

Are there children? The voice crackled over the old radio, urgent and trembling. In the bunker below the abandoned city, Mara pressed the transmit button, her knuckles white. "No. Not anymore," she replied, glancing at the empty sleeping bags strewn around her. Silence. Then, a distant thump echoed through the pipes overhead. Mara’s breath caught. She forced herself to scan the monitors—one by one, flickering screens showed empty streets, empty buildings. But on the last feed, a shadow darted past. Small, quick. She blinked, unsure. The radio hissed again. "Are you sure?" Mara hesitated. Hope and dread tangled in her chest. She left the radio and climbed the ladder, emerging into gray daylight. In the rubble-strewn street, a single red ball rolled to a stop at her feet. Mara looked up, heart pounding, as a small figure peeked from behind a broken wall. There were children, after all.

Are there children? Dr. Halvorsen surveyed the empty playground, its swings moving gently in the wind. The silence unsettled him. He had come to the village to investigate the reports—laughter at midnight, tiny footprints in the dew, lullabies drifting from empty windows. He knelt, touching the cold metal of a forgotten tricycle. Suddenly, a shadow flickered beside the slide. He turned, heart thundering. A group of children stood there, their faces pale, eyes wide and ancient. "We are here," they whispered in unison. Dr. Halvorsen stepped back, but the children advanced, their forms growing fainter with each step. "Will you stay and play?" they asked. The wind grew colder. Dr. Halvorsen realized too late these were not ordinary children. The playground swallowed his scream, and by morning, the swings creaked gently in the wind once more.

Are there children? That was the first thing Mrs. Langley asked as she stepped into the ruined chapel. Father Duran shook his head, but she felt eyes watching her from the cracked stained glass above. She brushed past the pews, ignoring the chill, searching for signs of life. In the back, she found a circle of candles and small, perfect shoes lined up in a row. A faint giggle drifted from the shadows. Mrs. Langley called out, her voice trembling, and a blurry figure darted behind the altar. She followed, heart pounding, into a secret passage she’d never seen before. As she entered, dozens of children’s voices greeted her, echoing off the cold stone walls. They beckoned her deeper, promising play and laughter, but as she followed, she realized their shadows grew longer and darker, and the chapel doors had vanished behind her.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
Are there children? The question echoed in the empty, dust-laden hall as Mara tiptoed across broken tiles. She paused, listening, but only the wind replied, shuffling torn curtains against shattered glass. The city had been silent for weeks now, since the evacuation. Mara clung to a faint hope that not all had fled, that perhaps some had hidden, survived.

She checked classrooms one by one, her flashlight trembling in her grip. Each time she asked, “Are there children?” she half-expected laughter to ring out, or small faces to peek from behind desks. But the only answers were abandoned backpacks, faded crayon drawings, and the persistent, hollow hush.

On the top floor, she finally heard it—a soft whimper, barely audible. Mara’s heart surged. She followed the sound to a supply closet and gently knocked. The door creaked open, revealing two wide-eyed children clutching each other.

“There you are,” Mara breathed, relief and sorrow mingling in her voice. She reached out, her hands trembling. “You’re safe now.”

In the vast emptiness, hope flickered anew.

Are there children? The radio crackled, the only light in the underground bunker flickering with each desperate call. Commander Elara leaned closer, straining to hear. Outside, the world was shrouded in a thick, toxic fog, and silence pressed in from all sides.

"Repeat, are there children in your group?" she asked again. Static. Then, a faint voice: "Yes. Two. Please help."

Elara scribbled the coordinates. Her team exchanged uneasy glances—rescuing adults was dangerous enough, but children made every mission fraught with risk and hope. They donned their gear, each carrying a small, hand-knit doll for comfort, a tradition born of too many rescues and too few survivors.

Hours later, Elara’s team found the survivors huddled in a derelict subway car, fear and hope mingling in their eyes. The children’s hands clung to their parents, but when Elara knelt and offered the dolls, they reached out, silent tears tracing dirty cheeks.

The city above was lost, but underground, in the flickering light, the future still breathed.

Are there children? The question came from a stranger at the edge of the encampment, his face hidden by a wide-brimmed hat. We hesitated, unsure how to answer in the new world, where trust was as scarce as clean water.

Mina stepped forward, her hand hovering over the crude knife at her belt. "Why do you ask?" she demanded, voice low but steady. The stranger shifted, revealing a battered toy rabbit, its ears worn thin. "My boy," he said quietly, "he's lost. I heard laughter here last night."

We exchanged glances. The only child in our group, little Sam, had been missing since dusk. Mina’s face softened, and she nodded. "Come in. We’ll help you look."

As we searched the camp together, suspicion slowly thawed. Amidst the ashes of the world, the search for children was a fragile thread, binding strangers with hope and fear. When we found Sam, curled up and clutching the rabbit, the stranger wept. In that moment, we remembered what it meant to hold onto kindness, even at the end of things.

Are there children? The words lingered in the hospital corridor, an echo from a distant time of laughter and chalk dust. Dr. Sato paused, clipboard in hand, and listened to the silence that had swallowed the city since the last train left. The pediatric ward, once bright with murals, was now shrouded in shadows and dust motes.

She walked past empty beds, her footsteps muffled by discarded toys and faded blankets. The question haunted her: were there any left? Her rounds had become a ritual, less about medicine, more about hope. She left a stuffed bear on each pillow, just in case.

Tonight, a faint cough drifted from the end of the hall. Dr. Sato’s heart leapt. She entered, finding a small girl curled beneath a sheet, eyes wide and watchful. Dr. Sato knelt, her own voice trembling. “You’re safe now.”

In the hush of the ward, the child nodded, clutching the bear. Outside, the city waited in silence, but within these walls, hope dared to breathe again.

Are there children? The question was scrawled in chalk on the crumbling wall, barely visible beneath layers of dust. Lena traced the letters with trembling fingers, her breath catching in the cold air. She’d been searching for weeks, moving from shelter to shelter, following rumors and fading footprints.

She moved deeper into the abandoned school, her lantern casting long shadows. A distant scrape made her stop; her heart thudded. “Is someone there?” she called softly.

A muffled giggle answered. Lena followed the sound, her hope growing with every step. In the gym, she found them—three children huddled beneath the bleachers, eyes wide with fear and hope. Their faces lit up at the sight of her.

She knelt, voice gentle. “I’m here to help.”

That night, together in the old nurse’s office, Lena read them stories by lantern light. The world outside was broken, but for these few precious hours, there was warmth, safety, and the fragile promise of a new beginning.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
Are there children? The question lingered in the chilly air of the abandoned playground, echoing off rusted swings and hollowed-out merry-go-rounds. Marcus, flashlight trembling in his grasp, stepped forward, scanning the shadows. He’d followed the laughter here, high-pitched and bright, but now there was only silence. His boots crunched over broken glass as he called out again, "Hello? Is anyone here?"

A cold wind answered, sending a faded kite fluttering from the tangled branches above. Then, a giggle—so faint he almost missed it—drifted from the tunnel slide. Heart pounding, Marcus approached, peering into the darkness. A pair of eyes glinted back, followed by another. Children, pale and insubstantial, emerged one by one, their smiles too wide, their forms flickering.

"We’ve been waiting for you," they whispered in unison, voices threaded with both hope and hunger. Marcus swallowed, realizing too late that some questions should never be asked, and some playgrounds should never be found after dark.

Are there children? The old woman’s voice cracked as she peered into the wagon. The mismatched wheels rattled over gravel, and the canvas cover flapped in the wind, revealing nothing but burlap sacks and a half-empty lantern. She waited for an answer, but the driver only grunted and kept moving, eyes fixed on the horizon.

Night crept closer. The woods around the road whispered secrets. The woman shuffled alongside, her question hanging between them like fog. Finally, a tiny hand slipped from beneath a sack, clutching a faded toy soldier. The woman smiled, relief and sorrow mingling in her gaze. She whispered a lullaby, barely audible over the cart’s creaking.

In this world, where children were rumors and memories, the answer was precious. The driver tipped his hat as the woman climbed in, shielding the child from sight. Together, they vanished into the forest, carrying with them hope that childhood, and perhaps the world itself, could be rebuilt from the smallest of secrets.

Are there children? The question echoed across the empty field, the sun setting behind the distant hills. Inspector Voss scanned the tumbledown farmhouse, its windows dark, its doors askew. She hesitated, remembering the stories: laughter at midnight, tiny footprints in the mud, lullabies drifting from nowhere.

She stepped toward the porch, boots sinking into soft earth. "Is anyone here?" she called, her voice trembling. A curtain fluttered. A shadow darted past. Voss gripped her flashlight. Something giggled inside, a sound both joyous and chilling.

She pushed open the door. The air was thick with the scent of old toys and dust. Dolls gazed from broken shelves, their painted eyes unblinking. Suddenly, a child appeared—barely more than a wisp, her form flickering. "We’re here," she whispered, voice like wind through reeds. "But we’re not what you’re looking for."

Voss backed away, heart pounding. She understood, finally, why the locals never answered the question. Not all children in this place were meant for the daylight.

Are there children? The inquiry was whispered beneath the crumbling archway of the orphanage, where shadows clung to the walls like old memories. Sister Mariette waited, breath visible in the cold air, hands trembling as she clutched her rosary. The silence pressed in, heavy and unbroken. Then, from the staircase, a faint scuffling—a child’s foot, perhaps, or a mouse.

She called again, voice steadier. "Come out, little ones." Slowly, three shapes emerged, clutching threadbare blankets, eyes wide and bright. Mariette knelt, arms open. The children hesitated, then rushed forward, collapsing into her embrace. She wept, relief mixing with sorrow for those who did not return.

In the morning, she would search again, through the ruined halls and battered dormitories, asking her question into empty rooms and hoping, each dawn, for another answer. In this place, children were miracles—fragile, fleeting, and fiercely protected by those who remembered the world before.

Are there children? The phrase was painted in bold red letters across the old station wall, chipped and fading. Every morning, Mara passed it on her way to work. She never saw children—not on the trains, not in the parks, not in the schools whose windows gathered dust. The city had grown quiet, almost reverent, as if holding its breath.

One day, as she hurried past, she caught a glimpse of movement—a flash of small hands, a giggle behind the station pillar. Mara stopped, heart pounding. A boy peeked out, his eyes bright with mischief. She wanted to speak, to ask his name, but he pressed a finger to his lips and darted away into the maze of alleys.

That night, Mara dreamed of laughter echoing through empty streets, of chalk drawings on pavement and skipping ropes. When she woke, she painted her own question on the wall: "Where have the children gone?" And beneath it, in smaller, spidery letters, someone had written: "We’re still here."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
Are there children? The question echoed in the dusty halls of the abandoned observatory. Mara squinted into the half-light, brushing aside a curtain of cobwebs. The silhouette beside her—Eli, her younger brother—clung to her sleeve. “I saw someone,” he whispered. The wind rattled a loose pane. Somewhere deeper in the building, a soft giggle rippled through the silence. 

Mara’s heart thudded. They had come searching for the lost kittens, following a trail of tiny pawprints. Now, the evidence suggested something else roamed these shadowed corridors. She took Eli’s hand and tiptoed forward, her flashlight beam trembling. 

In the planetarium dome, a circle of children’s shoes lay neatly arranged, empty and facing outward. A marble rolled across the floor, stopping at Mara’s feet. “Are there children?” she repeated, her voice trembling. 

A chorus of whispers answered from the darkness, “We’re playing hide and seek. Won’t you join us?”

Are there children? The words floated over the fence as Mrs. Dalloway leaned on her rake. She’d heard laughter earlier, or perhaps it was only the wind through the empty swings. The old playground was supposed to be off-limits—condemned, some said. But sometimes, at twilight, she saw shapes weaving through the slides, scraps of color flitting between the shadows.

She waited, listening. A giggle, faint as breath, drifted from behind the merry-go-round. Mrs. Dalloway hesitated. She remembered a time when the playground teemed with life, her own daughter’s laughter ringing out. The silence since had been heavy, broken only by the stray cat or distant car.

Tonight, though, as the sun bled into the horizon, she saw them: a handful of children, running, skipping, their outlines soft and pale. They waved, beckoning. Mrs. Dalloway blinked, and the playground was empty again. Only the wind, and her question, remained.

Are there children? The voice crackled through the radio, an unfamiliar frequency snaking into the empty cabin. Commander Hale hesitated before answering. She glanced at the two small forms bundled in blankets beside the makeshift heater. Their eyes, wide and unblinking, reflected the pale aurora leaking through frost-streaked windows.

She pressed the transmitter. “Yes. Two.”

A long silence followed. Then: “Keep them safe.”

Outside, the storm howled, snow piling up against the door. The children never spoke. Hale had found them in a downed escape pod three days ago, alone but unharmed. She wondered where they came from, what they knew, and if the voice on the radio was friend or foe.

As the night deepened, one of the children reached out, placing a tiny hand on Hale’s arm. “Don’t be afraid,” he whispered. “We remember you.”

Hale shivered, unsure if she felt comforted or more alone than ever.

Are there children? The old caretaker asked as he unlocked the creaking gates of the orphanage. The inspector nodded, glancing at his clipboard. Officially, the building had been closed for years, but rumors persisted—flickering lights at midnight, laughter behind boarded windows.

Inside, corridors stretched like arteries through the heart of the crumbling manor. The inspector paused as a small, cold hand slipped into his. He turned, startled, but saw only shadows pooling at the base of the stairs. “Did you see that?” he whispered.

The caretaker’s face paled. “They never really leave, you know. They’re waiting.”

A distant lullaby floated down the hall, notes unraveling in the chill. The inspector’s pen shook as he scribbled on his form, but the words seemed to twist and fade, as if the house itself was erasing them. He left hurriedly, the question still echoing: Are there children?

Are there children? The nurse asked, peering into the smoky twilight that drifted through the shattered window. Ruben shook his head. He’d seen no one, but the silence in the rubble was uneasy, like a breath held too long. The city had been evacuated for days now, but stories lingered—ghosts, stragglers, laughter echoing in the empty streets.

Suddenly, a skipping rope slapped the pavement beyond the barricade. A flash of red—maybe a dress, maybe a trick of the dust. The nurse darted forward, calling, but only pigeons scattered.

They searched the block, Ruben and the nurse, finding only a faded teddy bear nestled under a car door. As dusk pressed in, Ruben thought he heard a song—soft, tuneless, but unmistakably young. He squeezed the bear, hoping, until he realized the melody was coming from within. He pressed his ear to the toy. It sang on, despite the emptiness all around.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text: Are there children? The question echoed through the empty corridor, its answer uncertain. Maribel pressed her ear to the cracked wooden door, listening for laughter or even a cry, but only the soft hum of wind replied. The village had been deserted for weeks, yet footprints—small, muddy ones—dotted the path behind the old schoolhouse. She called softly, “Hello? Is anyone there?” Shadows flickered in the corner of her eye. A giggle, faint as dew, flitted past. Heart pounding, Maribel stepped inside. The room was dust-choked, desks askew, but on the chalkboard, a message: ‘We’re playing hide and seek.’ Maribel smiled, tears stinging her eyes. She’d found them—not in flesh, but in memories that clung to the walls. The children were gone, but their spirits danced on, playful and bright, reminding her that hope could linger, even in silence.

Are there children? The words slipped from Dr. Liem’s lips as she peered into the overgrown greenhouse. Her flashlight trembled as it illuminated rows of wild tomatoes and beans, but no sign of anyone living. The storm had driven the town’s people away, but Liem had heard rumors—tiny faces glimpsed at dusk, laughter wafting through broken windows. Suddenly, a soft rustle beside the compost heap. She knelt down to find a cardboard fort, patched with bottle caps and faded candy wrappers. Inside, three wide-eyed children gazed up, clutching makeshift dolls. They didn’t speak, but their hope radiated. Liem smiled gently, holding out her hand. “It’s safe now,” she whispered. The children hesitated, then crawled out, blinking in the sun for the first time in weeks. The world outside was uncertain, but together, they would build anew.

Are there children? The words came from the radio’s static, barely audible above the crackle of the dying fire. Mara huddled under a moth-eaten blanket, listening, hoping. She and her brother had been alone for days, hiding from the patrols. Each night, they tuned in, waiting for news—any sign they weren’t the last. Tonight, the voice sounded different. Softer. As if the speaker knew someone young was listening. Mara pressed the transmitter. “Yes. We’re here.” Silence stretched, then: “Stay inside. Help is coming.” Mara squeezed her brother’s hand. For the first time in weeks, she allowed herself to believe. Outside, the world raged on, but hope, fragile and trembling, had finally found its way in.

Are there children? The tour guide’s voice reverberated through the ancient stone hall, disturbing a dust-laden silence. No one answered. The group shuffled, uneasy, casting nervous glances at the faded murals—scenes of laughter, games, and small hands clutching bright ribbons. Suddenly, a marble rolled across the floor, spinning to a stop at the guide’s feet. The youngest in the group, a boy with freckled cheeks, stooped to pick it up. He looked around, puzzled, then smiled shyly at the shadows. Moments later, echoes of distant giggles floated down from the rafters. Were there children? Perhaps not in flesh and bone, but in echoes and memory, they lingered, refusing to be forgotten.

Are there children? The nurse asked, voice trembling as she scanned the rubble. In the dim light, dust motes danced like tiny fireflies. The bombing had left the orphanage in ruins, but she’d heard rumors—a laughter, a song, drifting from beneath collapsed beams. She called again, gently, “Children, are you there?” A faint cough answered. Crawling forward, she found a pocket of space where three children huddled, eyes wide, clutching each other. Relief washed over her as she wrapped them in her arms, promising safety. Above, the city roared with chaos, but here, in the fragile quiet, hope flickered back to life.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text: Are there children? The question echoed in the empty playground, where the only movement was wind nudging a tired swing. Francesca had come here every afternoon for weeks, clutching a faded photograph of three smiling faces. Once, laughter had filled this place—her children’s laughter. Now, it was just a memory, replaying in her mind as she wandered among the silent jungle gym and abandoned jump ropes. Tonight, a faint giggle drifted on the breeze, impossibly familiar. Francesca spun around, heart racing. Shadows danced beneath the slide. She stepped closer, calling out their names. The giggle came again, closer this time. Slowly, shapes emerged from the gloom—three children, eyes shining with secrets. Francesca’s breath caught. "Are you real?" she whispered. They only smiled, and in that moment, the playground was full of laughter once more.

Are there children? The question hovered in the air as the inspector peered into the dimly lit room. Dust motes swirled in the slanting light from a single, high window. The old caretaker hesitated, tracing the outline of a faded photograph on the mantel—a group of children, their faces blurred by time. "Not anymore," he murmured, voice trembling. But as the inspector turned to leave, a soft giggle echoed from behind the thick velvet curtains. The caretaker stiffened, his eyes wide. "Sometimes," he whispered, "they come back." The inspector paused, uncertain whether he’d heard a child’s laugh or only the lonely sigh of the wind. Outside, the playground swing creaked, swaying gently, though the air was still. No one else was there.

Are there children? The words tumbled out of Mara’s mouth before she could stop herself. She stared at the cluster of strange houses, each one painted with odd symbols and adorned with fluttering ribbons. An old woman looked up from her knitting, her eyes sharp and bright. "Not since the river changed course," she replied, her voice thin as a reed. Mara shivered, glancing at the silent fields. "What happened to them?" The woman only smiled, a small, sad twist of her lips. That night, Mara heard the distant sound of laughter, carried on the wind. She followed it to the riverbank, where shadows flickered and vanished. In the morning, she found a tiny, mud-caked shoe at her doorstep, as if left there by a ghost—or a promise.

Are there children? The question came from the stranger who stood at the edge of the clearing, his silhouette blurred by the mist. The villagers exchanged glances, their faces pale and drawn. No one spoke. The stranger’s eyes swept over the cottages, the abandoned toys, the silent schoolhouse. He waited. Finally, an old man stepped forward, his voice barely above a whisper: "Not anymore. They left with the dawn, following the song only they could hear." The stranger nodded as if he understood. He turned and walked away, the mist swallowing him whole. In the distance, a melody drifted through the trees—high, bright, and impossibly young.

Are there children? The question lingered, unanswered, as the sun dipped below the horizon. The town’s only playground stood in eerie silence, swings motionless, seesaw frozen mid-air. Miss Harper, the librarian, remembered a time when laughter echoed through these streets. But now, the houses were shuttered, the school boarded up. Some said the children had vanished overnight; others whispered of a pact made long ago. On the wind’s edge came the faintest sound—a lullaby, sung in a language no one remembered. Miss Harper closed her eyes, listening, and for a moment, she could almost hear footsteps running on the cracked pavement, voices calling out in play. But when she opened her eyes, the silence had settled again, deeper than before.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
Are you calling Mari a liar?”  “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.  

The words hung in the kitchen like a thick fog. Mari’s hands tightened around the chipped mug, knuckles whitening. Gloria’s eyes narrowed, her stance bristling with indignation. 

“You’re supposed to be her friend,” Gloria hissed. “After what she’s done for you—”

Gabe shrugged, glancing at the window where rain streaked the glass. “Friendship’s not the same as trust.”

A silence, heavy and cold. Mari’s voice was barely a whisper. “I didn’t take the money.”

No one moved. The ticking of the old clock filled the space between them. Gabe reached into his jacket and slid a folded piece of paper across the counter.

“Then what’s this?”

Mari stared at the note in her own handwriting, words pleading for forgiveness. “Where did you find that?”

“In the garden. Buried under the hydrangeas.”

Gloria’s voice wavered. “Mari?”

Tears welled in Mari’s eyes. “I was trying to protect someone.”

Gabe’s gaze softened, ever so slightly. “Sometimes, protecting someone looks a lot like lying to everyone else.”

Are you calling Mari a liar?”  “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.  

A hush fell over the group. The fire in the hearth popped and crackled, but no one moved. Mari sank into the old armchair, arms hugging her knees. Her eyes glistened but she didn’t speak.

Jules stepped forward, her hands trembling. “Gabe, you know her. You know she wouldn’t—”

“I know exactly what people are capable of,” Gabe interrupted, his voice cold. “And sometimes the ones you trust most have the best masks.”

Mari’s voice was barely a whisper. “Gabe, please. I—”

He looked away, jaw clenched. “The missing key, the strange footprints by the shed. None of that makes sense unless someone here is lying.”

Jules shook her head, tears threatening. “Then you should look at everyone. Not just Mari.”

Outside, thunder rolled. Mari pressed her palm to her heart, steadying her breath. “I didn’t take anything,” she said, her voice trembling but clear. “And if you don’t believe me, I guess that’s another thing I’ve lost tonight.”

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

The accusation hovered in the air, sharp and brittle. Mari sat at the edge of the table, her gaze fixed on the swirling pattern of the wood. The others shifted uncomfortably.

“Gabe, that’s not fair,” said Lena, voice trembling. “We’ve known Mari for years.”

Gabe’s eyes narrowed. “People change. Maybe she did.”

Mari’s lips parted, but no words came. Instead, she reached into her coat pocket, retrieving a small, velvet pouch. She placed it on the table, its contents clinking softly.

“I didn’t steal from anyone,” Mari said quietly. “But you’re right, people do change. Maybe not in the ways you think.”

She stood and walked to the door, pausing as she gripped the handle. “I hope you find what you’re looking for, Gabe.”

The door closed behind her, leaving a silence that felt like judgment.

Lena glared at Gabe. “You just lost your truest friend.”

Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Dylan slammed his fist on the table. “You know what you’re saying? She’d never do something like that.”

Gabe shrugged, avoiding Mari’s wide, wounded eyes. “Maybe you don’t know her as well as you think.”

The room chilled. Mari’s lips quivered, but she stood her ground. “I told you the truth, Gabe.”

“But you were the only one in the office after hours,” Gabe replied, voice low. “And the files went missing on your watch.”

A tear slipped down Mari’s cheek. “You don’t have to believe me. But I didn’t take them. Maybe you should ask yourself who benefits most from those files being gone.”

Dylan looked between them, suspicion dawning. “Wait, Gabe… where were you last night?”

Gabe’s jaw clenched. “Don’t turn this on me.”

Mari wiped her eyes, determined. “You wanted someone to blame, and I was easy. But I’m not the liar here.”

The silence snapped like a brittle twig, and nothing would ever be the same.

Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Tessa’s voice trembled, almost pleading. “She’s my sister, Gabe. She wouldn’t risk everything, not after—”

Gabe’s jaw tightened. “People do strange things when they’re desperate.”

Mari stood in the doorway, silent, her shadow stretching across the linoleum. She watched the faces turn toward her, suspicion and sorrow mingling in their eyes.

“I didn’t take your mother’s necklace,” Mari said, voice steady. “But if you’ve already decided I’m guilty, nothing I say will matter.”

Tessa shook her head. “No, Mari. I believe you.”

Gabe sighed, rubbing his temples. “Belief isn’t proof. The necklace is gone, and you were the last one in the house.”

Mari’s lips pressed together. “Sometimes the truth isn’t enough.”

She walked past them, out into the rain, leaving muddy footprints on the tile. Tessa looked at Gabe, eyes shining with hurt. “If you’re wrong about her, you’ll regret it.”

Gabe stared at the empty doorway, wondering if he already did.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, his voice steady, but his eyes darting to the window where dusk bled into the horizon. The room went silent, thick with accusation and the lingering scent of burnt toast. Mari stood by the door, arms crossed, her silhouette trembling.

“I saw the ledger,” she said. “It’s missing three entries.”

Gabe shook his head. “Then explain the deposits.”

Mari’s lips pressed together. Outside, a car backfired. “I can’t explain what I don’t know.”

“That’s convenient,” muttered Greg from the corner.

“Enough,” Gabe snapped. “Until we know for sure, no one’s blaming anyone.”

But suspicion had crept into the walls, and as the night deepened, so did the mystery. By morning, the ledger would be gone entirely, and Mari—along with it.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, eyes narrowing as the room tensed. The others exchanged glances, unsure whether to press further. Mari shifted uneasily, clutching the faded envelope to her chest.

"You all saw the message," she whispered, voice trembling. "I told you where I found it."

Gabe stepped closer, lowering his voice. "But you’re the only one who’s actually read it."

A hush fell. The old grandfather clock ticked ominously in the hallway. Finally, Lila broke the silence. "So what now? We just trust her?"

Mari met their eyes, defiance flickering in her gaze. "You can believe me, or you can check the attic yourself. But I’m done taking the blame for secrets I never made."

No one moved. Outside, thunder rolled. The truth—whatever it was—waited above them, shrouded in dust and shadows.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, his words echoing a little too confidently through the cramped living room. The air was thick with years of unresolved tension and now, a question that demanded more than just trust.

Mari didn’t flinch. Her gaze was unwavering, but her fingers twisted the hem of her sweater. “I told you what I saw. If you don’t believe me, check the shed yourself.”

Greg looked from Gabe to Mari, then out the window where the rain was starting. “If she’s lying, what’s her angle?”

Gabe shrugged. “People lie for all sorts of reasons.” He hesitated, then stood. “But maybe she’s telling the truth.”

Silence pressed in, heavy and expectant. Mari’s lips parted as if to speak, but a sharp crack of thunder interrupted her. The lights flickered. In that instant, they all realized—whatever secrets the night held, honesty might be the least predictable one.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, though his fingers drummed rapidly against the table. The others watched him—some with suspicion, others with relief. Mari stood by the back door, light from the hallway casting her shadow long and thin across the kitchen tiles.

She swallowed, her eyes darting to the letter crumpled in her fist. “I told you what happened. You can believe me or not.”

Gabe’s jaw clenched. The story, wild as it sounded, was their only lead. He glanced around at the faces—every one of them desperate for an answer.

Jessa finally spoke. “Let’s go to the old well. If the key is there, we’ll know.”

Mari nodded, and without another word, led them into the night. The truth, for better or worse, waited beneath the moonlit stones.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, but the tremor in his voice betrayed him. The others exchanged glances, the air thick with unease. Mari stood rigid, hands clenched at her sides.

"You saw the photograph," she said, holding out the faded print like a shield. "I didn’t fake it."

Gabe bit his lip, searching her face for the familiar warmth that now seemed absent. "It just doesn’t add up."

Jake, slouched in the armchair, finally spoke. "Either Mari’s telling the truth, or someone’s gone to a lot of trouble to make us think she is."

Lightning forked outside, illuminating the doubt in everyone’s eyes. Mari, voice barely above a whisper, said, "I just want to find out what happened to Uncle Pete."

Gabe nodded, the words catching in his throat. "Then let’s start by believing you. For now."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
Are you calling Mari a liar?” 

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

The accusation hung in the air, sticky and electric. Mari watched from the doorway, her arms crossed, eyes glinting. The old grandfather clock ticked away precious seconds. Eliza clenched her fists. “You weren’t there, Gabe. You didn’t see the look on her face.”

Gabe shrugged, a careful, measured motion. “I know what I heard, Eliza. She said she saw the painting move. That’s not normal. Either she’s lying, or—”

“Or what?” Mari’s voice, sharp and sudden, cut through the tension. “Or I’m crazy?”

“No,” Gabe said, softer now. “But something strange is happening in this house.”

Eliza stepped forward, her voice trembling. “We need to trust each other. Whatever is going on, it’s bigger than all of us.”

The wind howled outside, rattling the windows. In the silence that followed, the painting above the mantel shifted—again—just a fraction of an inch.

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

A hush fell over the cramped apartment. Mari, sitting at the edge of the couch, bit her lip and looked away. The air between them was heavy with secrets.

Jasper leaned forward, eyes narrowing. “So you’re just going to take her word for it?”

Gabe’s jaw clenched. “I trust her. I always have.”

Mari’s voice was barely a whisper. “You don’t have to believe me. But I know what I saw.”

The three sat in silence, the only sound the ticking of the kitchen clock. Outside, sirens wailed in the distance. Something shifted in Gabe’s expression—doubt, perhaps, or fear. He stood, walked to the window, and peered into the night.

“Maybe we should call the police,” he murmured.

Jasper shook his head. “If Mari’s telling the truth, the police can’t help.”

No one noticed Mari’s trembling hands clutching the photograph. The faces in it seemed to smirk, caught forever in a moment only she understood.

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Mari’s shadow stretched long over the cracked linoleum as she entered the kitchen, her eyes flickering between the two. Tension clung to the air, thick and unyielding. Gabe glanced up, his face unreadable.

Mari set the envelope on the table. “If you’d just look inside, you’d see I’m telling the truth.”

Elena hesitated, her hands trembling. “You’re saying you saw him?”

Mari nodded. “Last night. By the river.”

Gabe opened the envelope, spilling its contents—a faded photograph and a single blue feather—onto the table. He frowned. “This… this can’t be.”

Mari’s voice was steady. “He’s back, Gabe. And he’s looking for us.”

Elena swallowed hard. “We swore we’d never speak of him again.”

Gabe looked at Mari, fear creeping into his eyes. “If you’re right, we’re all in danger.”

The old clock chimed midnight. Outside, a cold wind howled, carrying with it the promise of old debts come due.

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

A hush swept through the cluttered attic. Dust motes hung in the sunlight, swirling lazily as the trio stared at the battered trunk. Mari’s hands trembled on the lid, but her eyes were steady.

“Open it, then,” whispered Jonas, his voice sharp with doubt.

Mari knelt, released the latch, and lifted the lid. Inside, old letters, brittle with age, spilled across faded velvet. Atop them, a tarnished locket gleamed.

Gabe crouched beside her, his gaze flickering between Mari and Jonas. “She’s been telling us about the letters for years. Why would she lie?”

Jonas crossed his arms. “Maybe she wanted attention.”

Mari drew out a letter, hands shaking. “See for yourself.”

Jonas took it, his skepticism melting to surprise as he read the looping script. “This… this is from Grandfather. He did know about the gold.”

Gabe smiled gently at Mari. “Sometimes, the truth just needs a little dusting off.”

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

The accusation reverberated through the dim-lit room, where shadows played against peeling wallpaper. Mari, sitting rigidly on the sofa, stared at the floor, her fists clenched so hard her knuckles blanched.

Liam paced by the window, peering into the foggy street below. “It’s just—her story doesn’t add up. First the lights, then the noises in the attic. You know how it sounds.”

Gabe shook his head. “You weren’t there, Liam. You didn’t see her face.”

Mari swallowed, lifting her gaze. “I know what I saw. Something’s wrong here. I’m not making it up.”

Silence pressed in, thick as the dust in the corners. Gabe crossed the room and sat beside Mari, offering a small, reassuring smile.

“We’ll figure it out,” he said quietly.

Outside, a sudden gust rattled the window. Somewhere above, faint footsteps echoed, as if the house itself was listening in.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
"Are you calling Mari a liar?" 

"I have no reason to believe she’s not," Gabe said, glancing toward the door where Mari had disappeared only moments earlier. The tension in the kitchen was thick, almost tangible, as if the air itself was holding its breath. 

Anna set her mug down harder than she intended, coffee sloshing over the rim. "She's been my friend for years. Why would she lie about something like this?"

Gabe shrugged, his jaw clenched. "People have their reasons. Maybe she thought it would help you. Or maybe she just wanted attention."

A gust of wind rattled the windowpane. Anna stared at Gabe, searching for a trace of the boy she once knew—the one who trusted too easily, believed in everyone. "I need to hear it from her," she said quietly, stepping out into the hallway. The door creaked as she opened it, and Mari's silhouette stood at the end, head bowed. 

Anna hesitated. "Mari?"

Mari looked up, tears shining. "I’m sorry, Anna. I never meant for it to go this far."

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. He fiddled with the frayed cuff of his jacket, eyes darting to the window, where dusk painted the glass in bruised purples. The room was silent except for the ticking clock and the distant hum of traffic.

Lena’s fingers drummed the table. “You know what happens if she’s lying.”

Gabe nodded, but his mind was elsewhere—remembering the way Mari’s voice quivered when she told them about the key, the attic, the locked box she’d never dared open.

“I believe her,” he said, voice softer. “But belief doesn’t open boxes.”

Lena stood, pushing back her chair. “Then we’ll find out. Tonight.”

They met Mari at the foot of the old staircase. She handed Gabe the key, her hand trembling. As the lock clicked open, secrets spilled out with the dust, and Gabe realized trust is never as simple as believing or not. Sometimes, it’s the courage to see what happens after.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, his voice steady, but his eyes betrayed a flicker of doubt. The candlelight flickered between them, casting long shadows on the peeling wallpaper. 

Sophie bit her lip, glancing toward the staircase where Mari had gone minutes before. "But you saw the letter, Gabe. You saw—"

"I saw a piece of paper," he interrupted. "And I heard Mari's story. But stories aren't always the truth, are they?"

Thunder rolled outside, shaking the windows. Sophie shivered. "You think she made it up?"

Gabe hesitated, then shook his head. "I just think... people do strange things when they're scared. Maybe she thought lying would keep us safe."

A soft creak on the stairs. Mari's silhouette appeared, her face pale.

"I heard you," she whispered. "And I'm not lying. But I wish I was."

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. His voice was measured, but his fingers fidgeted with the edge of his notebook. Holly stared at him, eyebrows raised.

“So we’re just going to ignore the fact that every time she tells that story, something changes?”

Gabe shrugged. “People remember things differently. Trauma messes with your head.”

Holly shook her head. “Or she’s hiding something.”

They both flinched as the door creaked open. Mari entered, clutching a faded photograph. For a long moment, she just looked at them, her eyes shining with something like fear.

“I know what you’re thinking,” she said quietly. “But I’m telling the truth. If you want proof, come with me tonight.”

Holly and Gabe exchanged a glance. Outside, the wind howled. Inside, something shifted—the lines between truth and lies, trust and suspicion, blurring in the dim light as Mari beckoned them to follow.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?" 

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, but his words hung in the stale air like cobwebs. The clock on the mantel ticked, each second louder than the last. 

Rosa crossed her arms. "You didn't see her face when she told us, Gabe. She looked terrified."

"Maybe she's scared because she knows what happens if the truth comes out." Gabe's gaze dropped to the floor. "Or maybe she's scared because she's been keeping something from us all along."

The house creaked, old wood groaning under secrets too heavy to bear. 

Rosa shook her head. "If Mari's lying, then everything we believed is wrong."

Gabe finally met her eyes, regret flickering across his face. "Sometimes it's easier to believe a lie, Rosa. Maybe that's what we've been doing."

A soft knock echoed from the hallway. Without a word, they both turned, uncertain if they wanted the truth—or if they could handle it when it finally arrived.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, eyes narrowing at the edge of his glass. The room’s hush thickened, everyone waiting for someone to break it. Mari stood by the window, arms crossed, her silhouette sharp against the dusk. 

“I saw what I saw,” she said. Her voice barely trembled.

Jonas, bristling with barely contained anger, shook his head. “You’re asking us to believe something impossible.”

Mari turned, her glare unwavering. “Sometimes the truth sounds impossible. That doesn’t make it a lie.”

Gabe set his glass down. “Look, we’re not getting anywhere like this.” He sighed, tired. “Mari, if you’re telling the truth, we have to act. If not—”

“If not, what?” Mari cut in. “You’ll go back to pretending nothing’s wrong until it’s too late?”

The old grandfather clock struck eight. Shadows deepened. Jonas opened his mouth, but the lights flickered—once, twice. When they came back, Mari was gone, and Gabe’s glass lay shattered on the floor.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, his voice barely above a whisper. The flickering candlelight made shadows dance across the cracked wallpaper. Mari’s hands trembled, clutching the faded photograph to her chest.

"Then you believe in ghosts, too?" asked Lena, arching an eyebrow.

Gabe didn’t answer. Instead, he stared at the photograph—three smiling children, all long grown now, except for the one who never had the chance. Mari’s brother, gone since the lake accident.

Mari’s voice quivered. "He stood at the foot of my bed last night. He tried to tell me something."

Lena scoffed, but Gabe only nodded. "Sometimes, the dead come back. Not to haunt, but to warn."

A cold wind rattled the window. Mari’s eyes widened, staring past them. "He’s here. He says we’re not safe."

Gabe stood, searching the corners of the room, heart pounding. The candle guttered, plunging them into darkness. In the silence, a voice, not quite Mari’s, whispered, "He’s right."

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, but his gaze flickered to Mari with uncertainty. The rain pounded against the tin roof, drowning out the uneasy silence that followed.

Mari’s jaw tightened. “I know what I saw. There was something in those woods—something watching us.”

Jonah snorted. “A deer, maybe.”

Gabe shook his head. “Mari’s never been one to make things up. If she says there was something, there was.”

Mari stepped forward, her voice trembling but determined. “It wasn’t an animal. Its eyes glowed red. And it spoke.”

A chill ran through the group. Outside, the wind howled. Suddenly, the lamp flickered. Shadows stretched and wrapped around the corners of the room.

Gabe swallowed, realizing he wanted to believe Mari. But as the temperature dropped, he wondered if it was already too late.

From the darkness outside came a whisper, echoing Mari’s words: “I see you.”

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said. He tried to keep his voice steady, but the accusation from across the table stung. Mari watched him, her knuckles white on the chipped Formica. 

“Then why do you keep asking the same question?”

Gabe stared at the window, rain streaking the glass. “Because nothing adds up. You said you saw someone in the alley at midnight. But the cameras—”

“Cameras miss things,” Mari snapped. “I know what I saw.”

The silence pressed in. The only sound was rain and the slow creak of the old house settling. Gabe shifted in his seat, unease prickling his skin.

He wanted to believe her. But something about Mari’s story—about the shadow with no face, the way it moved—gnawed at him. 

Outside, lightning flashed. In its brief glare, Gabe caught sight of a figure behind the glass. Faceless. Watching. He stood, heart pounding, and finally understood: Mari hadn’t lied. She’d only told the part he was willing to hear.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, but his voice wavered, betraying the uncertainty he tried to hide. Mari glared at him, her cheeks flushed with frustration.

"You think I made it up? That I imagined the whole thing?" she demanded, clutching her notebook tighter.

Simon looked between them, chewing his lip. "It's just… that's a pretty wild story, Mari."

Mari slammed her notebook on the table. "I know what I saw. The man in the red coat was there. He dropped the envelope. I picked it up."

Gabe ran a hand through his hair, glancing at the kitchen clock as if time might offer answers. "If Mari says it happened, maybe we should check the alley."

Simon shrugged. "Fine, but if we find nothing?"

Mari stood up, defiant. "Then you can call me a liar. But until then, I want to know why he chose me."

The three of them headed out into the night, the city’s secrets pressing close, waiting to be revealed.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
Silence fell between them, thick and humming with accusation. In the dim kitchen light, Rosa’s eyes flashed. “Gabe, you know she’s been acting strange for weeks.”

He shrugged, hands tightening around his coffee mug. “Strange doesn’t mean dishonest. Maybe you’re seeing things that aren’t there.”

Gabe’s jaw clenched. “Kids wander. She’s eight. Let her have secrets.”

Gabe leaned back against the counter, arms folded. “People get nervous. Doesn’t make her a liar.”

Mari’s hands fidgeted with the hem of her shirt. “No.”

The accusation lingered in the air, sharp as a blade. Gabe’s gaze never wavered. “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” he said, voice measured.

The floor creaked above them. Gabe looked up, tension in his shoulders. “We’ll ask her, together.”

But when they reached Mari’s room, the window was open, curtains fluttering in the moonlight, and Mari was gone. On the sill, a single feather glistened, impossibly blue.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, though his eyes betrayed a flicker of doubt.

Sasha scoffed. “She told me she saw a fox in the attic. A fox, Gabe! And that it spoke to her.”

“That may be, but you didn’t see her face. She wasn’t making it up. She was terrified. What if she really did see something?”

That night, Gabe sat on Mari’s bed, moonlight casting silver over her small frame. “You can tell me anything,” he whispered.

Mari looked up, eyes wide and honest. “The fox said you wouldn’t believe me.”

Gabe’s skin prickled. He wondered which was more unsettling: Mari’s story, or the growing sense that something in the house was listening.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. He stared at the crooked painting on the wall, avoiding Lena’s gaze.

Lena’s hands fluttered, nervous. “What about the missing keys? She’s the only one who could have taken them.”

Gabe shrugged. “She’s seven. Kids lose things.”
