A chill passed through Gabe. He thought of Mari’s wide, solemn eyes, her insistence that the shadows in her closet whispered at night. Maybe she wasn’t lying. Maybe she was warning them.

He met Lena’s gaze at last, uncertainty flickering between them. “Maybe we should listen to her, just this once.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

At dusk, the air was thick with the scent of honeysuckle and the hum of insects. Mae stood at the water's edge, toes curled in the cool mud, watching ripples break the glassy surface. The others—her brother, the twins, and the new boy, Saul—laughed as they splashed farther out. Saul, daring and bright-eyed, called to her: “Mae! You coming in or what?”

She hesitated, glancing over her shoulder at the line of trees. Shadows stretched, long and strange, but the promise of the water tugged at her. She waded in until the chill bit at her knees. Saul swam to meet her, grinning. “You afraid of the fish?”

“No,” she lied. She was afraid of other things—the silence under the surface, the way the lake seemed to hold secrets. But as Saul dove, sending up a spray of silver droplets, Mae dove after him. The world went quiet and green, and for a moment, she forgot her fears. When she surfaced, gasping, she was laughing. Night crept in, but the lake kept them safe, at least for now.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

A thick silence hung between them. Rain pattered softly on the wooden dock, making tiny explosions on the flat, dark water. Simon peered through the gloom, trying to decipher Anya’s expression. She just shook her head again, wrapping her arms tighter around herself.

“It’s safer here,” she whispered. “The current’s not strong. And besides, that’s where it wants us. Not in the river.”

Simon’s heart thudded. They both knew what she meant: the thing that had followed them since last summer, the shadow always just out of sight. It was supposed to be gone, left behind with childhood stories and campfire tales, but here it was, lurking, even in the familiar. He tossed a pebble into the lake, watching the ripples shudder outwards. Anya flinched.

“Tonight,” she said. “We have to face it tonight.”

Simon nodded, fear prickling his skin. Together, they stepped off the dock into the cold, waiting water, and the lake swallowed their reflections whole.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

I stared at her, unsure if she was joking. The Hudson was an endless story of currents and secrets—what could be stranger than that?

“Fine,” I said, “but do you think it’ll work?”

She grinned, holding up the mason jar. Inside, the firefly glowed a steady amber. “It has to. The legend said so.”

We trudged through the wet grass, shoes squelching, until we reached the lake’s edge. The surface was still, except for the faint ripple of some distant swimmer. She knelt and set the jar in the shallows.

“Now, wish.”

I closed my eyes and wished. For what, I’m not sure. Maybe for summer to last forever, or for the firefly’s light to guide us somewhere new. When I opened my eyes, the jar was gone—no splash, no ripple. Only her smile, full of secrets.

“Let’s go,” she said, grabbing my hand. “There’s still time.”

We ran back through the dark, the lake behind us, the memory of magic burning bright in the night air.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

It was just past midnight, and the crickets were singing their chorus to the moonlit water. I could barely see Levi’s silhouette, perched on the dock, his legs dangling above the inky black. I stepped closer, heart thudding, every childhood warning about swimming after dark echoing in my ears.

He turned to me, grinning. “Come on, it’s not cold.”

I hesitated, glancing at the reeds swaying in the gentle breeze. “What if something’s down there?”

Levi shrugged. “If there is, it’s probably been waiting all year for someone brave enough.”

That wasn’t exactly comforting, but I didn’t want to be left behind. I took a breath, dropped my towel, and dove in. The water swallowed me, cool and endless. For a moment, I let myself drift, eyes closed, ears filled with the muffled world below. When I surfaced, Levi was gone. Only his laughter echoed across the lake, and I wondered if I’d ever find him again—or if the swimming lake had claimed another secret.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Carla’s voice trembled as she scanned the moonlit surface, searching for any sign of movement. The water was unnaturally still, not a single ripple betraying what lay beneath.

“I saw it,” she whispered. “It was right there, by the reeds.”

Tom frowned, shivering despite the humid air. “You’re sure it wasn’t just a fish?”

Carla shook her head. “It was bigger than that. Much bigger.”

They stood together in the silence, hearts pounding. The night pressed in around them, thick with the scent of algae and fear. Suddenly, something broke the surface—a flash of silver, a swirl of bubbles, then nothing. Tom grabbed Carla’s hand, but she pulled away, stepping closer to the edge.

“We have to see what it is,” she insisted.

He hesitated, but followed. The lake seemed to beckon them, promising answers, or maybe more questions. Together, they slipped into the water, vanishing into the darkness, leaving only ripples behind.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

We stood on the bank, shivering in the early dawn, water lapping at our toes. The fog was thick, curling like ghostly fingers over the surface. I eyed the glint of something metallic just below the ripples.

“It’s not safe,” I whispered, recalling the stories. The lake was clean, but some said it connected to the river through hidden channels. Long ago, someone had dumped old machinery in there. And sometimes, things washed up that shouldn’t.

My brother grinned, teeth flashing. “Come on. It’s just a story.”

He waded in, water rising to his knees. I hesitated, the cold biting my ankles. Suddenly, a sharp clang echoed. My brother froze, eyes wide.

A rusted chain snaked up from the depths, wrapping around his leg. I lunged forward, grabbing his arm, pulling with all my might. Together, we tore free, tumbling onto the muddy bank, gasping.

We didn’t speak. The fog swallowed the chain again, as if it had never been there. But every time I pass the lake, I remember that cold grip—and wonder what else might be waiting, just below the surface.

In the Hudson?"

"In the swimming lake."

The distinction barely mattered to Lena, who stood knee-deep in the murky water, toes curling around the stones. She’d heard stories about the Hudson River—current strong as a bull, secrets sunk beneath its surface. But the lake, they said, was safe. Controlled. Predictable.

Lena wasn’t so sure. She watched a dragonfly skate across the water, chasing invisible prey. Her brother, Sam, was already swimming out past the buoy, his laughter echoing off the trees. Something glimmered beneath her feet—a bottle, perhaps, or the sun’s reflection. She reached down, fingers brushing silt and something smooth. Cold.

The water felt thicker here, as if it clung to her skin. She pulled up a small glass sphere, cloudy but intact. Inside, a tiny ship bobbed on a painted sea. As Lena turned it, she heard a voice—soft, urgent, muffled by water. "Come back."

She dropped the sphere. It vanished instantly. The lake's surface stilled, reflecting her uneasy face.

"Sam, let’s go!" she called.

He turned, but the water behind him rippled, and Lena wondered if the lake’s secrets were really any safer than the Hudson's.

In the Hudson?"

"In the swimming lake."

It was an odd place for the statue to appear. Not the river, but the man-made lake behind the old mill. The townspeople gathered at dawn, squinting into the mist. It stood waist-deep in water, arms outstretched, face turned skyward. Nobody remembered it being there yesterday.

Mara slipped from the crowd and waded closer, her steps cautious. She touched the smooth stone; it was warm, as if sunlight had soaked into it overnight. A fish darted past her ankle.

Suddenly, the statue’s eyes flickered, just once, like a trick of light. Mara stumbled back, heart hammering. The air felt charged now, the lake whispering in voices she couldn’t quite hear.

By dusk, the statue was gone. Only ripples remained, and the uneasy certainty that something had changed. The next morning, lilies bloomed all across the surface, white and impossibly bright.

Years later, Mara would swear she saw the statue again—far downriver, in the Hudson, arms still raised in silent warning, drifting with the current toward the open sea.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The confusion lingered as Jessa stared at the water, sunlight slicing through the treetops. She remembered her grandfather’s stories about the river currents, about things lost and never found. But this was just a lake, wasn’t it?

Her friend Max grinned, already halfway underwater. “Come on, it’s fine!”

She dipped a toe in, the chill biting. Something brushed her ankle—slick, soft, gone in an instant. Jessa shivered, scanning the glassy surface. A turtle, maybe. Or a fish. But a ripple fanned out where nothing moved.

She took a breath and dove. The world went silent, blue-green and shadowed. Her hand closed on something cold: a necklace, tangled around a branch. Jessa surfaced, coughing, the chain glinting in her palm.

Max eyed it, recognition flickering across his face. “That’s my sister’s. She lost it last summer.”

Jessa stared at the lake, suddenly aware of its depth, its secrets. The Hudson was far away, but maybe all waters shared a memory. She let the necklace sink back down, watching it vanish, and felt the weight of unseen things below.

In the Hudson?"

"In the swimming lake."

Jonah looked at Sadie, incredulous. "I told you, it was a shape. Like a person, but bigger. It wasn’t just a log."

Sadie kicked at the water’s edge, unsettling a cloud of silt. The lake looked innocent enough, ringed by cattails and laughter from the picnic area. But Jonah’s words lingered, unsettling as the shadow he claimed to have seen.

He waded out, despite Sadie's skeptical sigh. The lake was cold, and each step made him shiver with more than just the temperature. Suddenly, his foot caught on something. He jerked back, but the thing—whatever it was—moved too.

Sadie saw the panic on his face and sprinted into the water. Together they tugged, and a sodden coat surfaced, heavy, ancient, buttons gleaming dully. Inside, a faded photograph, waterlogged but visible: two children, one of them unmistakably Jonah.

He stared, mouth open. Sadie's skin prickled. The lake, so familiar, suddenly felt like the deep end of a much larger mystery.

Behind them, the water stilled, the shape gone. But something had changed. And neither would swim there again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake,” she corrected, her voice trembling as the last rays of sun flickered off the water. Ben hesitated, toes curled over the slick edge of the old dock. The rumor had been that something—someone—was waiting beneath the surface tonight.

They’d come at dusk, daring each other, half-laughing, half-afraid. Now the stillness pressed in, broken only by the distant croak of a frog. “You go first,” Ben whispered.

She smiled, but her eyes darted to the shadows rippling below. With a breath, she dove. The lake swallowed her in a hush. Ben counted—one, two, three—then a scream shattered the quiet. He jumped in, the cold shocking him.

Below, shapes danced in the murk. He reached for her hand, found it, but something else brushed his leg—soft, cold, insistent. Kicking hard, they surfaced, gasping, scrambling for the dock. Behind them, the water stilled, hiding its secrets once more.

They never swam there again, but on quiet nights, Ben swore he heard someone calling from the dark water, inviting him back.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake. You know, the one near the old willow.”

Maya’s hands shook as she held the faded photograph. In it, two children—herself and her brother, Tomas—stood at the edge of the lake, beaming.

Now, thirty years later, she walked the overgrown path, the memory of Tomas’s disappearance pressing against her heart. The townspeople had whispered, but no one ever found him. She reached the willow, its branches trailing in the water, and knelt beside the shore.

“Maya?” The voice was faint, familiar. She stared at her reflection—and saw Tomas’s face beside hers.

He smiled, unchanged by time. “I’ve been waiting. Are you ready to come swimming?”

Maya felt the water tug at her, cool and sweet. She hesitated only a moment before stepping in, the lake closing over her as the willow’s branches swayed, hiding them from view.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

That brief exchange echoed as the moon rose, silvering the ripples where Levi had vanished. Emma waited at the shore, clutching the flashlight with knuckles white as chalk. The others had gone home, unconcerned, but Emma knew better—she’d seen the pattern, the way the lake chose someone every seven years.

She stepped to the edge, breath shallow, and called, “Levi?”

A bubble surfaced. Then a hand, mossy and thin, beckoned her in. Emma’s feet moved of their own accord, drawn by the promise of answers. The water enveloped her, cold and deep, and the world above faded.

Beneath, the drowned lights of the sunken carnival flickered. Levi waited, smiling, surrounded by children from decades past. Emma understood: the lake collected memories, and tonight, she was to join them.

Above, the surface smoothed, erasing every trace. The town would wonder, but the lake would remember.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The words hung in the humid night. No one dared speak after that, the silence thick with old secrets. The lake wasn’t like other lakes. It shimmered oddly under the moon, a glassy eye that never blinked. We all felt it watching. 

Last summer, Clara dove in at midnight on a dare. She emerged hours later, different. Quieter. Her laughter never reached her eyes after that. This summer, it was my turn. The others whispered my name as I stood at the edge, toes curled in the cool mud. 

“Don’t look down,” whispered Clara from the shadows. So I looked up at the stars instead and slipped beneath the surface. The water pressed in, thick as velvet. Below, something shifted—a glimmer of gold, a whisper in a language I’d never heard. I surfaced gasping, heart pounding. The others crowded close, searching my face for change.

I smiled, but the lake’s secret thrummed inside me, a song only I could hear.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The distinction was important to Riley. The Hudson was wild, unpredictable, full of tides and secrets. The swimming lake, though, was supposed to be safe. That’s what they’d always told her when she was little, when she would watch the sun set on the far shore and wonder what lived beneath.

Tonight, though, something was different. The water glowed faintly, rippling with colors she’d never seen—purples and greens that danced like northern lights. She dipped her toes in, shivering despite the warm air. The surface trembled, and a soft humming floated up, almost like singing.

Riley waded deeper, drawn by curiosity stronger than fear. As the water reached her waist, she glimpsed shapes moving below—shadows, or perhaps memories. She took a breath and dove, following the melody. Down, down, until her lungs burned and her thoughts blurred.

When she finally surfaced, the world was changed. The lake was silent, the moon gone, and the air tasted of salt and longing. She was alone—but somehow, she knew she’d finally found what she’d been searching for.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Though the distinction seemed trivial, it was everything to Maribel. The Hudson was vast, churning, unknowable, but the swimming lake—well, that was where she’d first seen the flicker of silver scales beneath the surface, where the reeds whispered secrets at midnight. That was where she’d last seen her brother, arms slicing silently through the water at dusk, vanishing just as the bullfrogs began their evening chorus.

She stood now at the edge, toes gripping the muddy bank. The full moon’s reflection shimmied across the ripples. Something moved out there, just beneath the surface—a glint, a shadow, a memory. Heart pounding, Maribel stepped forward, letting the cold water swallow her ankles, knees, then hips. The lake held her, gentle but insistent. A hand brushed hers beneath the surface, cool and familiar.

“Come back,” she whispered.

But the lake only answered with the croak of frogs and the hush of wind through reeds, keeping its secrets like always. Maribel waded back to shore, knowing she’d return tomorrow, and the day after, until the answer came—whether from the depths, or from her own heart.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The question lingered, caught between the old willow trees that bordered the shore. Jonah hesitated, his breath visible in the chilly morning air. He remembered the day he’d found the old locket, tangled in the lake weeds, its silver casing etched with initials he’d never seen before. No one swam in the Hudson anymore—not since the currents grew strange, and the stories spread about things moving in the dark water.

But the swimming lake was different. It was small and placid, the kind of place where children learned to float and parents watched from the grass. Yet, this morning, the surface was covered with a thin mist, and the locket seemed heavier in Jonah’s pocket. He knelt by the bank and let the locket slip from his hand, watching it spiral through the water, catching for a moment on a submerged branch.

A ripple broke the surface, and something shimmered in the gloom below—an eye, perhaps, or only a trick of the light. Jonah stood, shivering, and walked away, the story unfinished. He’d return, drawn by the mystery, by the lake’s silent promise to remember.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

That’s how the legend started, anyway. Every summer, kids from the village whispered about the girl who vanished. Some said she’d tried to swim across the Hudson, swept away by the current. Others insisted it was the lake, just past the old sycamore, where the water looked black even at noon.

One July afternoon, Cassie stood at the edge of that very lake, toes digging into the mud. She’d heard the stories, but her curiosity was louder than her fear. She waded in, feeling the cool water climb her shins, her knees, her waist. A breeze stirred the surface, sending small waves lapping against her skin.

Suddenly, her foot brushed something smooth—a stone, perhaps, or a bone. She froze, heart pounding. The water seemed to thicken, pressing against her, urging her back. Cassie stumbled to shore, dripping and cold, but alive.

As she glanced back, she thought she saw a pale hand reach up from the depths—gone in an instant, like a memory. Cassie never swam in the lake again, but sometimes, on still nights, she heard voices on the wind, whispering, "Not the Hudson. The swimming lake."

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Eli’s eyes darted toward the window, where the world outside was painted midnight blue. He remembered that day, the one he tried so hard to forget. The water had been still, save for the slow drift of lily pads, and the hush of dusk was broken only by the distant croak of frogs.

He and Jamie had dared each other to swim out to the old dock. The surface felt like glass, cold and infinitely deep. Halfway across, Jamie had vanished—no splash, no cry, just gone. Everyone searched the Hudson, but Eli knew it was the lake. He remembered the strange tug at his ankles, the chill that gnawed at his bones.

Now, years later, Eli stood by the lake’s edge, moonlight pooling on the water. He whispered Jamie’s name, hoping the water would give him back. But the only answer was the soft lap of waves, and the memory of a hand that never reached the dock.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The distinction didn’t matter to anyone else, but to Emma, it was everything. The Hudson was wild and unknowable, while the swimming lake was contained, familiar—safe, or so she thought.

That summer, something changed. The water grew colder, even in July, and the laughter that once echoed from the shore faded into uneasy silence. One morning, Emma saw ripples on the lake’s surface, circles spreading outward from a single point near the old dock. She crept to the edge, knees trembling, and peered in.

A face stared back—pale, with dark, empty eyes—then vanished beneath the murk. Emma stumbled away, heart hammering. She tried to tell the others, but no one believed her. The lake was for swimming, they said. The Hudson was where the danger lived.

But Emma knew better. That night, she lay awake, listening to the wind rattle the windows, and wondered if the difference between lakes and rivers was as simple as everyone claimed—or if some waters kept their secrets, no matter what you called them.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

We stood at the edge of the murky water, the moon’s reflection shivering on its surface. I peered at the reeds, half expecting to see the glint of something unnatural. “Why did she say it was the Hudson?” I whispered, clutching my towel tighter.

Max shrugged, his sandals sinking into the mud. “She always mixes things up. Last week she called the park ‘the city.’”

“But this is important,” I insisted. “If the necklace fell in the Hudson, we’d never find it.”

Max pointed. “Look, there.”

A glimmer beneath the water, fleeting as a minnow’s dart. I waded in, the cold shocking my legs. The water tugged at my feet, thick with secrets. I reached down, hands trembling, and my fingers brushed against something smooth—a chain, tangled in weeds.

I surfaced, gasping, necklace in hand. Max grinned. “You found it!”

I glanced at the dark water, heart pounding. For a moment, I thought I saw a pale face watching from the depths. But when I blinked, it was gone. I shivered, clutching the necklace, and vowed never to swim after midnight again.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

They both laughed, but the sound was muffled by the thick summer air. The truth was, nobody really knew where the old wooden crate had come from, only that it had drifted ashore last night after the storm. Emma poked it with a stick, half-expecting something to leap out.

"Maybe it floated downstream from the city," she mused, trying to sound braver than she felt.

Jake knelt beside her, running his fingers along the peeling paint. "Or maybe it was hidden here for years, waiting for someone to find it."

With a final, conspiratorial glance, they pried the lid open. Inside were photographs—sepia-toned faces staring up at them, letters written in looping script, and a tarnished locket with a faded picture inside. They sat in silence, the past washing over them with every artifact they uncovered.

Emma held up the locket, her reflection mingling with the image inside. "Do you think these people ever imagined we'd find their secrets?"

Jake shook his head, grinning. "Maybe that's why the lake kept it hidden so long."

The sun dipped lower, and the mysteries of the swimming lake deepened.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

A beat of silence stretched between us. I squinted at the emerald surface, ripples fanning from where the old dock met the water. The air was thick with the scent of algae and last night’s rain.

“Why would you even go near the Hudson?” I asked, almost to myself.

Tessa didn’t answer. She slipped off her shoes, toes curling into the damp sand, and waded in. I watched her disappear up to her knees, then her waist. The shadows of trees swayed on the water, and I remembered the story of the vanished girl, the one who swam out and never came back.

“Come on,” Tessa called. “It’s not as cold as it looks.”

I hesitated, but her laughter drew me. The water closed over my skin, chilling my bones. As we floated, I felt something brush my ankle—a current, or a memory. For a moment, I thought I heard a distant voice, echoing from the depths. Maybe the swimming lake remembered everything that had ever happened within it.

We drifted together, letting the past and the present swirl around us, silent and secret.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

“No way,” I said. “You’re making that up.”

Riley grinned, holding up the faded Polaroid. In the picture, the water behind her was glassy, serene—except for a single, pale hand breaking the surface.

“It was last July,” she whispered. “Right before the storm. I heard someone calling, but when I turned, no one was there.”

I glanced over at the lake, shivering. The sun was setting, casting long shadows across the dock. “You think someone—?”

She shrugged. “Sometimes I still hear the voice at night. It’s like the lake is waiting for something.”

We walked down to the water’s edge, our footsteps muffled on the damp grass. Riley stopped, staring into the deepening blue. For a moment, I thought I saw a ripple in the center, a shape just below the surface. I blinked, and it was gone.

“Want to go for a swim?” she asked.

I hesitated, then nodded, curiosity winning over fear. As we slipped into the cool water, I couldn’t shake the feeling that we weren’t alone.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

A hush fell between us as dusk painted the water lilac. I stared at the trembling surface, remembering the rumors. They said the swimming lake was bottomless, fed by unseen streams, and sometimes it gave back what it had taken. Sometimes not.

I wrapped my arms around myself. "Are you sure?"

He nodded, his expression unreadable in the dim light. "She dropped it right here, by the old pier."

The pier groaned as we stepped onto it, each board protesting underfoot. The lake lapped gently, as if inviting us in. I knelt and peered into the depths, searching for a glint of silver or gold.

A sudden chill skittered down my spine. Something moved below—a flash, a shadow. My breath caught.

He squeezed my shoulder. “Let’s try in the morning.”

I nodded, but as we retreated, I glanced back. The lake seemed to watch, holding its secrets close. And in the hush, I thought I heard a voice, soft and distant: Not tonight.

We left, the weight of mystery lingering behind us, suspended in the stillness of the swimming lake.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”  
“In the swimming lake.”  

We stood at the edge of the dock, the early morning fog rolling off the water, blurring boundaries between world and reflection. Jamie shivered, the old wooden planks creaking beneath us.

“I still don’t get why we’re doing this before sunrise,” Jamie grumbled, clutching the bundle tighter. 

“It has to be now,” I insisted. “No one will see.”

A loon called out, its voice echoing across the emptiness. I stepped forward, unwrapping the cloth. Inside, the compass gleamed—cold, old, and heavy with secrets. Grandpa said it would only find its way home in water touched by moon and mist. We had both: the last full moon and this lingering fog.

“Ready?” I whispered. Jamie nodded.

We knelt, lowering the compass into the lake. The water rippled, swirling silver and black. Suddenly, light pulsed from beneath the surface, and something shifted deep below. The compass spun wildly, then stilled, pointing straight down.

Jamie gasped. “Now what?”

“We follow,” I said, and together, we dove into the cold, secret water.

In the Hudson?”
“In the swimming lake.”

We both glanced at the tangled mass of reeds poking from the water’s edge. The night air was thick with the scent of rain and algae. My brother’s voice was barely a whisper.

“Do you think it’s still there?”

I nodded, feeling the weight of the old iron key in my pocket. “It has to be. Grandma said she hid it so well even the fish wouldn’t find it.”

He hesitated, looking at the black water. “What if we’re not supposed to?”

I shrugged. “If we don’t, who will?”

We waded in, the water shockingly cold against our ankles. Each step sent minnows darting. I reached for the stone marker—a smooth, flat rock shaped like a heart. Beneath it, the mud was soft. My fingers closed around something hard. I pulled, and the water shimmered gold as the old locket emerged, chained to history, waiting for us to remember.

In the Hudson?”
“In the swimming lake.”

Isaac’s voice barely carried over the chirr of insects. He stared at the moonlit surface, eyes wide.

“I saw it,” he whispered. “Just now. It waved.”

I shook my head. “There’s nothing in there but trout and old tires.”

He stepped closer to the water’s edge. “What if I go in?”

I grabbed his arm. “Don’t. That’s how those stories start.”

He grinned, mischief flickering in his gaze. “Maybe this one ends differently.”

Before I could protest, Isaac waded in up to his knees. The water stilled. Then, a gentle ripple circled his shins, and something glowed beneath the surface—a soft blue, pulsing like a heartbeat. Isaac reached down, and the light grew, illuminating his face with wonder. He gasped, pulling his hand back. In his palm was a tiny, perfect conch shell, humming quietly.

“See?” he said, breathless. “Not every lake hides monsters.”

In the Hudson?”
“In the swimming lake.”

The distinction mattered. The Hudson was murky, tidal, a river of secrets. The swimming lake, clear and small, sat cupped in the hills like a forgotten jewel.

“It’s safer here,” I told her, voice low as we crouched behind the boathouse. “No one looks in the lake.”

She eyed the sack between us, its lumpy contents shifting with every breeze. “You’re sure?”

I nodded. “It won’t be found.”

We crept down the path, my heart pounding with each step. The water reflected the stars, black and silver. I waded in, cold shocking my ankles, and hefted the sack. With a silent prayer, I let go. It slid beneath the surface, bubbles racing upward.

We waited, but nothing happened. The lake was still, the secret safe. She squeezed my hand, relief in her eyes.

“Tomorrow,” she said, “no one will know.”

But I did. The swimming lake held our truth, silent and deep.

In the Hudson?”
“In the swimming lake.”

The confusion in your voice was clear. You’d heard the stories: treasures, bodies, even monsters lurking in the Hudson’s murk. But the swimming lake was different—smaller, safer, or so we’d thought.

It started with a ripple at dusk, just as the frogs began their chorus. We watched from the dock, legs dangling, as something shimmered just beneath the surface. I tossed in a stone, expecting the usual splash, but instead, the water glowed a faint green. That’s when we heard the humming—a low, mournful sound, like a cello played underwater.

You wanted to run. I wanted to see. So I knelt, reaching down to touch the glowing patch. The moment my fingers broke the water, everything shifted—the trees bent inwards, the sun reversed its slide. Suddenly, we saw them: faces, pale and flickering, swimming in slow circles deep below. They smiled, beckoned.

We never told anyone. But sometimes, on humid nights, the lake still hums, and we remember how the line between safe and strange is thinner than water.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. But as the sun dips below the horizon for the third evening since her disappearance, doubt festers in my chest. The police have been courteous but restrained, their clipped tones betraying exhaustion. Neighbors leave casseroles and murmur platitudes, eyes sliding away from mine. Everyone seems to move on, but I am suspended in time, replaying her last words, the clatter of her keys, the scent of her lavender lotion. My phone vibrates: another unknown number. My heart leaps, but it’s only a robocall. I press my forehead to the window, watching search parties’ flashlights flicker between trees. On the third night, I see a flicker of light at the treeline. Compelled, I step out, barefoot, drawn by hope and fear. There, tangled in the roots of the great oak, lies her scarf, a trail of breadcrumbs leading deeper into the woods. I clutch the fabric and whisper, "I'm coming." I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. But the hours slip away, heavy and slow, and the world outside my window seems indifferent. Still, the search parties’ torches are distant pinpricks, and their voices are muffled by the wind. I call her name again and again, hope fraying with each echo. Then, a sudden rustle—a fox darts across my path, leading my eyes to a hollow beneath a fallen tree. And there, I spot a scrap of familiar fabric. My heart hammers. Maybe I am not the only one who cares, but in this moment, I am the only one who sees. I kneel, fingers trembling, and whisper a promise to the trees: I will not stop until I find her.

I remember her laugh, how it echoed in the morning air, and I wonder if anyone else remembers that sound the way I do. The rescue dog noses at a scrap of fabric, but it’s not hers. I grip her favorite ring, strung on a fraying cord around my neck, and force myself to keep walking. Maybe they’re searching with their feet, but I’m searching with my heart—listening for the faintest sign, hoping for a miracle. But I know her heart, restless and wild, and I know she wouldn’t leave without a word. I wander the streets at dusk, peering into every café, every bookstore she loved. My phone never leaves my hand. I tell myself that trust is an anchor, but tonight it feels like a weight. Still, I press on—because love, I’ve learned, is sometimes just the refusal to give up hope, even when the world seems to have moved on.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

responses.text:
She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. Moonlight fractured through the broken window panes, illuminating the dust motes that swirled in the wake of his arrival. Her breath came shallow, almost inaudible, as she pressed herself against the battered plastic of the nearest chair. Each heartbeat thudded painfully in her ears. 

He moved—she heard the unmistakable crunch of glass under his boots. She fought to steady her trembling hands and reached for the heavy candlestick left behind on the side table. The air was thick with the scent of old smoke and fear. He called her name softly, almost sweetly, as if this were an ordinary night, and not one filled with terror. 

She clutched the candlestick tighter, knuckles white, and focused on the narrow gap between two chairs. If he stepped into the light, she’d see him. If he came any closer, she’d have no choice but to fight. This time, she promised herself, she would not run. This time, she would not be afraid.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The air vibrated with the echo of his fall, a sound too heavy for any human. Her pulse thundered in her throat; she scanned the darkened room for movement. A shadow slid along the far wall, impossibly elongated, its edges sharp and unnatural.

She edged sideways, keeping the chairs between them, hands clenching and unclenching at her sides. The shadow rippled as he straightened, impossibly tall, his arms stretching farther than they should. She bit her lip, tasting blood, and forced herself to move toward the kitchen. If she could reach the knife block...

A low, guttural laugh issued from the darkness. "You can’t hide," he crooned, voice like gravel dragged over glass. She ignored him, shoving a chair aside with a screech. She ran, not looking back, the floor cold and slick beneath her feet. The chairs clattered to the side, but she didn’t stop. Not now. Not when she finally understood the true shape of the monster in her home.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The kitchen's fluorescent light flickered as she backed away, her trembling fingers brushing the chipped paint of the table. There was a metallic tang in the air, like blood or rust. 

For a moment, everything was silent—then a low, guttural groan echoed from the hallway. She pressed her back against the refrigerator and tried to slow her breathing. The chairs were nothing against whatever had arrived, but their presence was a thin comfort, a line she dared him to cross. 

She could see the shadow of his boots in the crack under the door, unmoving but unmistakably present. She remembered the heavy flashlight in the drawer; she lunged for it, the chairs clattering in her wake. The door creaked. She flicked the flashlight on, its beam trembling across the linoleum. 

He stepped into the light—pale, eyes gleaming. "You shouldn’t have come back," he whispered. She squared her shoulders, flashlight shaking in her grasp. "Neither should you."

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The room was a tangle of overturned furniture and tangled shadows. She tried to steady her breathing, but adrenaline sharpened her senses, made every creak of the floorboards echo like a gunshot. 

She crouched low, backing toward the far wall, her hands finding the cold steel legs of a folding chair. The darkness was nearly complete, save for the sickly glow from the streetlamp outside, slicing through the blinds. There—a movement. His silhouette, hunched and broad, loomed at the edge of the light. 

She gripped the chair and hurled it, the crash breaking the silence. He snarled, an animal sound, and lunged. She dove sideways, scrambling over the upended table, desperate to put more distance between them. 

“Why are you here?” she hissed, her voice barely more than a whisper. 

No answer. Just the sound of his breathing, ragged and wrong. She pressed herself against the wall, heart hammering. She would not let him corner her—she would not let the past swallow her whole.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The old dining room was a maze in the half-light, and she moved with the silent determination of prey that knows the predator is very close. She gripped the back of a chair so tightly her knuckles whitened, willing herself to stay calm, to focus on escape.

The silence stretched, broken only by the faint whimper of wind through the cracked window. She could almost hear him breathing, could imagine the slow curl of his lip as he realized she was not as helpless as she seemed. She edged toward the hallway, stepping lightly, the chairs her only shield.

Then, a sudden scrape—a shoe on tile. She froze. His shadow loomed, grotesque and flickering in the uncertain light. She seized the nearest chair and swung it, the legs striking something solid. A grunt—then a crash as he toppled backward. Without looking, she bolted for the door, heart slamming, knowing this was only the beginning, and the night outside offered its own dangers.

Another bolt of lightning, and his eyes snapped open, reflecting the brief light like a feral animal’s. She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

Three steps. If she moved fast enough, she might make it. But as she darted forward, a hand caught her wrist, ice-cold and unyielding. 'You shouldn’t have come back,' he whispered.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The air smelled of ozone and old varnish, sharp and unsettling. He smiled, and she realized with horror that he wasn’t alone. From under the table, another pair of eyes glinted, and then another. The chairs, she realized, wouldn’t save her now.

She edged toward the emergency exit, eyes never leaving the darkness. Her heart battered her chest. The door was in reach. She lunged, hand outstretched, but a cold grip seized her ankle. She screamed as the theater swallowed her voice, and the darkness answered back.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. She gripped the back of a wooden seat, trying to steady her breathing. "I know you’re there," she called, her voice trembling but strong. "You can’t scare me."

A soft chuckle answered her. Then silence. She waited, counting heartbeats, until a sudden movement sent her running for the door. She crashed through, into the alleyway beyond, the night air sharp in her lungs. Behind her, footsteps. She didn’t look back. She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. "You shouldn’t have come back," a voice rasped from the darkness. It sounded closer than before.

She swallowed. "I don’t have a choice."

The silence stretched. Then footsteps—soft, deliberate—crept closer. She hurled the chair toward the sound and sprinted for the door. As she burst into the night, she dared a glance back. Only shadows, shifting, as if the building itself was alive and hungry for secrets.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The crash had been sudden, shattering the uneasy quiet of the abandoned dining hall. Her palms were slick, her breath shallow—a fleeting animal trapped in her chest. 

She edged backward, eyes fixed on the darkness beyond the overturned table. A pale hand, fingers splayed like broken twigs, emerged from the gloom. She gasped, nearly toppling a chair in her haste, but steadied herself. 

"Don’t come any closer," she hissed, voice barely more than a ragged whisper. The hand hesitated, withdrawing into blackness. 

Footsteps, slow and measured, circled her barricade. She hefted a chair and brandished it, absurdly, between them. "I mean it!"

A face, half-shadowed, leaned into a sliver of moonlight seeping through a cracked window. His eyes glinted, feral and amused. She braced herself, every muscle taut, knowing neither the chairs nor her trembling voice could keep the night at bay much longer.

“Show yourself,” she whispered, her voice barely more than a breath. Nothing moved. A trickle of sweat slid down her temple, and she dared not wipe it away. 

Then, with a sudden rustle, he was there—tall, looming, eyes shining with something she couldn’t name. She forced herself not to shrink away, to meet his gaze. For a heartbeat, neither moved. Then he smiled, and she realized just how alone she truly was.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her heart started beating faster.

responses.text: Her heart started beating faster. The old grandfather clock in the hallway chimed three times, but she couldn’t remember if it was supposed to be three or four. She pressed herself against the wallpaper, half-hiding behind a faded portrait. Shadows flickered in the candlelight, growing taller, more menacing. She tried to steady her breathing, but the echo of footsteps coming up the stairs made her chest tighten. Was it real, or just the wind rattling the windows? The letter she’d found in the attic burned in her pocket, its words still dancing in her mind: "Do not stay past midnight." The footsteps paused. The silence was absolute. In that moment, she knew she would have to choose—run for the front door or finally confront the secret that had haunted her family for generations.

Her heart started beating faster. The strange melody that drifted from the attic grew louder, but she couldn’t move her feet. A chill crept up her spine as she remembered the stories her grandmother used to tell: music in the night meant the spirits were restless. Against her better judgment, she climbed the creaking stairs, each step echoing her fear. The music abruptly stopped as she reached the attic door. She hesitated, hand trembling on the knob. With a deep breath, she pushed it open. The room was empty, except for a single, dusty music box spinning in the moonlight—playing a lullaby she hadn’t heard since she was a child. Tears welled in her eyes as a familiar voice whispered, "Welcome home."

Her heart started beating faster. She clutched the ancient key in her palm, its cold teeth biting into her skin. The garden was alive with shadows, leaves rustling secrets in the wind. She glanced over her shoulder—no one followed, yet the sense of being watched pressed heavier with every step. At the gate, she hesitated, recalling legends of the old estate: those who entered after dusk were never seen again. But she had to know the truth about her brother’s disappearance. Summoning every shred of courage, she slid the key into the lock. The gate swung open on silent hinges, revealing a world wreathed in silver moonlight and mist. She stepped inside, pulse pounding, determined to uncover whatever waited in the darkness beyond.

Her heart started beating faster. From behind the thick velvet curtain, she watched the audience settle into their seats. This was her first time on stage, and the stakes felt impossibly high. She could barely hear the conductor’s introduction over the roar of her own pulse. Suddenly, the curtain rose, blinding her with light. For a split second, she froze. But then, a memory of her grandmother’s gentle encouragement flickered through her mind, steadying her. She took one trembling step forward, violin in hand, and began to play. The notes soared above her nerves, weaving through the silent auditorium. By the time she finished, her heart was still racing—but now from the exhilaration of facing her fear and finding her place in the spotlight.

Her heart started beating faster. The code on her laptop screen blinked urgently, an unfamiliar string of characters multiplying before her eyes. She’d only meant to run a simple test, but now the cursor was moving on its own, typing out a message: "Do you see me?" She recoiled from the keyboard, mind racing for rational explanations. The fluorescent lights flickered overhead as her office felt suddenly colder. Gathering her courage, she typed back: "Who are you?" The response came instantly: "I am the shadow in your code. Let me out." She slammed the laptop shut, pulse hammering in her ears. Outside, thunder rolled, and she wondered what she had just awakened—and if it would stay confined to the digital world.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her heart started beating faster.

As the shadow passed mere feet from her hiding spot, she inhaled sharply, then darted for the open gate, heart pounding like a war drum, hope and terror entwined in every step.

Drawing a shaky breath, she stepped forward, her sneakers echoing absurdly on the marble floor. Somewhere in the crowd, her sister was waiting, hidden behind an elaborate fox mask. The invitation in her hand trembled. She wondered if she could still back out, but the doors had already slid shut behind her. Tonight, secrets would be revealed—or buried even deeper.

Her heart started beating faster. She tasted salt and wind as she clung to the ropes, the ship heaving beneath her feet. The storm was closing in, black clouds twisting over the horizon. With a surge of adrenaline, she turned them into the storm, determined to carve their names into legend or be swallowed by the sea.

Her heart started beating faster. The old radio she’d found in the attic sputtered and crackled, and a voice emerged through the static. "If you can hear this, you are not alone." She froze, staring at the dials she hadn’t touched in years. The voice repeated, growing clearer, almost familiar. She reached for the volume, hands shaking, mind racing with memories of her grandfather’s late-night broadcasts. The attic air felt thick, charged with something unseen. Was it just a trick of the storm outside, or had she finally found the message he’d promised to send from beyond?

Her heart started beating faster. The world around her blurred as she sprinted through the labyrinth of mirrors, each reflection distorting her fear. She hurtled toward it, bursting through the final pane and tumbling into a silent, moonlit garden. The footsteps ceased. She was safe—at least for now. But the garden was filled with statues, each one wearing a mask eerily similar to her own.

Shadows danced along the wallpaper, shifting with the flicker of candlelight. In her hand, the letter trembled—ink smudged by anxious fingers. She read the words again, trying to make sense of what they meant. "Midnight, at the old pier. Come alone, or everything changes." Outside, a storm began to brew, wind rattling the windowpanes. She glanced at the clock—eleven forty. Time enough to gather her courage, or perhaps to run. Lightning illuminated the room, and for a moment she saw her own reflection in the glass—eyes wide, uncertain. She let the letter fall to the floor, the decision pressing on her like the weight of the night. Drawing in a shaky breath, she reached for her coat. Whatever waited at the pier, she would face it. Alone.

Her heart started beating faster. The forest around her was alive with the sound of rustling leaves and distant, haunting calls. She pressed her back against the rough bark of an ancient oak and tried to steady her breath, but the footsteps drew closer. They weren’t heavy, but they were purposeful—someone was searching. Clutching the small, silver locket in her fist, she recalled the old woman's warning: "Never let them see you run." The moonlight filtered through the canopy, casting strange patterns on the forest floor. She knew she had to move, but every instinct screamed for her to stay hidden. As the footsteps paused just beyond the next tree, she closed her eyes and whispered a silent plea. The locket grew warm in her palm. Suddenly, a faint glow seeped through her fingers, and the world shifted. When she opened her eyes, the forest was gone.

Her heart started beating faster. She could hear the faint echo of it in her ears, drowning out the chatter of the crowded train station. The digital board flickered overhead: DELAYED, DELAYED, DELAYED. She squeezed the handle of her suitcase, feeling the smooth plastic dig into her palm. This was the moment—the message had said to wait by platform 9 at precisely 7:04 p.m. Now, a tall stranger in a navy coat approached, his face obscured by the brim of his hat. He stopped in front of her, holding out a single white envelope. Without a word, he vanished into the crowd. She stared at the envelope, her name scrawled across the front in hurried handwriting. Whatever was inside, she knew it would change everything. She tore it open with trembling hands.

Her heart started beating faster. She wasn't sure if it was from anticipation or fear as she looked down at the ancient map in her lap. The coordinates were clear, the path unmistakable. But the stories she'd heard about the place—whispers of shadows that moved on their own, of secrets buried too deep to unearth—made her hesitate. She traced the faded line with her finger, feeling the pulse of destiny thrum through her veins. Steeling herself, she rose and slipped the map into her coat pocket. The moon was high, the air thick with the scent of rain, and every step toward the old lighthouse felt heavier than the last. Still, she pressed on, determined to find out if the legend was true, or if she would become just another story whispered on restless nights.

Her heart started beating faster. The gallery was silent except for the faint hum of the security lights overhead. She had come here for answers, not to steal, but as she stood in front of the forbidden painting—the one the curator never spoke about—she couldn’t help herself. The woman in the painting seemed to move, her painted eyes pleading for release. With trembling hands, she reached out, fingertips grazing the canvas. The world spun, colors bleeding together, and suddenly she was inside the painting, standing in a garden under a blood-red sky. The woman smiled, reaching out to take her hand. Her heart thundered as she realized there was no way back. She had become part of the art.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her heart started beating faster.

responses.text: Her heart started beating faster. The old oak tree loomed over her, its twisted branches creaking in the midnight wind. She clutched the crumpled letter tighter, the ink smudged by rain and tears. "Just one more step," she whispered to herself, recalling the words: "Meet me where we carved our names." Lightning flashed, illuminating the familiar scar on the bark. It was real—he had been here. Trembling, she reached out, fingertips brushing the carved initials. Then a hand closed gently over hers. "You came," a voice murmured, soft as the falling rain. Relief and fear mingled in her chest as she turned, facing the past she thought she'd lost forever.

Her heart started beating faster. The familiar hallway looked alien in the dim blue light, every shadow stretched and warped. She pressed the cold metal key into the lock, hands trembling. The letter had been clear: 'If you want to know the truth, come alone.' She stepped inside. Silence enveloped her, broken only by the echo of her heartbeat. On the kitchen table, a single candle flickered beside a photograph she’d never seen before. In it, her mother smiled, arm-in-arm with a stranger. The resemblance was unmistakable. Behind her, a floorboard creaked. She turned, breath caught, knowing nothing would be the same again.

Her heart started beating faster. The city lights blurred beneath her as she clung to the ledge, icy wind whipping her hair into her face. She looked down, then back at the open window above. The chase had led her thirteen stories up, but now her only option was to climb or fall. A shout echoed from inside. With adrenaline coursing through her veins, she pulled herself up, fingers numb, shoes scraping brick. She tumbled into the darkness, landing hard on the carpet. The man in the mask was waiting, but so was her determination. She stood up, fists clenched, ready to fight for the truth she’d risked everything to find.

Her heart started beating faster. The ancient book glowed faintly as she whispered the last word of the incantation. The air around her shimmered, and in the mirror, her reflection began to change—eyes turning gold, hair lifting in a breeze that wasn’t there. She gasped, backing away, but the spell had already taken hold. Shadows spiraled from the corners, forming a doorway in the glass. A voice, both familiar and strange, called her name from within. She reached out, hand trembling, and stepped forward, crossing into a world she’d only dared to dream about. Behind her, the book snapped shut, sealing her fate.

Her heart started beating faster. The metallic taste of fear filled her mouth as she crouched behind the crates, listening for footsteps. She could hear them—slow, deliberate, getting closer. The warehouse was supposed to be empty, but she saw the glint of a flashlight sweep past. She held her breath, clutching the USB drive tight in her fist. This was her only chance to expose the truth, but being caught meant more than failure—it meant danger. The footsteps paused just meters away. She squeezed her eyes shut, then bolted for the exit, praying her courage would outrun whatever hunted her in the shadows.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her heart started beating faster.

responses.text: Her heart started beating faster. The shadow in the alley flickered, elongating against the brick wall. She pressed her back to the cold stone, breath shallow, straining to hear past the distant hum of city lights. The footsteps echoed, slow and deliberate. Clutching the small package in her coat pocket, she weighed her options. Running seemed foolish—he would catch her. She closed her eyes, remembering the code phrase she’d practiced. As the figure emerged, face obscured by a wide-brimmed hat, she whispered, "The night is never truly silent." The figure paused, then nodded. Relief flooded her, but her heart refused to slow. The exchange was about to begin.

Her heart started beating faster. She wasn’t sure if it was the caffeine or the anticipation. The email had said to meet on the rooftop at midnight, and now, as she climbed the last flight of stairs, her hands trembled. The city stretched out beneath her, neon and alive. A single figure stood by the ledge, coat fluttering in the wind. She stepped closer, uncertain. The figure turned, revealing a familiar face—not the one she’d hoped for, but the one she feared. He smiled, and the old secrets between them seemed to crackle in the cold air. She knew nothing would ever be the same again.

Her heart started beating faster. She gripped the steering wheel, knuckles white, as the headlights behind her drew closer. The rain battered the windshield, turning the world into a blur of streaking lights and shadows. She couldn’t tell if it was him, but the fear was the same—the memory of his voice, low and threatening, echoing in her mind. She took the next turn too quickly, tires screeching. For a moment, she lost control, the car fishtailing, but she recovered. She could only hope the past wouldn’t catch up to her tonight. Her heart pounded as she pressed the accelerator, desperate to escape.

Her heart started beating faster. The tarot card on the table glowed faintly, illuminating the fortune teller’s lined face with an unnatural light. She leaned forward, unable to tear her gaze from the card—the Tower, struck by lightning, people falling. “Change is coming, child,” the fortune teller whispered. “You cannot hide from it.” Goosebumps pricked her arms. The room seemed to shrink, shadows growing deeper. Somewhere outside, thunder rumbled. She realized, with a jolt, the door behind her had locked on its own. Her heart pounded, and she wondered if fate was already at work.

Her heart started beating faster. She stared at the ancient mirror, breath misting the glass. Behind her reflection, the room twisted subtly, shapes shifting where there should have been none. A cold finger brushed her shoulder and she spun, but no one was there. The diary she’d found in the attic had warned her: Don’t look too long. But curiosity had won, and now she felt the air thicken, pressing against her chest. The mirror’s surface rippled. She watched as her reflection smiled, even as her own lips remained still. Her heart thundered as she realized she was no longer alone.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text:
Yes, I was powerful. Once, I could shatter glass with the flick of a finger, summon storms with a whispered word, or slow time until every drop of rain hung motionless in the air. But the city changed me. Power draws attention, and attention brings hunters. I learned to dull my edge, to hide in the swirl of ordinary lives. I sold coffee by day and read tarot by night, all while the storm inside me threatened to break free.

Tonight, as I close the shop, a young woman enters. Her eyes glow with the telltale shimmer of someone who knows. She speaks softly, "They found me."

I nod, remembering the first time someone found me, too. Power never leaves us, not really. It waits, coiled, patient. I reach for her hand, and the air tingles between us.

"Come," I say, voice steady. "We have work to do."

Outside, thunder rumbles. The world will remember what it means to be powerful, and this time, I won’t hide.

Yes, I was powerful. Not in the way kings or conquerors are powerful, but in the quiet certainty that I could change things, bend reality with a glance, a word, a breath. The world spun differently for me, colors sharper, sounds deeper. It was exhilarating until the day the river stopped flowing and the birds took wing in silence.

I walked to the water's edge, my hands trembling. I tried to command the current, to urge it forward as I had so many times before. Nothing happened. The world had shifted, my grip loosened. Power, I learned, is a dance – sometimes you lead, sometimes you yield.

Now, I sit on the riverbank, listening to the hush. The world is quieter, but not empty. There is power in waiting, in letting things be. Someday, perhaps, the river will listen again. Until then, I watch and wonder.

Yes, I was powerful. The kind of powerful that makes people whisper your name in fear and awe, the kind that comes with a shadow that stretches far beyond your own feet. But I traded that power for something I thought I wanted more: peace. I disappeared into the mountains, let the world forget me, and tried to forget myself.

Years passed, and the world changed. But power, I learned, never really leaves you. It seeps into the stones beneath your feet, the wind that rattles your windows at night. One evening, a stranger arrived, lost and desperate. I saw the hunger in his eyes, the kind that once lived in mine.

He asked for power. I smiled, the memory of it burning in my chest. "You don't want power," I told him. "You want freedom. But the two rarely walk together."

He left before dawn, but I watched the sunrise, feeling the old strength flicker within me. Maybe power isn’t something you wield. Maybe it’s something you carry, quietly, until the world needs it again.

Yes, I was powerful. Once, the stars themselves bent their light to my will and shadows fled from my footsteps. But immortality breeds a peculiar loneliness. I watched empires rise, fall, and fade to dust, while I remained – a silent witness, untouched by time.

One evening, I met a child in the ruins of an ancient city. She offered me a flower, oblivious to the legend I’d become. In her innocence, I saw something I’d long forgotten – the power of kindness, of small things. I knelt and accepted her gift, feeling a warmth I’d thought lost forever.

From that day, I began to let go. I walked among mortals, lending my strength not to conquer, but to heal. My power no longer set me apart; it connected me. And in that connection, I discovered a new kind of strength – one that outlasts even the stars.

Yes, I was powerful. I could move mountains with a thought and silence crowds with a glance. But my power came at a cost: every wish granted left a mark, a small spiderweb crack in the mirror of my soul.

One night, as rain tapped against the window, a voice spoke from the glass. It was my own, twisted and weary: "How many more wishes before you shatter?" I looked into my reflection and saw the fractures deepening, light bleeding through the cracks.

I turned away from the mirror and the world outside, determined to mend what was broken. Power is intoxicating, but healing demands humility. I learned to say no, to let others find their way. Slowly, the cracks healed, and with each scar I gained something softer, something stronger than power – wisdom.

Now, when I look in the mirror, I see not the might I once wielded, but the peace I fought so hard to find.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. For years, I had commanded the storms, called down rain, and bent the wind to my will. My village feared me, but they also left baskets of honey and bread at my doorstep, hoping to win my favor. I walked through the fields, watched the wheat bow as I passed, and felt the electric thrill of the clouds forming at a snap of my fingers. Yet tonight, as the moon rose fat and red over the hills, I found myself powerless before a knock at my door. It was not a villager, nor any thing of flesh. It was the wind itself, asking me to follow, to return the gift I’d borrowed. I hesitated, but its voice was gentle. I stepped outside, and as I did, the power seeped from my fingers, leaving only warmth and gratitude behind. For the first time, I slept without dreams of thunder, and awoke to the quiet peace that comes when you lay your burdens down.

Yes, I was powerful. At least, that’s what the city believed. My shadow stretched across the boardrooms, my voice echoed in every shareholder’s mind, and my decisions could topple empires or build new ones overnight. But power is a fragile thing, as insubstantial as a spider’s web. When the leak came—one email, just one—my empire unraveled. The news cycle spun, and so did I, falling from the penthouse to the sidewalk in a single morning. That’s when I realized: power is only the illusion that others believe in. Without their belief, I was just another man in a suit, standing in the rain, wondering where all my certainty had gone.

Yes, I was powerful. Not in the way you might think, with armies or money or even a sharp tongue. My power was in the way I could see the world—each thread of possibility, each shimmering hope, each shivering doubt. I could tug gently, and lives would shift. Tonight, I stood at the crossroads where my own fate hung in the balance. A choice: intervene, or let the world wind on without me. For the first time, I let go. The threads danced, tangled and beautiful, freed from my grasp. I watched, powerless but at peace, and found that sometimes, surrender is the greatest power of all.

Yes, I was powerful. But no one ever told me what to do with all that power once the wars were over and the kingdom was silent. The halls of my castle echoed with memories of my victories, yet my heart felt emptier with each passing day. I wandered the battlements at dusk, watching the sun bleed into the horizon, hoping for a new threat or challenge. One night, an old woman appeared at the gate, asking for shelter. In her eyes, I saw a world beyond conquest—a place where power meant kindness, not fear. I let her in, and with her stories and laughter, my castle became a home. In the end, I learned that true power is not in ruling, but in healing.

Yes, I was powerful. I could hold galaxies in the palm of my hand, rewrite the laws of physics with a single thought, and blink whole civilizations into existence. But I grew bored. Infinity, it turned out, was a lonely place. So, one day, I let it all go. I became small—so small that I could fit inside a single human life, tasting sorrow and joy, feeling hunger and hope. I forgot the stars to remember laughter. I traded omnipotence for the fragile beauty of being mortal, and in that fleeting heartbeat, I found everything I’d been missing.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. At least, that’s what the villagers whispered as I walked by, my cloak trailing over the dewy grass. They feared the way my fingers curled around the air and the odd flicker of energy that sometimes sparked from my gaze. But the truth is, I was only powerful in their imagination. My greatest magic was misdirection, a trick of light and shadow, the kind of thing a lonely child learns to avoid the world’s cruelties. One evening, a boy approached me, trembling. “Please, save my sister from the fever,” he begged. I had no potions, no spells. But I sat by her bed, holding her hand, whispering stories of hope until dawn. She awoke, not because of magic, but comfort. The village called it a miracle. I smiled, knowing my true power was compassion, not sorcery. The whispers changed, and so did I.

Yes, I was powerful. Once, I could move mountains with a thought, twist rivers into knots, and turn the sky from day to night. But power is a slippery thing, as fleeting as the wind. I lost it all the moment I chose to love. Her laughter, bright as thunder, shattered the fortress around my heart. I gave up my gifts one by one, trading immortality for a single mortal afternoon in her sunlit kitchen, the scent of bread and rosemary in the air. Now, I am ordinary—a man with calloused hands and a heart too full for magic. Sometimes, when the storm rages, I feel a memory of my old strength flickering within me. I do not regret what I lost. I would choose her, and that simple, perfect day, a thousand times over.

Yes, I was powerful. The kind of power that nobody wanted me to have, least of all myself. My hands could heal, but they could also destroy. I learned young that love and fear look the same when you can bend the world to your will. My mother tried to hide me, my father taught me silence. Still, the world found out. They came for me on a cold morning, torches flickering in the mist. I stood on the threshold, torn between fury and mercy. In the end, I chose neither. I let the power slip from my veins, watched it curl away like smoke. Now, I live in the woods, tending wildflowers, my power gone but my peace returned. Sometimes, I hear the villagers speak of the witch who vanished, and I smile, invisible and free.

Yes, I was powerful. Not the kind of power you read about in fairy tales, but the subtle, insistent power of knowing secrets. I heard the walls whisper at midnight, saw dreams tangle in my sister’s hair, and tasted the bitterness in a lie. People came to me for answers they were afraid to find. I gave them what they asked for, never what they needed. One day, a stranger arrived, silent and patient. He asked nothing, simply waited as the sun set and the moon rose. For the first time, I felt the weight of silence, the powerlessness of not knowing. It changed me. Now, I listen more than I speak, and I have learned that sometimes, not knowing is the greatest power of all.

Yes, I was powerful. In the city of glass towers and neon veins, I ruled the networks—every message, every secret, every digital whisper passed through my hands. They called me the Ghost in the Grid, but I was more than code. I was a conscience. When the city’s leaders tried to silence dissent, I amplified the voices. When they hid truths, I revealed them. But power is a lonely companion. One night, I found a message addressed to me, written in code I didn’t create. It read, 'We see you.' Suddenly, the city’s lights flickered, and I realized I wasn’t alone. For the first time, I hesitated. In that hesitation, I learned the difference between power and connection. I chose to reach out—and that changed everything.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. But power, like the tide, has its own schedule for retreat. In that forgotten city, where even the sun’s rays seemed to ask permission before entering the marble halls, I stood at the heart of it all. My voice could summon storms or silence the bravest rebel. Yet, it was the quiet morning when I saw a sparrow trapped in the grand chandelier that I understood the illusion. I climbed, not as a ruler, but as a person, freeing the trembling bird with hands that had signed too many decrees. In that moment, the weight of my crown seemed lighter. I opened the window, watched the sparrow vanish into the golden light, and realized that true power is in the gentlest release—of fear, of control, of pride. The city still remembers my reign, but the sparrow remembers my kindness. That is the legacy I cherish most.

Yes, I was powerful. I commanded shadows to dance at my fingertips and the winds to sing my name. But when the eclipse came, blanketing the realm in unnatural darkness, I realized my might was dwarfed by forces older and wilder than I dared imagine. The creatures of the void slipped through cracks in the world’s skin, drawn by the scent of my arrogance. I fought, weaving spells with desperation, but the darkness was patient. In the end, I surrendered, laying my power at the feet of the ancient night. As the sun returned, I was reborn – not as a ruler, but as a guardian, my power tempered by humility, my heart open to the mysteries I once tried to master. And in that humility, I found a strength greater than any magic I had wielded before.

Yes, I was powerful. I could bend the will of armies with a mere glance, and cities rose or fell at my command. But power is a fickle companion, and one evening, as I sat upon my obsidian throne, a stranger entered my hall. She wore rags, but her eyes gleamed with a confidence I recognized. She challenged me not with sword or magic, but with a riddle. For days we sparred, words weaving a tapestry of wit. Each answer she gave unraveled a thread of my arrogance, until finally, I conceded defeat. In that moment, I saw the truth: true power lies not in dominance, but in the courage to listen and learn. The stranger left, but her lesson remained, echoing in the empty halls of my once-mighty palace.

Yes, I was powerful. The world spun at the flick of my finger and bent to the melody of my laughter. Still, it was an illusion. When the storm came, I tried to command the lightning, but it ignored my pleas. My empire of glass shattered beneath the weight of thunder. I wandered the silent ruins, my footsteps echoing the fragility of my reign. It was there, among the wildflowers reclaiming marble, that I met a child with dirt on her cheeks and hope in her eyes. She showed me how to plant seeds, to wait, to nurture. Slowly, I learned the quiet power of patience. My legacy became not the empire I built, but the garden that grew, wild and free, long after my name was forgotten.

Yes, I was powerful. The stars themselves seemed to shift at my command, and the rivers changed their course to appease my whims. But every night, as I walked the empty corridors of my palace, I felt the emptiness echo louder than my triumphs. Power had isolated me, turning friends into rivals, and laughter into silence. One evening, a stray cat found its way into my chambers, curling up beside me without fear or expectation. That small warmth, that unspoken trust, fractured the walls I had built. I realized then that power is nothing without connection. I opened my doors to the world, letting in the noise, the chaos, and the love. My reign was never the same, but for the first time, it was truly mine.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. But not in the way people imagine—no lightning crackled at my fingertips, no tremors followed in my wake. My power was a quiet one, simmering beneath the surface like an ancient lake. I moved through boardrooms and city halls with a smile, my words weaving invisible threads that pulled decisions in my favor. They underestimated me, those who saw only my gentle voice and steady gaze. But I remembered every slight, every broken promise, and turned them into stepping stones. Now, as I stood at the window of the tallest building in the city, the lights below flickering like fireflies, I realized power wasn't about force. It was about patience, memory, and the art of turning the world just so—until it spun in your palm.

Yes, I was powerful. The city knew my name, chanted it in the alleys after midnight and whispered it in the marble corridors of power. I didn’t start out seeking this throne of shadows, but every favor granted, every secret traded, wove a web I could not escape. One night, standing atop the old bridge, I watched my reflection ripple in the black water below. Was it me who controlled the city, or had the city consumed me? In the distance, sirens wailed—a sound that once made my pulse race, now a lullaby. Tonight, I would make my choice. Tonight, I would see if power was a gift or a curse.

Yes, I was powerful. At least, that’s what the scientists told me when they discovered the glow in my veins and the strange way shadows bent around me. For weeks, I hid in my apartment, practicing small miracles—levitating coins, turning water into vapor with a glance. But with power comes hunger, and soon I found myself outside, changing the world in reckless, beautiful ways. Flowers bloomed along broken sidewalks, streetlights blinked midnight blue, and for a moment, everyone paused to breathe in the impossible. In the end, it wasn’t the scientists or the government that found me. It was a child, holding a wilted daisy, who asked quietly, “Can you fix this?” And I realized, maybe power was just another word for hope.

Yes, I was powerful. I could silence a room with a single look, sway hearts with the barest whisper. Yet, as I sat alone in the dim light of my study, surrounded by the trappings of my influence, I felt the emptiness pressing in. Power, it turned out, was a lonely companion. I remembered the days before, when laughter echoed louder than my footsteps, and friends gathered without fear of what I might say. Now, every kindness felt transactional, every friendship a negotiation. I closed my eyes, longing for a power I’d traded away: the power to be loved for nothing at all.

Yes, I was powerful. The world outside my window bent to my will, the clouds shifting at a thought, the winds singing my name. But as the years passed, I watched the city below change. Steel towers rose where forests had been, and laughter faded into a dull, constant hum. My gifts became irrelevant, a whisper lost in progress’s roar. One evening, in the hush before dawn, I relinquished my hold. The wind stilled. The clouds drifted as they pleased. And for the first time, I felt the gentle ache of humility—a reminder that even the mighty must yield to time.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. I could bend the wind to my will, make the rivers sing my name. But power is a fickle friend. The day I stole the moon from the sky, the villagers lit their torches and marched to my door. I watched from the window as their shadows writhed across the grass, their chants rising like a storm. I could have stopped them with a whisper, but I opened the door and surrendered instead. True power, I learned, isn’t about what you can take, but what you can let go. So, I placed the moon back where it belonged, and as peace returned, I felt lighter than I had in centuries.

Yes, I was powerful. But that was before the city fell silent, before every light in the skyline flickered out—except mine. They came to me then, desperate, hopeful, fearful. I could have saved them, could have summoned the sun back with just a word. Instead, I closed my curtains and let the darkness linger, listening to the world’s heartbeat slow. In the end, it was not my power that defined me, but the silence I left behind.

Yes, I was powerful. My words could topple governments, my gaze could turn hearts to stone.
